story: Buongiorno Amici!! I welcome you to my page, and to my story. I am Nikkie. As an art student and aspiring author I am constantly in search for interesting stories and unique perspective to inspire me, so that in turn I may inspire others. My final chapter in undergrad studies is upon me, and I have chosen to spend my senior year in the CSU system studying in beautiful Florence Italy,right at the heart of the western civilization's artistic origins. Because I am such a knowledge hungry individual I decided to embark on a journey to find new tales and experiences across the sea. I push myself outside of my comfort zone whenever I can, and in fact pride myself in my ability to excel under even the hardest of situations. I always find a way to explore my dreams and fears. I have climbed a hundred foot tall redwood to conquer my fear of heights, raced collegiate cycling because I used to be afraid of riding bikes, and now am about to embark on an adventure abroad because I am afraid my knowledge of the world is not well rounded enough. My ultimate dream in life is to write and illustrate books in multiple genres and for all ages. I am currently working on 9 books... yup.... quite the work load... and have two kids tales illustrated and written ready for self publication. I work as a freelance graphic designer to help with some small expenses, but because I'm just starting out my networking is still just a tiny little web. Your help will mean the world to me, as I am taking out school loans to pay for my tuition and housing. I have earned a small scholarship from wining a county wide art competition in Ventura this past year, but any and all financial assistance will go a long way. With your help I can spend more time truly getting to know my host country, and perhaps surrounding countries, and less time scrambling to make rent and school expenses. I have included some awesome perks for you too, and welcome any conversation, advice on traveling, and wandering stories of your own. Thank you for reading about me, and I promise to make you all proud with the knowledge and skill that I'll work hard to achieve in my year abroad.

I work as a freelance graphic designer to help with some small expenses, but because I'm just starting out my networking is still just a tiny little web. Your help will mean the world to me, as I am taking out school loans to pay for my tuition and housing. I have earned a small scholarship from wining a county wide art competition in Ventura this past year, but any and all financial assistance will go a long way. With your help I can spend more time truly getting to know my host country, and perhaps surrounding countries, and less time scrambling to make rent and school expenses. I have included some awesome perks for you too, and welcome any conversation, advice on traveling, and wandering stories of your own. Thank you for reading about me, and I promise to make you all proud with the knowledge and skill that I'll work hard to achieve in my year abroad.

story:
How would you define Freedom?

My name is Logan McCulloch and I'm travelling from coast to coast by foot and now by bicycle.  Why?  I am a 55 year old survivor of chronic Lyme disease.  After recovering some of my health, I left my career, sold my home and possessions and spent 5 months hiking the Appalachian Trail to raise awareness of the devastating effects of the fastest growing epidemic in America.  I am continuing that effort with this cross-country journey, but through videos, blog posts and our website, my dear friend and Trek For Truth partner Drew Allgeier and I are tackling others issues as well.  Issues that relate to the systemic corruption, greed and self interest that are perpetuating not only the epidemic of Lyme disease, but that are suppressing the health, wealth and creative potential of so many, for the benefit of a tiny few.    

We can be and do so much more than we realize.  Drew and I and so many others around the world want to contribute in some way to the advancement of humanity.  One way is through a fearless dialogue with folks across this land, discussing what it means to be a free human being on this planet, and ways that we can support each other in making real freedom a reality.  As part of this adventure we are shooting footage with the people we meet to produce a documentary entitled "Freedom?"  Thus far I have backpacked more than 1,100 miles from the Atlantic Ocean back to my home in Kentucky.  Now I'm embarking on an attempt to bicycle the remaining 2,800+ miles to the Pacific coast near San Francisco.  We self-funded the first leg of this project, but now we need the help of like-minded individuals to continue the journey.  Please help if you can, and visit our website to find out more about Drew, myself and our work. Thank you!

VI ET ANIMO (Strength and Courage, Heart and Soul)

story:
I am starting this campain so I can get enough money together to have a deposit and money for the 1st months rent and food as well.

If you have seen the picture above that is what the flat looks like. I am trying to earn more money so I can make better YouTube content.

Also I am leaving my old room so my 16 year old brother who has autism can have it and share it with my 11 year old brother.

story:
(Für Deutsch nach unten scrollen)

Hello Friends wherever you are. My name is Miriama. I am a musician and a music teacher. For over 20 years I have facilitated music education for kids and adults through my rock school program. I was doing this even before the great Jack Black film " School of Rock" came out.  

The program has been developed over the years for many students from varied backgrounds in USA and Germany.   Participants blossomed in their young lives getting the chance  to discover their own personal versions of the rock and roll dream. Many of my earlier students are now professional musicians and true artists. I thank them for being the experimental pilots in the early development of the program.

 In late 2013, I traveled to Gambia, West Africa to volunteer at Fandema Women development Center in Tujering. Here is the story:

I had 2 guitars with me. My personal instrument for performances and one extra. My original idea was to find one lucky and motivated young woman, give her daily private lessons for the duration of my four week stay, and at the end, give her the guitar so that she could continue on her own. I arrived to the centre to offer my idea to The Center´s director, Malang Sambou. He suggested that we ask the women directly who among them might have interest to learn guitar. Later the same day  at the general meeting with everyone gathered together, Malang introduced me. I played one of Bob Marley´s songs, “No Woman No Cry”. Everyone sang along in the "Everythings gonna be alright" part. After an encore, (They wanted the same song again!), Malang asked the group in Mandinka, "who would like to learn to play guitar?" Almost all hands flew up. He continued: “OK, but whoever really wants to do it has to work very hard learning and practicing everyday, now who still wants to do it?” That narrowed the group to about half. He announced, “everyone who still wants to do it will now be tested on ability.  The best one will be chosen.” 

We immediately began the audition process. I said, "who´s first?", only one brave hand went up. Remember, these girls had never seen a real guitar, much less held and played one. Amazingly, all were quite proficient in air guitar, which is a good sign.  

Mballing Bojang made her way to the hot seat. I showed her how to hold it , put her hand in position and asked her to play on the highest string frets 1-2-3-4 each with corresponding finger. I demonstrated. She did her best, but it wasn´t very good. The next came and she did a just a little bit better. Meanwhile the hall was absolutely silent. Everyone was concentrating and watching. The next one did better, the one after that even better than the one before. After about the 7th young woman, Mballing shouted out, “please! let me do do it again! I know I can do it!” I gave her another chance because she was brave enough to be the first and she did it great. In fact out of the 14 women who auditioned that day, there was really only one who I thought would not have an easy time understanding. Malang announced, "OK, tomorrow we will announce  who has been chosen." 

How could I choose one? Half of them had a real potential, the other half could surely learn as well. I needed more guitars! The whole rest of the day, I asked everyone who I saw where I might find guitars in the Gambia. Finally, someone told me that they once saw a guitar in a supermarket in Brusuby. I went to the supermarket and sure enough, there it was, hanging high on a hook. It was covered in dust, with missing, rusted strings and  generally in bad shape. I doubted that it would stay in tune at all. But I needed guitars, so I made the clerk an offer of half the asked price. I said, “this is a very poor quality instrument. It is not worth the price.” He said I´d have to talk to the boss. The bossman came over and said, "we have more guitars do you wish to see them?" Yes! He brought out 10 more of the gnarliest, lowest quality plywood guitars I had ever seen.  Some were made in China, some in India. All just a small step above toys. I spent the next several hours stringing up and tuning, trying out each of the guitars. 4 of them were unacceptable. The other 6 I bought with a bulk discount. The price of each instrument costing €25. Including the instrument I brought, we now had 7 plus mine, eight total.

I put the 14 women into 2 groups and the next day, our workshop began in earnest. We accepted the challenge from Malang to put together a song to perform for the winter festival which was to be held 5 days later. What was suggested to be a daily 2 hour session (1 each for each group) stretched out to many hours everyday. When the first group had the session, the 2nd stayed and watched. When it was the 2nd´s turn, the First group also stayed and watched. They were really only one group of 14, not two of 7. The women went to their other classes and immediately returned to the guitars. They couldn´t get enough. Once they mastered one technique, they ran to me wanting the next. Meanwhile, the low quality instruments were steadily falling apart and I was constantly tuning, hammering frets back into the necks and repairing them best as I could to keep them functioning. 

Since we only had 8 guitars, only 8 could play the guitars, the others would sing and/or dance for the performance. This pushed them even more as I was assigning the guitars one by one to the women who could best play the song. The women chose to perform the song, “The African Tears”, a song about African migrants losing their lives trying to get to a better life in Europe. They rehearsed until the last moment before their performance. The show was amazing. They absolutely rocked! I will never forget it.

In the Gambia there is a rich traditional music culture with beautiful instruments like Kora, balafon, Ngoni, riti, etc... Women from the Griot families participate primarily as backing singers. There is also a thriving pop music scene where women are singers or dancers but don´t play instruments. Only men play guitar, bass, drumset, horns and other instruments.   As a woman whose life, living, and leisure revolves around playing and teaching guitar, it is only natural that I would want to share that gift with my African sisters who never before had the chance. Women and girls love to to play guitars! I know I do.

 

I promised the girls I would come back one day to teach them more. 

Now, after 2 years of preparation, I am ready to launch my new project.

It´s called, “The Groovy African Ladies Music School”.

I will return to Fandema and help build up a lasting music program there.

The vision is to establish the first and only music school for girls and women and ultimately the first professional all women band and events/entertainment production company in the Gambia. 

The program is entrepreneurial by design and will teach participating women from the ground up to learn about the many aspects of an independent music/entertainment industry. The Groovy African Ladies (GALs) Music School will be the most grassroots rock school ever known.

The women at Fandema are already doing it for themselves in many ways with an enormous benefit to the community at large.  Many of the young women participating had never previously been to school at all. All the programs at Fandema are designed with the goal of alleviating poverty in the community. In the local Mandinka language, Fandema means “help yourself”.

 On top of basic language, computer and business skills studies, crews of women are building and installing solar electric systems, creating beautiful arts and quality products that are market ready. They have programs in sewing/fashion/textiles, printing and silk screening, midwifery, environmental sustainability, hotel, restaurant and eco-tourism management.

Music and the entertainment industry will be the next career path option that will be offered to participating young women.

But how to pay for it?  Unfortunately, these women and girls (and boys) in Gambia have no financial support whatsoever. The participants attend the programs at Fandema free of charge as long as they complete the program. Only if they leave in the middle are they required to repay for the resources that they had utilised before quitting. As for a music program, the center now possesses a few very low quality instruments which will not last. Half of the guitars I bought at the supermarket did not survive for long after my workshop was completed.

I went home to Germany inspired to find a donor organisation to fund the project. The reality soon hit me. I am a  busy working musician and music teacher. I don´t know anything about fundraising. I found all the protocols and language required in attaining project grants completely daunting. I do not have nonprofit status. Considering my education and experience, I am uniquely qualified to facilitate this project, but I am one single person with a vision.

 I decided to do what I am able to do. I wrote a bunch of songs and recorded a new CD. Now I am waging  a crowd funding campaign to offer my music as a perk with the hope to  to raise enough money to fund the first year of the first all woman rock school in West Africa!

The plan is to finance music education with music. My brand new solo recording is called, “Far and Wide”. It is a collection of travel and love songs. I am pre-releasing the album exclusively in the campaign.  Everything will go to fund GALs.  If all 2000 of the first run of the physical CDs are claimed, that alone could fund the first year of operating costs, including instruments, materials and transportation. I am personally investing my time, my expertise and all my heart in the first year to get it rolling. I am confident that the results we will achieve after the first year will attract support to fund subsequent years until the project is self-sustaining. I am offering other prizes as well; live appearances, wearables, downloads and other music swag.



I am asking for help! Please support this project by buying my CD and swag, booking a live appearance, and donating as much as you can. Even if you can´t donate,  please pass the campaign link to your friends and networks who might be interested to support grassroots music education and the groovy african ladies music school.


Here is how I will use the money when I reach my goal:


1. Music materials/ Instruments-                                                     €1945 

          including 6 acoustic guitars, 2 electric, 2 bass

2. Room/board for 5 months                                                             €4500

        600€ x5 months =€3000+1,500 (food €10 per diem)

3. Transportation, personal and for materials                             €2500

4. Stipend for apprentice                                                                     €1000

5. Stipend for guest programs/field trips                                      €1000

6. Office/communications/telephone/Computer                     €2000


If we are successful in funding our initial year, any donations received beyond our first goal of US $14,500  (€12,957) will be rolled over to finance equipment needed for the 2nd year´s curriculum, housing, promotional costs and other expenses.

If we are unsuccessful in raising our stated goal of US $14,500 (€12,945), The project will proceed anyway, just on a more bare bones budget with less materials.  


                              

Hallo, ich heiße Miriama, bin Musikerin und Musiklehrerin. Seit über 20 Jahren führe ich Kinder und Erwachsene mit meinem eigenen Rockschulprogramm, das ich sogar schon, bevor Jack Blacks großartiger Film "School of Rock" herauskam, angewendet habe, durch ihre musikalische Ausbildung. 

Das Programm habe ich im Laufe der Jahre entwickelt, für die vielen Schüler mit ganz unterschiedlichem Background, die in den USA und in Deutschland zu mir kamen. Die Teilnehmer konnten sich frei entfalten, weil sie die Chance erhielten, ihre eigenen, ganz persönlichen Versionen des Rock'n'Roll-Traumes zu entdecken. Viele meiner früheren Schüler sind heute Berufsmusiker und wahre Künstler. Ich danke ihnen dafür, dass sie in der ersten Entwicklungsphase meines Programms die Rolle der Testpiloten übernommen haben. 


Ende 2013 reiste ich nach Gambia, Westafrika, um dort in Tujereng als Freiwillige im Fandema Women Development Center zu arbeiten. 

Hier ist die Geschichte:

Ich hatte zwei Gitarren dabei - mein persönliches Instrument für Auftritte und eine weitere. Meine ursprüngliche Idee war, dass e i n e motivierte junge Frau das Glück haben sollte, für die Dauer meines vierwöchigen Aufenthaltes täglich privaten Unterricht von mir zu bekommen. Am Ende wollte ich ihr dann die Gitarre überlassen, damit sie alleine weitermachen könnte. Ich kam in das Center, um dem Direktor, Malang Sambou, meine Idee zu unterbreiten. Er schlug vor, die Frauen direkt zu fragen, wer von ihnen vielleicht Interesse habe, Gitarre spielen zu lernen. Noch am selben Tag, als alle Mitglieder des Centers sich versammelt hatten, stellte Malang mich vor. Ich spielte eines von Bob Marleys Liedern, “No Woman No Cry”. Bei "Everythings gonna be alright" sangen alle mit. Nach einer Zugabe (sie wollten das gleiche Lied nochmals hören!) fragte Malang die Gruppe auf Mandinka: "Wer würde gerne Gitarre spielen lernen?" Fast alle Hände flogen hoch. Er fuhr fort: “OK, aber wer es wirklich lernen will, muss sehr hart arbeiten, jeden Tag lernen und üben. Wer will es jetzt immer noch machen?” Das reduzierte die Gruppe auf etwa die Hälfte. Er kündigte an: “Jede, die es immer noch will, wird jetzt auf ihre Eignung geprüft, und die Beste wird ausgewählt." 

Wir begannen sofort mit dem Vorspielen. Ich sagte: "Wer ist die erste?" Nur eine mutige Hand ging nach oben. Bedenken Sie, diese Mädchen hatten noch nie eine echte Gitarre gesehen, erst recht keine gehalten oder gar gespielt. Erstaunlicherweise waren alle ziemlich geübt im Luftgitarrespielen, was ein gutes Zeichen ist. 

Mballing Bojang setzte sich auf den heißen Stuhl. Ich zeigte ihr, wie die Gitarre gehalten wird, legte ihre Hand in Position und bat sie, auf den obersten Bünden 1-2-3-4 jeden mit dem entsprechenden Finger zu spielen. Ich machte es vor. Sie gab ihr Bestes, aber es war nicht besonders gut. Die nächste kam und machte es ein bisschen besser. Inzwischen war es in der Halle absolut still. Alle waren konzentriert und sahen zu. Die nach ihr kam, machte es wieder etwas besser, und die darauf folgende sogar noch ein bisschen besser. Als schon etwa die Hälfte der jungen Frauen vorgespielt hatte, rief Mballing, “Bitte! Lassen Sie mich es nochmals versuchen! Ich weiß, dass ich es kann!” Da sie so mutig gewesen war, sich als erste prüfen zu lassen, gab ich ihr natürlich noch eine Chance, und sie machte es toll. Tatsächlich gab es unter den vierzehn Frauen, die an diesem Tag vorgespielt hatten, nur eine einzige, von der ich dachte, sie würde Schwierigkeiten haben, es zu lernen. Malang kündigte an: "OK, morgen werden wir bekannt geben, wer ausgewählt wurde." 

Aber wie sollte ich eine auswählen? Die Hälfte von ihnen zeigte echtes Potenzial, und auch die andere Hälfte könnte bestimmt Gitarre spielen lernen. Ich brauchte mehr Gitarren! Den restlichen Tag über fragte ich jeden, den ich sah, wo ich in Gambia Gitarren finden könnte. Schließlich erzählte mir jemand, dass sie einmal in einem Supermarkt in Brusuby eine Gitarre gesehen hätten. Ich ging zum Supermarkt, und siehe da, dort hing eine hoch oben an einem Haken. Sie war mit Staub bedeckt, Saiten fehlten, andere waren rostig, ihr gesamter Zustand war schlecht. Ich bezweifelte, dass sie überhaupt gestimmt bleiben würde. Aber ich brauchte Gitarren, also machte ich dem Verkäufer ein Angebot - die Hälfte des geforderten Preises. Ich sagte: “Das ist ein Instrument von sehr geringer Qualität. Es ist das Geld nicht wert.” Er sagte, ich müsse mit dem Chef sprechen. Der Chef kam und sagte: "Wir haben noch mehr Gitarren. Wollen Sie sie sehen?" Ja! Er brachte zehn weitere; das waren die gröbsten und schlechtesten Sperrholzgitarren, die ich je gesehen hatte. Einige waren in China, andere in Indien hergestellt worden und alle kaum besser als Spielzeug. Ich verbrachte die folgenden Stunden damit, die Gitarren zu besaiten und zu stimmen und probierte jede davon aus. Vier von ihnen waren unbrauchbar. Die übrigen sechs kaufte ich mit Mengenrabatt. Jedes Instrument kostete 25 Euro. Einschließlich der von mir mitgebrachten hatten wir nun sieben Gitarren plus meine eigene, insgesamt also acht. 

Ich teilte die vierzehn Frauen in zwei Gruppen auf, und am nächsten Tag begann tatsächlich unser Workshop. Wir nahmen Malangs Herausforderung an, einen Song einzuüben und auf dem Winterfest aufzuführen, das fünf Tage später stattfinden sollte. Was als zweistündige Session pro Tag vorgeschlagen worden war (je eine Stunde für jede Gruppe), erstreckte sich nun über viele Stunden jeden Tag. Wenn die erste Gruppe ihren Unterricht hatte, blieb die zweite und sah zu. Wenn die zweite an der Reihe war, blieb auch die erste Gruppe und sah zu. In Wirklichkeit war es nur eine Gruppe mit vierzehn, nicht zwei mit sieben Teilnehmerinnen. Die Frauen gingen zu ihren anderen Unterrichtsstunden und kehrten dann sofort zu ihren Gitarren zurück. Sie konnten nicht genug bekommen. Sobald sie eine Technik beherrschten, kamen sie zu mir gelaufen und wollten die nächste gezeigt bekommen. Mittlerweile fielen die minderwertigen Instrumente schon auseinander, und ich musste sie ständig stimmen, Bünde zurück in Hälse hämmern und sie reparieren so gut ich konnte, um sie funktionsfähig zu halten. Da wir nur acht Gitarren hatten, konnten nur acht auf Gitarren spielen, die anderen würden in der Aufführung singen und/oder tanzen. Das spornte sie noch mehr an, denn ich wies die Gitarren eine nach der anderen den Frauen zu, die den Song am besten spielen konnten. Die Frauen hatten sich entschieden, den Song “The African Tears” zu spielen, ein Song über afrikanische Migranten, die ihr Leben verlieren auf der Suche nach einem besseren Leben in Europa. Sie übten ihn bis zum letzten Moment vor ihrem Auftritt, und die Show war einfach herrlich. Sie waren absolut toll! Das werde ich nie vergessen. 



In Gambia existiert eine reiche traditionelle Musikkultur mit wunderschönen Instrumenten wie Kora, Balafon, Ngoni, Riti usw. Frauen aus den Griot-Familien sind in erster Linie als Backgroundsängerinnen dabei. Es gibt auch eine blühende Popmusik-Szene, wo Frauen als Sängerinnen oder Tänzerinnen auftreten, aber keine Instrumente spielen. Nur die Männer spielen Gitarre, Bass, Schlagzeug, Blasinstrumente und andere Instrumente. Als eine Frau, deren Leben, Unterhalt und Freizeit sich um Gitarrenspiel und Gitarrenunterricht drehen, ist es nur natürlich, dass ich dieses Geschenk gerne mit meinen afrikanischen Schwestern teilen möchte, die nie zuvor eine solche Gelegenheit hatten. Frauen und Mädchen lieben es, Gitarre zu spielen! Ich weiß das, denn ich tue es. 

Ich versprach den Mädchen, dass ich eines Tages wiederkommen würde, um sie weiter zu unterrichten. Jetzt, nach zwei Jahren Vorbereitung, bin ich bereit, mein neues Projekt zu starten. Es heißt: “The Groovy African Ladies Music School”. Ich werde wieder zum Fandema Center reisen und helfen, dort ein dauerhaftes Musikprogramm aufzubauen.

Meine Vision ist, in Gambia die erste und einzige Musikschule für Mädchen und Frauen zu etablieren, aus der letztendlich auch die erste professionelle Frauenband und von Frauen geführte Veranstaltungs- und Musikproduktionsfirma hervorgehen sollen. Das Programm ist vom Aufbau her unternehmerisch ausgerichtet und wird den teilnehmenden Frauen von Grund auf die vielen Aspekte einer unabhängigen Musik- und Entertainmentindustrie vermitteln. The Groovy African Ladies (GALs) Music School wird eine Rockschule mit so breit gefächertem Angebot sein, wie es bisher noch keine gegeben hat. 

Die Frauen bei Fandema arbeiten schon in vielen Bereichen mit enormem Nutzen für ihr gesamtes gesellschaftliches Umfeld. Viele der teilnehmenden jungen Frauen hatten nie zuvor irgendeine Schule besucht. Alle Programme von Fandema sind darauf ausgerichtet, die Armut in der Gesellschaft zu mindern. Fandema bedeutet in der lokalen Mandinka- Sprache “Hilf dir selbst”.

Zusätzlich zum Unterricht, in dem Grundwissen in Sprachen, Computeranwendung und Betriebswirtschaft vermittelt wird, bauen und installieren Frauenteams Solarstromsysteme und schaffen schöne Kunstobjekte und Qualitätsprodukte, die vermarktet werden können. Es gibt Kurse für Nähen, Modedesign, Textilkunde, Druck- und Siebdruckverfahren, Geburtshilfe, ökologische Nachhaltigkeit, Hotel- und Restaurant- sowie Ökotourismus- Management. Der Weg zu einer beruflichen Laufbahn in der Musikbranche und in der Unterhaltungsindustrie wird den jungen Frauen als nächstes angeboten werden.

Aber wie soll das finanziert werden? Leider erhalten diese Frauen und Mädchen in Gambia keinerlei finanzielle Unterstützung. Die Teilnahme an den Programmen von Fandema ist kostenlos, wenn die Teilnehmerinnen ihre Kurse abschließen. Nur, wenn sie die Kurse vorzeitig verlassen, müssen sie für die Materialien zahlen, die sie bis dahin verbraucht haben. Was das Musikprogramm betrifft, so verfügt das Center jetzt über ein paar sehr minderwertige Instrumente, die nicht lange halten werden. Die Hälfte der Gitarren, die ich im Supermarkt gekauft hatte, hat das Ende meines Workshops nicht lange überlebt. 

Ich kehrte nach Deutschland zurück in der Überzeugung, eine Spender-Organisation zu finden, die das Projekt finanzieren würde. Die Realität holte mich bald ein. Ich bin eine vielbeschäftigte Musikerin und Musiklehrerin. Davon, wie man Geld sammelt, habe ich keine Ahnung. Angesichts all der Formalien, die erfüllt sein müssen, um Projektzuschüsse zu erhalten, und der dafür erforderlichen sprachlichen Voraussetzungen fühlte ich mich vollkommen entmutigt. Ich besitze keinen gemeinnützigen Status. Hinsichtlich meiner Ausbildung und Erfahrung bin ich ganz besonders qualifiziert, dieses Projekt zu unterstützen, aber ich bin nur eine einzelne Person mit einer Vision.

Ich beschloss zu tun, was mir möglich ist. Ich schrieb ein paar Songs und nahm eine neue CD auf. Jetzt führe ich eine Crowdfunding-Kampagne, in der ich meine Musik als Gegenleistung für Spenden anbiete, und hoffe, dass ich damit genug Geld sammeln kann, um das erste Jahr der ersten Rockschule für Frauen in Westafrika zu finanzieren! 


Die Idee ist, Musikunterricht mit Musik zu finanzieren. Meine brandneue Soloaufnahme heißt “Far and Wide”. Sie enthält eine Sammlung von Reise- und Liebesliedern. Dieses Album veröffentliche ich vorab exklusiv im Rahmen dieser Kampagne. Alle Einnahmen daraus werden in die Finanzierung der GALs fließen. Würden alle 2000 CDs der ersten Auflage abgerufen werden, könnte allein das die Betriebskosten des ersten Jahres tragen, einschließlich Instrumente, Materialien und Transport. Ich investiere meine Musik, meine Zeit, mein Know-how und mein ganzes Herz in das erste Jahr, um das Projekt auf den Weg zu bringen. Und ich bin zuversichtlich, dass die Ergebnisse, die wir nach einem Jahr erzielt haben werden, genug Unterstützung nach sich ziehen werden, um die folgenden Jahre zu finanzieren. Außer meiner CD biete ich auch noch anderes an: Live-Auftritte, T-Shirts, Downloads und weitere Musikartikel. 



Ich bitte um Ihre Mithilfe! Bitte unterstützen Sie dieses Projekt, indem Sie meine CD und andere Artikel erwerben, einen Live-Auftritt buchen und spenden, so viel Sie können. Und auch wenn Sie nicht spenden können, bitte teilen Sie den Kampagne-Link mit Ihren Freunden und in Netzwerken, die Interesse haben könnten, eine musikalische Grundausbildung und "The Groovy African Ladies Music School" zu unterstützen. 


Verwendung der Mittel, wenn das Ziel in Höhe von € 12.945 erreicht wird: 

1. Unterrichtsmaterial / Instrumente und Zubehör                         € 1.945
   - darunter 6 akustische Gitarren, 2 E-Gitarren, 2 Bässe 

2. Zimmer / Verpflegung für 5 Monate                                                 € 4.500 

Miete € 600 x 5 Monate = € 3.000 - 

Verpflegung € 10 x 150 Tage = € 1.500 

3. Transport- und Reisekosten                                                                 € 2.500

4. Gehalt für einen Lehrling                                                                        € 1.000 

5. Vergütung für Gästeprogramme / Exkursionen                            € 1.000

 6. Büro / Kommunikation / Telefon / Computer                              € 2.000                       

                                                                                  Gesamtbetrag              € 12.945  


Wenn wir bei der Finanzierung unseres ersten Jahres erfolgreich sind, werden alle Spenden, die über unser erstes Ziel von € 12.945 (US $14.500) hinausgehen, in die Finanzierung der für das zweite Schuljahr erforderlichen Ausstattung, Unterkunft, Werbekosten und sonstigen Aufwendungen fließen. 

Sollten wir das gesetzte Ziel von € 12.945 (US $14.500) nicht erreichen, wird das Projekt auf jeden Fall weitergeführt, allerdings mit gekürztem Budget und weniger Materialien.
story_txt:
(Für Deutsch nach unten scrollen)Hello Friends wherever you are. My name is Miriama. I am a musician and a music teacher. For over 20 years I have facilitated music education for kids and adults through my rock school program. I was doing this even before the great Jack Black film " School of Rock" came out.  The program has been developed over the years for many students from varied backgrounds in USA and Germany.   Participants blossomed in their young lives getting the chance  to discover their own personal versions of the rock and roll dream. Many of my earlier students are now professional musicians and true artists. I thank them for being the experimental pilots in the early development of the program.

 In late 2013, I traveled to Gambia, West Africa to volunteer at Fandema Women development Center in Tujering. Here is the story:I had 2 guitars with me. My personal instrument for performances and one extra. My original idea was to find one lucky and motivated young woman, give her daily private lessons for the duration of my four week stay, and at the end, give her the guitar so that she could continue on her own. I arrived to the centre to offer my idea to The Center´s director, Malang Sambou. He suggested that we ask the women directly who among them might have interest to learn guitar. Later the same day  at the general meeting with everyone gathered together, Malang introduced me. I played one of Bob Marley´s songs, “No Woman No Cry”. Everyone sang along in the "Everythings gonna be alright" part. After an encore, (They wanted the same song again!), Malang asked the group in Mandinka, "who would like to learn to play guitar?" Almost all hands flew up. He continued: “OK, but whoever really wants to do it has to work very hard learning and practicing everyday, now who still wants to do it?” That narrowed the group to about half. He announced, “everyone who still wants to do it will now be tested on ability.  The best one will be chosen.” 
We immediately began the audition process. I said, "who´s first?", only one brave hand went up. Remember, these girls had never seen a real guitar, much less held and played one. Amazingly, all were quite proficient in air guitar, which is a good sign.  

Mballing Bojang made her way to the hot seat. I showed her how to hold it , put her hand in position and asked her to play on the highest string frets 1-2-3-4 each with corresponding finger. I demonstrated. She did her best, but it wasn´t very good. The next came and she did a just a little bit better. Meanwhile the hall was absolutely silent. Everyone was concentrating and watching. The next one did better, the one after that even better than the one before. After about the 7th young woman, Mballing shouted out, “please! let me do do it again! I know I can do it!” I gave her another chance because she was brave enough to be the first and she did it great. In fact out of the 14 women who auditioned that day, there was really only one who I thought would not have an easy time understanding. Malang announced, "OK, tomorrow we will announce  who has been chosen." 

How could I choose one? Half of them had a real potential, the other half could surely learn as well. I needed more guitars! The whole rest of the day, I asked everyone who I saw where I might find guitars in the Gambia. Finally, someone told me that they once saw a guitar in a supermarket in Brusuby. I went to the supermarket and sure enough, there it was, hanging high on a hook. It was covered in dust, with missing, rusted strings and  generally in bad shape. I doubted that it would stay in tune at all. But I needed guitars, so I made the clerk an offer of half the asked price. I said, “this is a very poor quality instrument. It is not worth the price.” He said I´d have to talk to the boss. The bossman came over and said, "we have more guitars do you wish to see them?" Yes! He brought out 10 more of the gnarliest, lowest quality plywood guitars I had ever seen.  Some were made in China, some in India. All just a small step above toys. I spent the next several hours stringing up and tuning, trying out each of the guitars. 4 of them were unacceptable. The other 6 I bought with a bulk discount. The price of each instrument costing €25. Including the instrument I brought, we now had 7 plus mine, eight total.I put the 14 women into 2 groups and the next day, our workshop began in earnest. We accepted the challenge from Malang to put together a song to perform for the winter festival which was to be held 5 days later. What was suggested to be a daily 2 hour session (1 each for each group) stretched out to many hours everyday. When the first group had the session, the 2nd stayed and watched. When it was the 2nd´s turn, the First group also stayed and watched. They were really only one group of 14, not two of 7. The women went to their other classes and immediately returned to the guitars. They couldn´t get enough. Once they mastered one technique, they ran to me wanting the next. Meanwhile, the low quality instruments were steadily falling apart and I was constantly tuning, hammering frets back into the necks and repairing them best as I could to keep them functioning. 
Since we only had 8 guitars, only 8 could play the guitars, the others would sing and/or dance for the performance. This pushed them even more as I was assigning the guitars one by one to the women who could best play the song. The women chose to perform the song, “The African Tears”, a song about African migrants losing their lives trying to get to a better life in Europe. They rehearsed until the last moment before their performance. The show was amazing. They absolutely rocked! I will never forget it.


In the Gambia there is a rich traditional music culture with beautiful instruments like Kora, balafon, Ngoni, riti, etc... Women from the Griot families participate primarily as backing singers. There is also a thriving pop music scene where women are singers or dancers but don´t play instruments. Only men play guitar, bass, drumset, horns and other instruments.   As a woman whose life, living, and leisure revolves around playing and teaching guitar, it is only natural that I would want to share that gift with my African sisters who never before had the chance. Women and girls love to to play guitars! I know I do. 

I promised the girls I would come back one day to teach them more. Now, after 2 years of preparation, I am ready to launch my new project.
It´s called, “The Groovy African Ladies Music School”.
I will return to Fandema and help build up a lasting music program there.

The vision is to establish the first and only music school for girls and women and ultimately the first professional all women band and events/entertainment production company in the Gambia. 



The program is entrepreneurial by design and will teach participating women from the ground up to learn about the many aspects of an independent music/entertainment industry. The Groovy African Ladies (GALs) Music School will be the most grassroots rock school ever known.



The women at Fandema are already doing it for themselves in many ways with an enormous benefit to the community at large.  Many of the young women participating had never previously been to school at all. All the programs at Fandema are designed with the goal of alleviating poverty in the community. In the local Mandinka language, Fandema means “help yourself”.

 On top of basic language, computer and business skills studies, crews of women are building and installing solar electric systems, creating beautiful arts and quality products that are market ready. They have programs in sewing/fashion/textiles, printing and silk screening, midwifery, environmental sustainability, hotel, restaurant and eco-tourism management.
Music and the entertainment industry will be the next career path option that will be offered to participating young women.


But how to pay for it?  Unfortunately, these women and girls (and boys) in Gambia have no financial support whatsoever. The participants attend the programs at Fandema free of charge as long as they complete the program. Only if they leave in the middle are they required to repay for the resources that they had utilised before quitting. As for a music program, the center now possesses a few very low quality instruments which will not last. Half of the guitars I bought at the supermarket did not survive for long after my workshop was completed.


I went home to Germany inspired to find a donor organisation to fund the project. The reality soon hit me. I am a  busy working musician and music teacher. I don´t know anything about fundraising. I found all the protocols and language required in attaining project grants completely daunting. I do not have nonprofit status. Considering my education and experience, I am uniquely qualified to facilitate this project, but I am one single person with a vision.

 I decided to do what I am able to do. I wrote a bunch of songs and recorded a new CD. Now I am waging  a crowd funding campaign to offer my music as a perk with the hope to  to raise enough money to fund the first year of the first all woman rock school in West Africa!The plan is to finance music education with music. My brand new solo recording is called, “Far and Wide”. It is a collection of travel and love songs. I am pre-releasing the album exclusively in the campaign.  Everything will go to fund GALs.  If all 2000 of the first run of the physical CDs are claimed, that alone could fund the first year of operating costs, including instruments, materials and transportation. I am personally investing my time, my expertise and all my heart in the first year to get it rolling. I am confident that the results we will achieve after the first year will attract support to fund subsequent years until the project is self-sustaining. I am offering other prizes as well; live appearances, wearables, downloads and other music swag.

I am asking for help! Please support this project by buying my CD and swag, booking a live appearance, and donating as much as you can. Even if you can´t donate,  please pass the campaign link to your friends and networks who might be interested to support grassroots music education and the groovy african ladies music school.Here is how I will use the money when I reach my goal:
1. Music materials/ Instruments-                                                     €1945           including 6 acoustic guitars, 2 electric, 2 bass2. Room/board for 5 months                                                             €4500        600€ x5 months =€3000+1,500 (food €10 per diem)3. Transportation, personal and for materials                             €25004. Stipend for apprentice                                                                     €10005. Stipend for guest programs/field trips                                      €10006. Office/communications/telephone/Computer                     €2000If we are successful in funding our initial year, any donations received beyond our first goal of US $14,500  (€12,957) will be rolled over to finance equipment needed for the 2nd year´s curriculum, housing, promotional costs and other expenses.If we are unsuccessful in raising our stated goal of US $14,500 (€12,945), The project will proceed anyway, just on a more bare bones budget with less materials.                                







Hallo, ich heiße Miriama, bin Musikerin und Musiklehrerin. Seit über 20 Jahren führe ich
Kinder und Erwachsene mit meinem eigenen Rockschulprogramm, das ich sogar schon,
bevor Jack Blacks großartiger Film "School of Rock" herauskam, angewendet habe, durch
ihre musikalische Ausbildung. 









Das Programm habe ich im Laufe der Jahre entwickelt, für die
vielen Schüler mit ganz unterschiedlichem Background, die in den USA und in Deutschland
zu mir kamen. Die Teilnehmer konnten sich frei entfalten, weil sie die Chance erhielten, ihre
eigenen, ganz persönlichen Versionen des Rock'n'Roll-Traumes zu entdecken. Viele meiner
früheren Schüler sind heute Berufsmusiker und wahre Künstler. Ich danke ihnen dafür, dass
sie in der ersten Entwicklungsphase meines Programms die Rolle der Testpiloten
übernommen haben. 






Ende 2013 reiste ich nach Gambia, Westafrika, um dort in Tujereng als Freiwillige im Fandema Women Development Center zu arbeiten. 
Hier ist die Geschichte:










Ich hatte zwei Gitarren dabei - mein persönliches Instrument für Auftritte und eine weitere.
Meine ursprüngliche Idee war, dass e i n e motivierte junge Frau das Glück haben sollte, für
die Dauer meines vierwöchigen Aufenthaltes täglich privaten Unterricht von mir zu
bekommen. Am Ende wollte ich ihr dann die Gitarre überlassen, damit sie alleine
weitermachen könnte. Ich kam in das Center, um dem Direktor, Malang Sambou, meine Idee
zu unterbreiten. Er schlug vor, die Frauen direkt zu fragen, wer von ihnen vielleicht Interesse
habe, Gitarre spielen zu lernen. Noch am selben Tag, als alle Mitglieder des Centers sich
versammelt hatten, stellte Malang mich vor. Ich spielte eines von Bob Marleys Liedern, “No
Woman No Cry”. Bei "Everythings gonna be alright" sangen alle mit. Nach einer Zugabe (sie
wollten das gleiche Lied nochmals hören!) fragte Malang die Gruppe auf Mandinka: "Wer
würde gerne Gitarre spielen lernen?" Fast alle Hände flogen hoch. Er fuhr fort: “OK, aber wer
es wirklich lernen will, muss sehr hart arbeiten, jeden Tag lernen und üben. Wer will es jetzt
immer noch machen?” Das reduzierte die Gruppe auf etwa die Hälfte. Er kündigte an: “Jede,
die es immer noch will, wird jetzt auf ihre Eignung geprüft, und die Beste wird ausgewählt." 



Wir begannen sofort mit dem Vorspielen. Ich sagte: "Wer ist die erste?" Nur eine mutige Hand ging nach oben. Bedenken Sie, diese Mädchen hatten noch nie eine echte Gitarre gesehen, erst recht keine gehalten oder gar gespielt. Erstaunlicherweise waren alle ziemlich geübt im Luftgitarrespielen, was ein gutes Zeichen ist. 
Mballing Bojang setzte sich auf den heißen Stuhl. Ich zeigte ihr, wie die Gitarre gehalten wird, legte ihre Hand in Position und bat sie, auf den obersten Bünden 1-2-3-4 jeden mit dem entsprechenden Finger zu spielen. Ich machte es vor. Sie gab ihr Bestes, aber es war nicht besonders gut. Die nächste kam und machte es ein bisschen besser. Inzwischen war es in der Halle absolut still. Alle waren konzentriert und sahen zu. Die nach ihr kam, machte es wieder etwas besser, und die darauf folgende sogar noch ein bisschen besser. Als schon etwa die Hälfte der jungen Frauen vorgespielt hatte, rief Mballing, “Bitte! Lassen Sie mich es nochmals versuchen! Ich weiß, dass ich es kann!” Da sie so mutig gewesen war, sich als erste prüfen zu lassen, gab ich ihr natürlich noch eine Chance, und sie machte es toll. Tatsächlich gab es unter den vierzehn Frauen, die an diesem Tag vorgespielt hatten, nur eine einzige, von der ich dachte, sie würde Schwierigkeiten haben, es zu lernen. Malang kündigte an: "OK, morgen werden wir bekannt geben, wer ausgewählt wurde." 
Aber wie sollte ich eine auswählen? Die Hälfte von ihnen zeigte echtes Potenzial, und auch die andere Hälfte könnte bestimmt Gitarre spielen lernen. Ich brauchte mehr Gitarren! Den restlichen Tag über fragte ich jeden, den ich sah, wo ich in Gambia Gitarren finden könnte. Schließlich erzählte mir jemand, dass sie einmal in einem Supermarkt in Brusuby eine Gitarre gesehen hätten. Ich ging zum Supermarkt, und siehe da, dort hing eine hoch oben an einem Haken. Sie war mit Staub bedeckt, Saiten fehlten, andere waren rostig, ihr gesamter Zustand war schlecht. Ich bezweifelte, dass sie überhaupt gestimmt bleiben würde. Aber ich brauchte Gitarren, also machte ich dem Verkäufer ein Angebot - die Hälfte des geforderten Preises. Ich sagte: “Das ist ein Instrument von sehr geringer Qualität. Es ist das Geld nicht wert.” Er sagte, ich müsse mit dem Chef sprechen. Der Chef kam und sagte: "Wir haben noch mehr Gitarren. Wollen Sie sie sehen?" Ja! Er brachte zehn weitere; das waren die gröbsten und schlechtesten Sperrholzgitarren, die ich je gesehen hatte. Einige waren in China, andere in Indien hergestellt worden und alle kaum besser als Spielzeug. Ich verbrachte die folgenden Stunden damit, die Gitarren zu besaiten und zu stimmen und probierte jede davon aus. Vier von ihnen waren unbrauchbar. Die übrigen sechs kaufte ich mit Mengenrabatt. Jedes Instrument kostete 25 Euro. Einschließlich der von mir mitgebrachten hatten wir nun sieben Gitarren plus meine eigene, insgesamt also acht. 






Ich teilte die vierzehn Frauen in zwei Gruppen auf, und am nächsten Tag begann tatsächlich
unser Workshop. Wir nahmen Malangs Herausforderung an, einen Song einzuüben und auf
dem Winterfest aufzuführen, das fünf Tage später stattfinden sollte. Was als zweistündige
Session pro Tag vorgeschlagen worden war (je eine Stunde für jede Gruppe), erstreckte sich
nun über viele Stunden jeden Tag. Wenn die erste Gruppe ihren Unterricht hatte, blieb die
zweite und sah zu. Wenn die zweite an der Reihe war, blieb auch die erste Gruppe und sah
zu. In Wirklichkeit war es nur eine Gruppe mit vierzehn, nicht zwei mit sieben
Teilnehmerinnen. Die Frauen gingen zu ihren anderen Unterrichtsstunden und kehrten dann
sofort zu ihren Gitarren zurück. Sie konnten nicht genug bekommen. Sobald sie eine Technik
beherrschten, kamen sie zu mir gelaufen und wollten die nächste gezeigt bekommen.
Mittlerweile fielen die minderwertigen Instrumente schon auseinander, und ich musste sie
ständig stimmen, Bünde zurück in Hälse hämmern und sie reparieren so gut ich konnte, um
sie funktionsfähig zu halten. Da wir nur acht Gitarren hatten, konnten nur acht auf Gitarren
spielen, die anderen würden in der Aufführung singen und/oder tanzen. Das spornte sie noch
mehr an, denn ich wies die Gitarren eine nach der anderen den Frauen zu, die den Song am
besten spielen konnten. Die Frauen hatten sich entschieden, den Song “The African Tears”
zu spielen, ein Song über afrikanische Migranten, die ihr Leben verlieren auf der Suche nach einem besseren Leben in Europa. Sie übten ihn bis zum letzten Moment vor ihrem Auftritt, und die Show war
einfach herrlich. Sie waren absolut toll! Das werde ich nie vergessen. 













In Gambia existiert eine reiche traditionelle Musikkultur mit wunderschönen Instrumenten wie
Kora, Balafon, Ngoni, Riti usw. Frauen aus den Griot-Familien sind in erster Linie als
Backgroundsängerinnen dabei. Es gibt auch eine blühende Popmusik-Szene, wo Frauen als
Sängerinnen oder Tänzerinnen auftreten, aber keine Instrumente spielen. Nur die Männer
spielen Gitarre, Bass, Schlagzeug, Blasinstrumente und andere Instrumente. Als eine Frau,
deren Leben, Unterhalt und Freizeit sich um Gitarrenspiel und Gitarrenunterricht drehen, ist
es nur natürlich, dass ich dieses Geschenk gerne mit meinen afrikanischen Schwestern
teilen möchte, die nie zuvor eine solche Gelegenheit hatten. Frauen und Mädchen lieben es,
Gitarre zu spielen! Ich weiß das, denn ich tue es. 








Ich versprach den Mädchen, dass ich eines Tages wiederkommen würde, um sie weiter zu
unterrichten. Jetzt, nach zwei Jahren Vorbereitung, bin ich bereit, mein neues Projekt zu
starten. Es heißt: “The Groovy African Ladies Music School”. Ich werde wieder zum
Fandema Center reisen und helfen, dort ein dauerhaftes Musikprogramm aufzubauen.

Meine Vision ist, in Gambia die erste und einzige Musikschule für Mädchen und Frauen zu
etablieren, aus der letztendlich auch die erste professionelle Frauenband und von Frauen
geführte Veranstaltungs- und Musikproduktionsfirma hervorgehen sollen. Das Programm ist
vom Aufbau her unternehmerisch ausgerichtet und wird den teilnehmenden Frauen von
Grund auf die vielen Aspekte einer unabhängigen Musik- und Entertainmentindustrie vermitteln. The Groovy African Ladies (GALs) Music School wird eine Rockschule mit so
breit gefächertem Angebot sein, wie es bisher noch keine gegeben hat. 













Die Frauen bei Fandema arbeiten schon in vielen Bereichen mit enormem Nutzen für ihr
gesamtes gesellschaftliches Umfeld. Viele der teilnehmenden jungen Frauen hatten nie
zuvor irgendeine Schule besucht. Alle Programme von Fandema sind darauf ausgerichtet,
die Armut in der Gesellschaft zu mindern. Fandema bedeutet in der lokalen Mandinka-
Sprache “Hilf dir selbst”.

Zusätzlich zum Unterricht, in dem Grundwissen in Sprachen, Computeranwendung und
Betriebswirtschaft vermittelt wird, bauen und installieren Frauenteams Solarstromsysteme
und schaffen schöne Kunstobjekte und Qualitätsprodukte, die vermarktet werden können. Es
gibt Kurse für Nähen, Modedesign, Textilkunde, Druck- und Siebdruckverfahren,
Geburtshilfe, ökologische Nachhaltigkeit, Hotel- und Restaurant- sowie Ökotourismus-
Management. Der Weg zu einer beruflichen Laufbahn in der Musikbranche und in der
Unterhaltungsindustrie wird den jungen Frauen als nächstes angeboten werden.

Aber wie soll das finanziert werden? Leider erhalten diese Frauen und Mädchen in Gambia
keinerlei finanzielle Unterstützung. Die Teilnahme an den Programmen von Fandema ist
kostenlos, wenn die Teilnehmerinnen ihre Kurse abschließen. Nur, wenn sie die Kurse
vorzeitig verlassen, müssen sie für die Materialien zahlen, die sie bis dahin verbraucht
haben. Was das Musikprogramm betrifft, so verfügt das Center jetzt über ein paar sehr
minderwertige Instrumente, die nicht lange halten werden. Die Hälfte der Gitarren, die ich im
Supermarkt gekauft hatte, hat das Ende meines Workshops nicht lange überlebt. 









Ich kehrte nach Deutschland zurück in der Überzeugung, eine Spender-Organisation zu
finden, die das Projekt finanzieren würde. Die Realität holte mich bald ein. Ich bin eine
vielbeschäftigte Musikerin und Musiklehrerin. Davon, wie man Geld sammelt, habe ich keine
Ahnung. Angesichts all der Formalien, die erfüllt sein müssen, um Projektzuschüsse zu
erhalten, und der dafür erforderlichen sprachlichen Voraussetzungen fühlte ich mich
vollkommen entmutigt. Ich besitze keinen gemeinnützigen Status. Hinsichtlich meiner
Ausbildung und Erfahrung bin ich ganz besonders qualifiziert, dieses Projekt zu unterstützen,
aber ich bin nur eine einzelne Person mit einer Vision.

Ich beschloss zu tun, was mir möglich ist. Ich schrieb ein paar Songs und nahm eine neue
CD auf. Jetzt führe ich eine Crowdfunding-Kampagne, in der ich meine Musik als
Gegenleistung für Spenden anbiete, und hoffe, dass ich damit genug Geld sammeln kann,
um das erste Jahr der ersten Rockschule für Frauen in Westafrika zu finanzieren! 












Die Idee ist, Musikunterricht mit Musik zu finanzieren. Meine brandneue Soloaufnahme heißt
“Far and Wide”. Sie enthält eine Sammlung von Reise- und Liebesliedern. Dieses Album
veröffentliche ich vorab exklusiv im Rahmen dieser Kampagne. Alle Einnahmen daraus
werden in die Finanzierung der GALs fließen. Würden alle 2000 CDs der ersten Auflage
abgerufen werden, könnte allein das die Betriebskosten des ersten Jahres tragen,
einschließlich Instrumente, Materialien und Transport. Ich investiere meine Musik, meine
Zeit, mein Know-how und mein ganzes Herz in das erste Jahr, um das Projekt auf den Weg
zu bringen. Und ich bin zuversichtlich, dass die Ergebnisse, die wir nach einem Jahr erzielt
haben werden, genug Unterstützung nach sich ziehen werden, um die folgenden Jahre zu
finanzieren. Außer meiner CD biete ich auch noch anderes an: Live-Auftritte, T-Shirts,
Downloads und weitere Musikartikel. 












Ich bitte um Ihre Mithilfe! Bitte unterstützen Sie dieses Projekt, indem Sie meine CD und
andere Artikel erwerben, einen Live-Auftritt buchen und spenden, so viel Sie können. Und
auch wenn Sie nicht spenden können, bitte teilen Sie den Kampagne-Link mit Ihren
Freunden und in Netzwerken, die Interesse haben könnten, eine musikalische
Grundausbildung und "The Groovy African Ladies Music School" zu unterstützen. 







Verwendung der Mittel, wenn das Ziel in Höhe von € 12.945 erreicht wird: 
1. Unterrichtsmaterial / Instrumente und Zubehör                         € 1.945   - darunter 6 akustische Gitarren, 2 E-Gitarren, 2 Bässe 
2. Zimmer / Verpflegung für 5 Monate                                                 € 4.500 
Miete € 600 x 5 Monate = € 3.000 - 
Verpflegung € 10 x 150 Tage = € 1.500 
3. Transport- und Reisekosten                                                                 € 2.500
4. Gehalt für einen Lehrling                                                                        € 1.000 
5. Vergütung für Gästeprogramme / Exkursionen                            € 1.000
 6. Büro / Kommunikation / Telefon / Computer                              € 2.000                       
                                                                                  Gesamtbetrag              € 12.945  



Wenn wir bei der Finanzierung unseres ersten Jahres erfolgreich sind, werden alle Spenden, die über unser erstes Ziel von € 12.945 (US $14.500) hinausgehen, in die Finanzierung der für das zweite Schuljahr erforderlichen Ausstattung, Unterkunft, Werbekosten und sonstigen Aufwendungen fließen. 
Sollten wir das gesetzte Ziel von € 12.945 (US $14.500) nicht erreichen, wird das Projekt auf jeden Fall weitergeführt, allerdings mit gekürztem Budget und weniger Materialien.

story:
About the Project

Its Traveller's Tales ... only the modern day sort, with four wheels, an engine and lots of magical explorations ... 

"There was a time, not that long ago at all, when it was said that the birds showed the human folk the ways of the world...
It was at this time, not very long ago, that an old, old lady was to be found sitting upon a rock, clothed as she was in a dress woven from memories. 
This lady, this Old, Old lady was taking a pause for a moment from her work.
She breathed in and the sun came up. She breathed out and the sky became dark and filled with stars...
And the work of this Lady, this Old, old lady, well she was walking all around the world. She was walking all around the world collecting Magpies..." 

Extract from 'A Necklace of Magpies', from The Little Green Van Tales series.

_____________________________

Hello, My name is Oren.

I am a Yorkshire girl, born and bred, and have been writing since I could first hold a pen. I am a single mum and have lived a very wonderful and interesting life 'on the road' with my children these past few years. We spend a lot of time in the bosom of nature and meeting many fine people, fairies and elves. I am a doula and earth activist and am passionate about communities that support and empower parents, children and our earth, the art of spoken word and the gifts of love, wisdom and stories with which we can nurture the children of today

The Little Green Van Tales consists of 6 children's short stories, each set in a different location in the British Isles. The reader gets to know the family as they travel around and share their findings, of magical stories and knowledge about native birds, tree planting, alternative energy, historical and geographical culture, crystals and much more...

Book Titles and Locations

"The Dragon and the Woodland" - A reforestation story from Edinburgh

"A Necklace of Magpies" - Told from a Green Lane in York

"The Sheep of Chimney Bank" - Chimney Bank in the North Yorkshire Moors

"The Fox and the Sea" - From a beach on Anglesey, North Wales

"The Magic Alley" -  A time tour in Shakepeare's Stratford-upon-Avon

"The Floating Island" - A magical journey on Glastonbury Tor


I believe that the art of spoken word storytelling is an invaluable gift for Children and I have tried to create this effect through the way in which the stories are written.

Each book is different in literary style and they are all beautifully illustrated by different artists, whilst at the same time keeping the thread of the familiar characters.

As I was travelling with my own two small offspring around Britain and Europe, we not only created The Little Green Van Tales but we also met the 7 artists, who all got happily involved in the project. Each artist I met was sitting by themselves, sketch book in hand, drawing away in their own worlds. They were all like me, doing what they love, non-professionally (i.e.not for money). It has been truly wonderful watching this project grow between us and we are all as excited as each other.

 Now all that we need to gift these Tales out into the world is a big Bag of Gold to get the first batch of books printed and delivered to book stores and happy shops!

This is where you come in!!
Everyone donating here will not only be gifting me, they will also be supporting 7 lovely artists, a lovely publisher, a great designer and hopefully many children and parents around the world.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is a breakdown of what the money will enable;

* £350  - Corporate Partnership with Trees for Life. 
http://treesforlife.org.uk/

I believe that we live in a world of cycles and circles, and the best thing is when they are completed. As the books will taking paper from trees, I want to ensure that the books are planting trees too. A corporate partnership with this Scottish reforestation project enables us to fund the planting of a grove of trees, publicise their logo on our books and have a page on their website. I will also be donating 5% of all book profits to Trees for Life, which means that on average, every 20 books sold means 1 tree is planted.

* £2,100 - 600 books printed (that makes 100 prints of the full series)

When you look at it like this, it isn't that many books at all. But we need to start somewhere, getting a couple of copies of the books in shops around Britain and Independent Sales are the first step. The more that comes in, the more we can get out there! (NB - Printing and Sales costs / prices may be subjective to change upon completion of the project)

* £250 - Promotional material
Posters and Book-cover Postcards to introduce the series to both shopkeepers and customers in cafes, shops and public spaces.

* £300 - Fuel and Materials for Oren to do the book launch tour.
I am going to visit country and town cafes and bookshops to run children's workshops based on some of the book themes and to introduce the stories to people. I want to do this in each of the six story locations, so my range is from Edinburgh to Anglesey, Glastonbury to the Yorkshire Moors, and a couple of spots in between.

The Impact

I believe these stories will bring the magic of storytelling to families all over, whilst also inspiring connection to the beautiful lands of Britain and drawing attention to some areas where we can affect positive change, no matter how young or old.

With your support, 8 budding artists will be launched professionally into their careers and many children will be able to benefit from the magic of this very special travelling family and their stories.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest work is in marketing the books and getting them out there on the shelves. I would rather be skipping barefoot in a stream any day rather than sitting in front of a computer researching and contacting book sellers and outlets, in attempt to get our project out there. I am wholly inspired though by the other 7 with which I am working, as is often the case, it can be easier to do something for others rather than yourself!

And hopefully ... these stories will inspire others to take their children out barefoot skipping in streams, and then my work is truly done ...

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute money on this occasion, you can still help !
Please tell other people about The Little Green Van Tales and this fundraising campaign ... the more the merrier : )

(Indiegogo does also have Share Buttons...)

Thank You so much for your time, you focus and your support,

With Lots of Love,

Oren and the LGV Team xx*

story:
iSchool STEM BEST Robotics need you!!!
Help and Junior/Senior Earn Prom Day OFF!!

We have 10 days left to raise money for the BEST (Boosting Engineering Science and Technology)  and as part of our final push we are giving the Junior/Seniors the opportunity to be in a drawing for Prom Day off.  For each $50 donated in their name they will be entered.

The BEST (Boosting Engineering, Science, and Technology) program is designed to teach teamwork, problem solving, project management, and pride in task completion within the constraints of a short time period and limited physical resources. The goal is to demonstrate the excitement of advanced technical careers to young people who are nearing decisions on college plans. The technology contest is designed to simulate a real-world business and engineering environment including:

  • Specifications (weight, size, functionality)
  • Time to Market (time to market - 6 weeks)
  • Limited Resources (use only the kit of parts provided)

Part of the points that can be gained is from fundraising dollars through creative marketing.    Please send this to anyone you know who can help support our kids.  Last year we won 4th place BEST.  We are aiming for 1St place this year and we need your help.

 We are at 50% of our goal. The Fab Lab will be designed around the emerging possibility for students to not just learn about science and engineering, but actually design machines and make measurements that are relevant to improving the quality of their lives and the communities around them.


If you would rather write a check, please make it payable to iSchool High STEM Academy and put BEST in the memo line. All donations are tax deductible.

story:
Hey!

My name is Cam, I'm a middle child, I'm 26 and live in a share house near the city, I have been making music for over 10 years and have run a meditation dance class with a live band for the last year. We help people centre themselves, connect with other, express freely and get into their bodies. I also coach and suport people on the daily...

My thrust for life is in noticing limiting patterns and behaviours and rewiring them into something that serves myself and others. 

Lately I have been helping and supporting people make a difference in their lives by helping them see new perspectives and achieve their potential in areas such as business, communication, creativity, body and mind. I have been seeing so many beautiful shifts and changes in people including myself through doing this work.

One of my idols, a man who inspires me in this kind of work, Tony Robbins, is coming to Sydney. I am feeling a HUGE call to see him for his 4 day event, where he will be helping people discover their potential and making huge transformations with people. He is a renowned man who has helped people like Ghandhi and Oprah Winfrey, he even helped Oprah walk across burning coals, which is what I will be doing on day one of the retreat. If you haven't seen this guy in action, I suggest watching his new documentary "I Am Not Your Guru" on NetFlix.

Once I come back, I will be running a workshop series, called 'Be Your Best Self', on breaking patterns, rewiring our daily thought patterns and actions, getting aware of / tending to our basic human needs, aligning to our values, communication, body mind practices, cultivating integrity. I'll be giving practical weekly homework to help people start implementing changes in  living the lifestyle of their dreams in ways that they've wanted but haven't been aware of how to go about it.

And yeah I'm real shy and nervous about it, but empowering other people is about getting out of your own head, listening to others and fully supporting them into living their ideal reality.

I'm FULLY serious about this work, my heart body and mind are calling me to step up, stop playing small and fully integrate this ideal reality, and learn from the best who are doing this work...
And Tony is the next step of this journey, and I need your help.

I will be offering:
~ Open Sesame Meditation Dance 5 Class Pass Special

~ One Free Consultation and One Half Price 'Ideal Reality' Session

~ 'Ideal Reality' One Month Course (Four 1:1 Sessions) HALF PRICE

~ The 5 week 'BE YOUR BEST SELF' Workshop happening in Oct

~ A 4 week 1:1 music tutoring program - "Learn and Play 1 Song in 1 Month" - learning how to play and perform a song with voice and accompanying instrument, within a month.

~ A special live musical performance at the place of your choice.

~ "Return To The Light - Part One" (A concept album made in India)

~ A 1 Hour Meditation Massage in Coburg

It would mean the world to surround myself and learn the teachings of this powerful man over 4 days, and to share what I've learnt and put it into practice.
This is the line of work I want to do till the day I die and I would be so thankful to recieve all the help I can get for this.

If I don't reach my goal I am still going and will find a way. I have about 3 weeks.

I simply MUST go. I know that with my heart.

I realise some people may not be able to afford this so if you could share the love and let people know I'm out to impact and help people I would be really grateful for that opportunity. :)

story:
Created by professor and performer, Alicia Swiz,  SlutTalk's mission is to empower girls and women to tell their stories in order to challenge and change the stigmas of womanhood. Throughout the journey of creating SlutTalk for the last year in Chicago - 8 performances! 4 public talks! 3 radio episodes! 2 workshops! plus #FeministHappyHour - we have collected so much content and worked with so many rad women and organizations...WE HAVE TO TALK ABOUT IT. Your contribution will help us to launch our podcast! We already have enough content for quite a few episodes we just need some software and minor equipment to keep recording while on the road plus pay someone to help us produce it. 

SlutTalk Diaries is an original workshop that encourages girls and women to explore their experiences with slut culture, slut shaming and body image through guided dialogue, writing and culminates with a stage reading (participation optional). Our funding goal will allow us to provide this workshop free of charge to girls and women in domestic violence shelters, juvenile detention and prisons, and social welfare programs. Donate $500-$1,000 and we'll come to your organization or community to work with a local service provider to girls and women. 

Funding for this campaign will also enable SlutTalk to travel beyond Chicago casting and creating SlutTalk performances with local performers, artists and community members throughout the country. A SlutTalk performance thrives in any setting whether it's a theater, a music venue, a bookstore or coffee shop. We'd love to come create a show for you! Donate $1,000 or more and we'll put your location on the map.

We have an awesome network of women-identified performers across the country ready for us to come to town and a super-rad support squad of women and allies including the filmmakers over at Milk Media Productions who, along with the help of many others, will be documenting our entire journey. We've been lucky enough to work with a handful of local businesses and makers in Chicago whose generous support has helped us create some rad merch (a donation gets you some)! But, of utmost importance, we have a country full of girls and women who have been historically and systemically silenced, shamed and brutally attacked for being sexual. For being female. For being a slut. 

In 2016, we the people, allowed a convicted rapist to serve only 3 months in jail, disrupted the educational pursuits of young women across the country by shaming the way they dress, and elected a self-proclaimed sexual predator as our next President. This tells us that, as a nation, we are more interested in blaming girls and women than we are in trusting their stories, believing in their experiences and valuing their voice.

We will not allow it any longer.

We are reclaiming ourselves. We are redefining ourselves. We are SlutTalk.

story:
Im Steph, the author of Laila and Habib: Adventures in Jordan. I am originally from the UK but now call Petra, Jordan home. 

Since arriving in Jordan I have dreamed to create a community project and play my part in a community that has accepted and supported from day 1. Alongside writing Laila and Habib, I run A Piece of Jordan, a community initiative engaging visitors with everyday life beyond the typical tourist trail (you can see more about A Piece of Jordan here www.apieceofjordan.com). 

My plans for the women and children's centre began after we moved back to Jordan from the UK with our son Karam. There is no doubt that the natural elements of Petra provide amazing adventures for children but I wanted to also add a new dimension and option for families here. I also want to create a cafe for women as there is currently nothing of the sort in Petra.

When I began to think of ways to fund the centre I fell in love with the idea of creating imformative but fun stories for young travelers and indeed for children all over the world. I see these books as another way to show the real Jordan to the world, celebrate its history, culture and engage young families when the travel here. I also plan to create a English language program here in Petra using Laila and Habib. 

I look forward to sharing your jouney with us!

What We Need & What You Get

I am planning to write stories on various cities, sites and parts of Jordanian life - we currently have Petra complete with illustrations and Amman and Dana written. In order to get our illustrations put into the correct graphic design format and the physical book designed we have been qouted 70GBP per page. Which means each book is likely to cost 1000GBP for the design process. Once this is complete printing costs will be in the realm of 2GBP per book.

We would love for you to help us get the ball rolling - we have recieved written support from the Ministry of Culture, who have offered to publish the book!

If we don't reach our target for this campaign the money will be set aside so that we can keep fundraising until we reach our target and get the first book design complete and ready for print

The Impact

Jordan is a very misunderstood part of the world, through Laila and Habib's stories I feel we can continue to combat and fight the stereotypes of the region through storytelling!

Enjoy reading...Laila and Habib: Glen the Tortoise Visits Petra

by Stephanie Altwassi

Glen the Brummie tortoise was desperate for a holiday,
He asked James and Sarah, but they kept saying ‘Glen not today’!
So Glen decided to go alone and he knew just the place,
He packed his bags and off he went, excitement all over his face!

In Glen’s secret tortoise lair his plane was good to go;
Petra, Jordan was his destination there’s no way he was going slow!
Jabel Haroun also Aaron’s tomb Glen found a spot to land,
His friends waiting so eagerly with a tortoise made of sand.

With excited smiles Laila and Habib were ready on horseback;
Galloping down the steep mountain, Glen loved his very first hack.
As they toed into Wadi Musa, the town his friends call home,
People greeted them ‘Salam’ – Glen knew he’d never be alone.

In Petra food was plentiful, Glen wasn’t sure what to do,
Dates, pomegranate, apricot and figs – just some foods that were new!
His stomach full and much to see, Glen found a place to rest,
In the home of Laila and Habib, his Jordanian friends were the best!

As the sun rose Habib woke up, it was such a beautiful morning,
He could hear his good friend Glen the tortoise, asleep and loudly snoring.
He headed out to feed their horses, whilst Laila prepared their breakfast
Fresh bread, falafel, hummus and foul, Laila’s food was known as the best.

They headed down to the City of Petra, it was time for Glen to explore
A city that’s seen more than 2,000 years, the Nabateans created it all.
Petra once a city buzzing with trade, linking Jordan to the rest of globe
Silk and spices came from near and from far, with a man, his camel and a thobe

When Glen arrived at the famous Siq, he could hardly contain his smile,
He wished James and Sarah could see it all with him, he got his phone out to dial.
“James! Sarah!, you have to see Petra; Its more beautiful than you’ll ever know,
In the Summer it’s hot, Spring, Autumn is cool, in winter you’ll even find snow!

Laila and Habib took Glen to Little Petra, as the night drew nearer
To watch the sunset behind the sandstone mountains, the stars now so much clearer
Reminiscing on their day in Petra, around the warm, crackling fire,
For Glen it was time to return to his plane, Petra, Jordan has much to desire.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I know its not always possible to contribute financially, but there is still lots you can do!

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • If you know any talented Graphic designers that you feel may be able to help us send them our way!
  • If you have a shop/library/childrens centre/playgroup and would like to preoder a copy of the book email me at info@apieceofjordan.com 

Thank you for taking the time to read and letting me share my dream with you!
story_txt:
Im Steph, the author of Laila and Habib: Adventures in Jordan. I am originally from the UK but now call Petra, Jordan home. 
Since arriving in Jordan I have dreamed to create a community project and play my part in a community that has accepted and supported from day 1. Alongside writing Laila and Habib, I run A Piece of Jordan, a community initiative engaging visitors with everyday life beyond the typical tourist trail (you can see more about A Piece of Jordan here www.apieceofjordan.com). 
My plans for the women and children's centre began after we moved back to Jordan from the UK with our son Karam. There is no doubt that the natural elements of Petra provide amazing adventures for children but I wanted to also add a new dimension and option for families here. I also want to create a cafe for women as there is currently nothing of the sort in Petra.
When I began to think of ways to fund the centre I fell in love with the idea of creating imformative but fun stories for young travelers and indeed for children all over the world. I see these books as another way to show the real Jordan to the world, celebrate its history, culture and engage young families when the travel here. I also plan to create a English language program here in Petra using Laila and Habib. 
I look forward to sharing your jouney with us!

What We Need & What You Get
I am planning to write stories on various cities, sites and parts of Jordanian life - we currently have Petra complete with illustrations and Amman and Dana written.
