story:
Become a confident beekeeper in 60 days

Learn what bees need to survive and thrive, get a steady supply of free honey, and leave a legacy on our ailing planet.

Please note: Regardless of whether we reach our Indiegogo goal or not, we will be delivering the Course in December 2016 to all our Indiegogo supporters and enrolments.

If you’re a new beekeeper, you’ve just bought your first colony, or you once purchased a hive that’s now gathering dust in a closet somewhere, then you probably already know how important bees are to the future of our planet.The world needs bees. Badly. But it also needs confident passionate beekeepers.

I've partnered up with my teacher, Ben Moore, who coached me through the shaky period of being a new beekeeper. 

We’ve taken everything Ben learned in his 25-year beekeeping career and distilled it down into a 100% do-able program that even a busy exec like me can handle.


(don’t be alarmed by his youthful appearance — Ben bought his first hive at 14 [with his own money!] and has been caring for bees ever since. He is a true, dyed-in-the-wool bee lover. The kind of guy who would keep doing his work, even if he won the lotto and never had to work again)

Ben has 4 kids and I have 2 kids. We both have ‘day jobs’ to pay the bills. But bees need a little help, and education and mentoring beekeepers is a great place to start! Plus, you would be helping us fulfil a lifelong dream if we could be of service to the beekeeping community for a living.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $12,500 to finish 20 of 75 educational videos focusing on beginner beekeeping. After Shooting the Raw video we out source the raw video to an editing team that charges $25 hour and takes 3-5 hours to finish each video. We then pay a graphics designer to create Graphics to make the videos more pleasing.

We also need your help to raise funds to assist in the marketing, advertising and overall launch of the course. We plan on using Google Adwords, Facebook Advertising and YouTube Advertising as Nathan has a strong backgound in Digital Marketing and we can leverage his contacts and expertise.

For contributing we are offering strong discounts of 50-65% off the normal price of the course.

Imagine what the world would be like if…

  1. Instead of just talking about all the bad things that would happen to us if all the honeybees were suddenly extinct, people actually started DOING something about it, planting beautiful flower gardens and cultivating thriving beehives?
     
  2. All of us busy, hard-working people of the world went out to our backyards to hang with the bees, check the hive or harvest honey, instead of flopping on the couch and watching Netflix every evening?
     
  3. Rather than sharing another doomsday article about dying honeybees on Facebook, you opened a new window on your computer and started learning what it would actually take to save them?

That’s what we aim to achieve with Beekeeping Apprentice.

The Course

Beekeeping Apprentice is the first course of its kind that offers…

A Complete, All-In-One-Place Training Program

If you’re new to beekeeping, you’ll find tons of information online that can help you on your beekeeping journey. But a one-stop-shop that actually WALKS you through each decision you need to make along the way, from buying a hive to harvesting honey? Ours is the first and only one currently available.

Cuts Down On All the Noise

Ever been to a beekeeping group? You’re likely to meet a bunch of old-timers, each with their own (probably pretty strong) opinions about the best way to care for bees. With all the conflicting opinions on YouTube, blogs, and in beekeeping societies, it’s hard to make confident decisions. Beekeeping Apprentice solves this problem for you.

Access To A Private Facebook For Real-Time Decision Making

Got a question? Now you don’t have to wait for your monthly beekeepers’ meetup to get the answer. You’ll belong to a supportive online network of new beekeepers that are asking the same questions you are (plus Beekeeper Ben will answer questions on weekly live Q&A sessions).

Here’s how it all breaks down…

MODULE #1

Falling In Love With Bees

  • The lifecycle of a honeybee, and why it’s important to understand it
  • Why the world needs bees, and how even 1 backyard hive can make an impact

MODULE #2

  • Starting Your Beekeeping Adventure
  • Urban beekeeping—do I really need a 40 acre property just for a few hives?
  • Where to place you hive so your bees have good access to food, shelter and water
  • Purchasing bees: where to get them, what to ask, and how to determine a fair price
  • Growing a bee-friendly garden—what to plant and what to pull out
  • Collecting nectar and pollen

MODULE #3

Equipment & Supplies

  • Buying your gear—do you really need that 1/4" crown staple gun and compressor?
  • The 3 tools every beekeeper MUST own
  • The 6 most popular hives, and how to determine which one is right for you

MODULE #4

Inspecting the Hive

  • Why inspections are important, and how often you should be doing them
  • Determining queen status, and inspecting queen cells
  • How to spot signs of disease before it’s too late
  • Taking the temperature of your hive
  • How to identify Queen, Drone and Worker Bees

MODULE #5

Expanding & Splitting Hives

  • Why splitting is important and how to do it
  • Determining when it’s time to split
  • To confine or not to confine the Queen Bee

MODULE #6

Common Problems Most Beekeepers Encounter

  • Every beekeeping apprentice sees at least 1 of these common problems (don’t panic, we’ll tell you how to handle them!)
  • Bee swarming, and how to make sure all your Worker Bees don’t fly away
  • Seasonal impacts on beekeeping (what do bees do in the winter, anyway?)

MODULE #7

Sweet Rewards

  • Honey production & harvesting—how to do it on a budget, how to do it with an extractor, and when to take it super pro
  • Making beeswax candles (and other cool by-products your bees produce)

story:
Foundations of a Living Learning Village

What is the Lucid University?
The Lucid University is immersive transformational education, organized into 5 curriculum tracks:

  • CommunityWorks
  • CreativeWorks
  • BodyWorks
  • EcologyWorks
  • SpiritWorks

We are excited to be putting down roots for the Lucid University on a permanent piece of land that we will co-own together with the lucid community. Trillium, the land, revealed herself to be the perfect place to do so.

DOWNLOAD THE LUCID UNIVERSITY PROJECT OVERVIEW HERE

Our Vision
We envision a world in which lifelong learning is joyfully embraced by all beings as a fun and deeply meaningful journey of discovery. We see a future enriched by individuals inspired by their personal path, activated in their purpose and passions, sharing their skills, exchanging wisdom, and co-creating regenerative solutions for our earthly communities to heal and thrive.

Our Mission
Lucid University is committed to creating immersive educational experiences that offer students tools for empowerment, inspiration, introspection, and integration to promote harmonious and regenerative relationships with all of life. The Lucid University will offer scholarships, grants, work trade opportunities and online education to provide an inclusive approach for our students to learn and grow.  Our community-based educational experiences provide an abundance of opportunity for people of all walks of life to explore and develop skill-sets in a supportive and immersive environment.

Lucid University is dedicated to fostering solutionary thinking to the challenges we face as a people and a planet through a curriculum focusing on Creativity, Spirit, Ecology, the Body, and Community. We lovingly support each other’s growth, across all domains, with our implicit understanding of the unity within our diversity. Honest communication, upholding our agreements, and commitment to consensus are inherent to our process of respecting the individual while recognizing the awesome potential of the whole.

    Who Are We? 
    We are the Lucid University, a collective of dreamers, artists, healers, leaders, and earth guardians, committed to creating immersive educational experiences in a village setting. Incubated from within Lucidity Festival over the last four years, there is a considerable amount of overlap in communities, however the new Lucid University is its own entity.

    Moving forward, Lucidity Festival (as an organization) will be a core member of LU, and LU will continue to produce educational offerings at Lucidity Festival. Lucidity Festival operations will remain in Southern California. 

    Unique Hands-On Learning
    Lucid University creates accessible pathways for inter-generational, multicultural learning and skill building. Our unique approach to learning includes courses and programs tailored to the needs, goals and interests of the student with a supportive community environment and effective tracking systems to ensure success.

    A Focus on Student Experience

    • Interactive Community Experience
    • Makerspace & Business Incubation
    • Self-Directed & Hands-on Learning
    • Certification Opportunities
    • Skills Trainings & Apprenticeships
    • Diverse Curriculum
    • Field Studies 

    The Fun Stuff: Rewards and Perks

    LU Organizational Structure

    The Land: Trillium

    DOWNLOAD THE FRIENDS OF TRILLIUM DECK HERE

    In addition to founding the Lucid University as an educational platform, we are giving it a home on a beautiful piece of land in Southern Oregon. We are engaging as a core member of "Friends of Trillium," a holding company that's been formed to purchase the land collectively. The larger vision of Trillium is an educational center, a community, a retreat sanctuary, and a research and demonstration site for regenerative solutions. As a result of our involvement we are able to offer some amazing perks including a romantic getaway or an educational adventure!

    We are excited about Trillium as a venue because:

    • We'll be co-owners of the land with a handful of amazing partners (see org structure below)
    • As a living-learning village, there is the opportunity for deeper integration of skills and knowlege into every day life 
    • There's an abundance of water in the form of a river, a creek, a well, and a spring
    • Trillium's rich history boasts a 40-year community and a wilderness education center 
    • Favorable zoning and permitting that will allow us to start operations almost immediately
    • Trillium is surrounded on 3 sides by pristine old growth forest and BLM-owned wilderness

    Friends of Trillium (Land-Holding Company) Organizational Structure

     

    ​The Trend is our Friend

    The timing of this project and Lucidity's track record is perfectly positioned to support a great success. Consider these important pieces of context:

    • Lucidity Festival is stepping into the final chapter of its first six year story, the chapter is called Eudaimonia, a Greek word for human flourishing, and is meant to be all about our collective future. All along Lucidity has been envisioning purchasing land for a community, while Lucidity is just one partner among many in this project, grounding the Lucid University at Trillium still feels like the fulfillment of a lucid prophecy. 
    • The Reinhabiting the Village book project, which Lucidity associate produced with Keyframe Entertainment, provides a powerful blueprint to develop the whole-systems-living community that we have been dreaming in.
    • Other leading festivals in the "Transformational" genre are purchasing land to put down roots. Burning Man just purchased the Fly Ranch in Nevada and Boom Festival in Portugal recently launched a campaign to purchase Boomland. 
    • The face of education is changing. As our government funded institutions and corporate student loan behemoths are continuously found to be supporting the creation of an educational system that recreates the status quo, more and more alternative education opportunities are emerging, focusing on passion-based learning and student-driven curriculum. 

    Risks and Challenges

    At present, the largest challenge before us is purchasing the land. We are bringing together partners to make the purchase happen and are getting very close to the asking price. The Friends of Trillium team experienced a fair amount of growth edges since this is the first real estate endeavor for most of us. Other challenges include:

    • CHALLENGE: Establishing good rapport with the local community in the Little Applegate Valley. 
      • SOLUTION: Invite them to events and immersions. Be good neighbors!
    • CHALLENGE: Maintaining the exceptional track record of local environmental activism held by previous Trillium stewards. 
      • SOLUTION: Have LU representatives sit on the board of Birch Creek Arts & Ecology, a 501(c)3 non-profit connected to the bio-region.
    • CHALLENGE: Building a thriving online educational platform.
      • SOLUTION: We are looking for a Web-Tech partner to work with us to create "the Netflix of Transformational Education!" wink wink... are you out there?
    • CHALLENGE: Funding the necessary repairs on the land and paying full time employees. 
      • SOLUTION: You! via this Crowdfunding Campaign... see where the money is being spent below!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • SHARE the project with your friends and family.
    • Ask one new person everyday to become a backer. 
    • Like the Lucid University FB page. 
    • If it's still before September 27th at noon, join our Thunderclap!
      --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
      All courses offered by Lucid University are meant for educational purposes only.  None of the courses or material has been accredited by any national, international, or private accreditation association.  The courses offered by Lucid University DO NOT meet the requirements of any accrediting authority, whether regional or national, of any country.  Lucid University has not applied to any accrediting agency to receive any accreditation that would be recognized by the Department of Education of the United States or any other country.  Lucid University DOES NOT have the ability to offer a degree of any kind.  Lucid University DOES NOT have the ability to offer credits.  The courses offered by Lucid University ARE NOT accepted by other educational institutions.  Lucid University DOES NOT intend to represent itself as offering university degree-granting educational services.​

As a result of our involvement we are able to offer some amazing perks including a romantic getaway or an educational adventure!
We are excited about Trillium as a venue because:

We'll be co-owners of the land with a handful of amazing partners (see org structure below)
As a living-learning village, there is the opportunity for deeper integration of skills and knowlege into every day life 
There's an abundance of water in the form of a river, a creek, a well, and a spring
Trillium's rich history boasts a 40-year community and a wilderness education center 

Favorable zoning and permitting that will allow us to start operations almost immediately
Trillium is surrounded on 3 sides by pristine old growth forest and BLM-owned wilderness

Friends of Trillium (Land-Holding Company) Organizational Structure

 
​The Trend is our Friend
The timing of this project and Lucidity's track record is perfectly positioned to support a great success. Consider these important pieces of context:

Lucidity Festival is stepping into the final chapter of its first six year story, the chapter is called Eudaimonia, a Greek word for human flourishing, and is meant to be all about our collective future. All along Lucidity has been envisioning purchasing land for a community, while Lucidity is just one partner among many in this project, grounding the Lucid University at Trillium still feels like the fulfillment of a lucid prophecy. 
The Reinhabiting the Village book project, which Lucidity associate produced with Keyframe Entertainment, provides a powerful blueprint to develop the whole-systems-living community that we have been dreaming in.
Other leading festivals in the "Transformational" genre are purchasing land to put down roots. Burning Man just purchased the Fly Ranch in Nevada and Boom Festival in Portugal recently launched a campaign to purchase Boomland. 
The face of education is changing. As our government funded institutions and corporate student loan behemoths are continuously found to be supporting the creation of an educational system that recreates the status quo, more and more alternative education opportunities are emerging, focusing on passion-based learning and student-driven curriculum. 


Risks and Challenges
At present, the largest challenge before us is purchasing the land. We are bringing together partners to make the purchase happen and are getting very close to the asking price. The Friends of Trillium team experienced a fair amount of growth edges since this is the first real estate endeavor for most of us. Other challenges include:


CHALLENGE: Establishing good rapport with the local community in the Little Applegate Valley. 
SOLUTION: Invite them to events and immersions. Be good neighbors!


CHALLENGE: Maintaining the exceptional track record of local environmental activism held by previous Trillium stewards. 
SOLUTION: Have LU representatives sit on the board of Birch Creek Arts & Ecology, a 501(c)3 non-profit connected to the bio-region.


CHALLENGE: Building a thriving online educational platform.
SOLUTION: We are looking for a Web-Tech partner to work with us to create "the Netflix of Transformational Education!" wink wink... are you out there?


CHALLENGE: Funding the necessary repairs on the land and paying full time employees. 
SOLUTION: You! via this Crowdfunding Campaign... see where the money is being spent below!




Other Ways You Can Help

SHARE the project with your friends and family.
Ask one new person everyday to become a backer. 
Like the Lucid University FB page. 
If it's still before September 27th at noon, join our Thunderclap!--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------All courses offered by Lucid University are meant for educational purposes only.  None of the courses or material has been accredited by any national, international, or private accreditation association.  The courses offered by Lucid University DO NOT meet the requirements of any accrediting authority, whether regional or national, of any country.  Lucid University has not applied to any accrediting agency to receive any accreditation that would be recognized by the Department of Education of the United States or any other country.  Lucid University DOES NOT have the ability to offer a degree of any kind.  Lucid University DOES NOT have the ability to offer credits.  The courses offered by Lucid University ARE NOT accepted by other educational institutions.  Lucid University DOES NOT intend to represent itself as offering university degree-granting educational services.​

story:
Our Concept/ Về ý tưởng

We're building a unique restaurant that will not only help Vietnam's most disadvantaged youth, but also meet the growing demand of Hanoi-based consumers for Japanese food, and of Vietnam-based Japanese restaurants for highly trained chefs that can create authentic Japanese cuisine.

This is a partnership between an award-winning Vietnamese vocational training NGO, REACH, and restaurant developer Setsugekka, with support from the Tsuji Culinary Institute in Japan and world-renowned 7-Michelin Star Chef Yoshihiro Murata. This venture will be a symbiotic combination of an authentic Japanese cooking training course and training restaurant, the first of its kind in the world. 

In building this restaurant, not only are we meeting the needs of consumers and industry, but we're also providing Vietnam's most disadvantaged youth, including human trafficking victims, ethnic minorities and youth living in poverty, with certified skills training and quality employment opportunities. 

---

Dự án hướng tới xây dựng một nhà hàng độc đáo ở Việt Nam. Nhà hàng đáp ứng nhu cầu thưởng thức món ăn Nhật với chất lượng và hương vị chuẩn mực của ẩm thực Nhật Bản. Các đầu bếp của nhà hàng đều có nhiều năm kinh nghiệm làm việc và đặc biệt có thời gian tu nghiệp tại Nhật Bản. Bên cạnh đó, nhà hàng hỗ trợ đào tạo nghề bếp cho thanh niên có hoàn cảnh khó khăn, bao gồm nạn nhân của buôn bán người, thanh niên nghèo, thanh niên bỏ học sớm, hay thanh niên dân tộc thiểu số đến từ vùng núi với điều kiện sống khó khăn.

Dự án này là sự hợp tác giữa REACH và đơn vị phát triển nhà hàng Setsugekka, với sự hỗ trợ của Bộ Kinh Tế, Thương Mại và Công Nghiệp Nhật Bản (METI), và trường đào tạo ẩm thực Tsuji tại thành phố Osaka. Đầu bếp 7 sao Michelin nổi tiếng thế giới Yoshihiro Murata cũng có những đóng góp cho dự án này.

What We Need/ Chúng tôi cần bạn hỗ trợ

We need at least $40,000 to help with the setup of our project. This money will help fund:

  1. The recruitment and training of our restaurant's head chefs and classroom cooking teachers
  2. The equipment needed for our new industrial kitchen
  3. Tuition and training materials needed for our cooking students and restaurant trainees
  4. Fit out costs for training restaurant, including rent, refurbishment and décor

---

Chúng tôi cần ít nhất $40,000 để có thể thực hiện được dự án này. Số tiền gây được sẽ được dùng để:

    1.  Tuyển dụng và đào tạo cho đội ngũ đầu bếp và giáo viên đứng lớp dạy cho các học viên

    2. Mua các trang thiết bị.

    3. Chi phí đào tạo, nguyên vật liệu thực hành cho các học viên.

    4. Cải tạo, trang trí lại nhà hàng.

The Perks/ Quyền lợi tài trợ

We are offering a diverse range of perks to help you get the most out of your investment in our project. Our perks vary according to the amount and your location (we have tailored specific packages to those investors based within and outside of Vietnam).

Whether you want to hear from one of our students in a hand-written thank you card, have your name on our Restaurant Honour Board or receive an invite to our launch event next year, there is something here for everyone. Every dollar counts and we appreciate every contribution. Even for a minimal amount, you can change the life of a student.

---

Có những gói quyền lợi khác nhau để ghi nhận sự đóng góp của nhà tài trợ cho dự án, bao gồm thư cảm ơn viết tay từ học viên REACH, ghi tên trên bản tường danh dự của nhà hàng, hay vé mời tham dự  lễ khai trương của nhà hàng. 

Chúng tôi trân trọng mọi sự đóng góp, dù là nhỏ nhất. Cùng nhau, chúng ta có thể đem lại sự đổi thay trong cuộc sống của thanh niên có hoàn cảnh khó khăn Việt Nam. 

The Impact/ Tác động của dự án

Despite the growing popularity of Japanese food all around the globe, the number of Japanese cuisine chefs is actually decreasing as less and less young Japanese are entering the profession. REACH sees this market dislocation as a tremendous market opportunity it can capture and leverage to further its mission to help disadvantaged youth in Vietnam.

REACH's award-winning vocational training, life skills and job placement programs target Vietnam's most disadvantaged youth, including human trafficking and domestic violence victims, ethnic minorities, youth with a disability, youth with or affected by HIV/AIDS, rural migrants, and youth living in poverty. With around 1.4 million workers entering Vietnam’s labour market each year, it is these vulnerable groups that are being left behind, unable to grasp opportunities for prosperity.

In line with REACH's current training cycle, we will host three intakes of students in 2017 alone, totalling between 60-80 students. Each student will be provided with technical training, life skills training and work-readiness training in preparation for a traineeship at our restaurant, where they will be mentored and guided by head chefs who have received capacity building support from the Tsuji Culinary Institute in Osaka, Japan.

---

Dự án hướng tới giúp đỡ những thanh niên có hoàn cảnh khó khăn nhất của Việt Nam , bao gồm thanh niên nghèo, thanh niên bỏ học sớm, thanh niên dân tộc thiểu số, nạn nhân của buôn bán người và bạo lực gia đình, thanh niên khuyết tật, hoặc thanh niên sống chung/ bị ảnh hưởng bởi HIV/AIDS. Đây là nhóm đối tượng dễ bị tổn thương, không có khả năng kiếm việc trong thị trường lao động đầy cạnh tranh.

Nhà hàng đào tạo Nhật Bản trong năm 2017 dự kiến sẽ hỗ trợ từ 60-80 thanh niên. Các học viên sẽ được các đầu bếp giàu kinh nghiệm từng đi tu nghiệp tại Nhật Bản trực tiếp hướng dẫn. 

Risks & Challenges

This restaurant shows REACH embarking on a new challenge to expand its social entrepreneurship portfolio by setting up a Japanese cuisine training restaurant in Hanoi. We know this is new territory, which is why we've chosen our partners carefully. Each partner will bring different expertise to the table:

Michelin Star Chef Yoshihiro Murata

Declaring his life’s work as “accurately communicating Japanese cuisine to the world” and “cooking for the public benefit”, 7-Michelin Star Chef Yoshihiro Murata will be providing input on curriculum development, restaurant development, and menu and recipe development. 

Tsuji Culinary Institute

To support the training of disadvantaged Vietnamese youth to become skilled Japanese chefs, Tsuji will provide capacity building, curriculum development and training support, overseen by the head trainer.

Setsugekka

With the support of Japan's Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI), Setsugekka is providing a restaurant development plan, corporate advisory and seed-funding for the project.

REACH

REACH will utilise its NGO network and connection with Vietnam’s most disadvantaged communities (including domestic violence and human trafficking victims, youth with a disability, youth affected by HIV/AIDS, ethnic minorities, rural youth, youth living in poverty, amongst others) to recruit vulnerable and marginalized youth to join this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word about our campaign, whether through WOM or by sharing our campaign page on social media. Every like, share and donation makes a difference!

story:
*scroll down for english

Kako je krenulo?

Inicijativom benda velikog srca - Kriesa i njihovom velikodušnom idejom da odricanjem od zarade na novom albumu podrže mlade kreativce bez doma.  Tu ideju su zdušno podržale udružene snage Are You Syrious?, Inicijativa za podršku izbjeglicama Dobrodošli!, SOLIDARNA – Zaklada za ljudska prava i solidarnost i Koalicija Solidarnosti Split te zajedno pokrenuli  kampanju prikupljanja sredstava, instrumenata, kreativnog mentorstva i svega onog što je potrebno mladim kreativcima bez doma da bi mogli ostvariti svoj puni potencijal i razvoj svih talenata.

Uključi se i ti!

Budimo dobri domaćini! U Hrvatskoj se nalaze ljudi koji su svoj dom morali napustiti ili ga nikada nisu imali. Među njima su mladi kreativci - djeca bez primjerene roditeljske skrbi i izbjeglice koje su u Hrvatsku došle bježeći od rata. Da bi mogli stvarati i biti ono što jesu, potrebni su im instrumenti, kistovi, plesne cipele, prostor za pjevanje i fotoaparat.

Uplati donaciju i dobiti ćeš povratan mail koji će sadržavati tvoj kod za besplatan download novog albuma grupe Kries!

Kome pomažemo?


Kroz ovu kampanju želimo podržati najmanje 12 izbjeglica koje žive u Zagrebu i mladih bez primjerene roditeljske skrbi, štićenika SOS Dječjeg sela Hrvatska. Njima su potrebna sredstva za rad i uključivanje u društveni i kulturni život zajednica u kojima žive. 


„Učim hrvatski i radim na svom engleskom. U slobodno vrijeme ja i suprug pjevamo zajedno...ali najlakše se izražavam fotografijom.“ D., 31.g.


„Želje za budućnost? Prvo želim slobodu, a onda i dobar život. Želim raditi i želim nastaviti studij. Volio bih da mogu ići na umjetnički tečaj.“ S., 27.


„Trenutno sviram na gitari svog prijatelja, ali bih volio jednog dana imati vlastitu gitaru. Želio bih sudjelovati u radionicama sviranja gitare i volio bih pomagati mladima kojima je to potrebno.“  N., 18.g

„Tamo sam vodila galeriju... da mogu, upisala bih akademiju.“ M.


„Dosta sam skromna i stidljiva osoba, ali jednog dana vidim kako će moji radovi biti prezentirani i cijenjeni u javnosti.“  M., 16.g
 

 

 

Koja je cijena doma?

Da bismo osigurali podršku pravog doma, nabaviti ćemo potrebnu opremu (slikarsku, fotografsku i glazbenu) te osigurati prostor za rad i učenje. Za to nam je potrebno 8000 dolara.

Svaki iznos je dobrodošao – Kries i kreativci kažu veliko HVALA

Predloženi minimalni iznos donacije je 10 dolara, a ako možete uplatite i više, i proširite vijest o kampanji, da sakupimo potrebnih 800 donacija.

Hvala svima na podršci i sjetimo se - umjetnost je jezik koji svi razumijemo, a kad putem nje komuniciramo, mi živimo, postojimo - imamo dom!

 

 

.....................................

How to get engaged?


Let's be good hosts! In Croatia there are many who had to leave their homes or never had one in the first place. Among them there are creative young people without parental support, or refugees that came to Croatia escaping from war. In order for them to create and be what they are, they need instruments, paint brushes, dancing shoes, a place to sing, a photocamera.
Give a donation on this link and you will receive an email with a code for a free download of the new album of Croatian band Kries, who started this initiative with the support of several Croatian organisations.


We need 8000 dollars for the needs of creative youth, and the suggestion for a minimum donation is 10 dollars – a small price for a supportive home.

U slobodno vrijeme ja i suprug pjevamo zajedno...ali najlakše se izražavam fotografijom.“ D., 31.g.„Želje za budućnost? Prvo želim slobodu, a onda i dobar život. Želim raditi i želim nastaviti studij. Volio bih da mogu ići na umjetnički tečaj.“ S., 27.„Trenutno sviram na gitari svog prijatelja, ali bih volio jednog dana imati vlastitu gitaru. Želio bih sudjelovati u radionicama sviranja gitare i volio bih pomagati mladima kojima je to potrebno.“  N., 18.g„Tamo sam vodila galeriju... da mogu, upisala bih akademiju.“ M.„Dosta sam skromna i stidljiva osoba, ali jednog dana vidim kako će moji radovi biti prezentirani i cijenjeni u javnosti.“  M., 16.g 

 
 Koja je cijena doma?Da bismo osigurali podršku pravog doma, nabaviti ćemo potrebnu opremu (slikarsku, fotografsku i glazbenu) te osigurati prostor za rad i učenje. Za to nam je potrebno 8000 dolara.Svaki iznos je dobrodošao – Kries i kreativci kažu veliko HVALAPredloženi minimalni iznos donacije je 10 dolara, a ako možete uplatite i više, i proširite vijest o kampanji, da sakupimo potrebnih 800 donacija.Hvala svima na podršci i sjetimo se - umjetnost je jezik koji svi razumijemo, a kad putem nje komuniciramo, mi živimo, postojimo - imamo dom! 

 
.....................................How to get engaged?Let's be good hosts! In Croatia there are many who had to leave their homes or never had one in the first place. Among them there are creative young people without parental support, or refugees that came to Croatia escaping from war. In order for them to create and be what they are, they need instruments, paint brushes, dancing shoes, a place to sing, a photocamera.Give a donation on this link and you will receive an email with a code for a free download of the new album of Croatian band Kries, who started this initiative with the support of several Croatian organisations.We need 8000 dollars for the needs of creative youth, and the suggestion for a minimum donation is 10 dollars – a small price for a supportive home.

story:
Tačiau užtenka abstrakčiai ir pabandykime konkrečiai. Be to, kaip galite pamatyti mūsų video archyve (http://ou-ls.org/video-archive/), kviečiame į šių metų Vasario 16-osios minėjimą.

Ką veiki šią Vasario 16-ąją?

Kartais Nepriklausomybės diena - tai proga vieni kitiems priminti, jog mūsų laisvė yra trapi. Kitais kartais - tai progą prisiminti, kokiomis sunkiomis aplinkybėmis ją pavykdavo iškovoti ir išlaikyti, dar kitais - galimybė pamąstyti apie daug žadančią, o galbūt ir nerimą keliančią ateitį.

Permainingieji 2016-ieji visiems sukėlė skirtingų reakcijų - šoką, nerimą, džiaugsmą, viltį, neviltį. Tad šių metų vasario 18-19 d. norime pakviesti į Oksfordą tai apmąstyti ir... atšvęsti Vasario 16-osios pasiekimus.

Į Oksfordą atvyks ir savo darbus/muziką atsiveš:

  • fotografai ir įvairių socialinių projektų autoriai Neringa Rekašiūtė ir Artūras Morozovas, prieš JAV rinkimus turėję progą pakeliauti po šią įvairialypę šalį ir kalbėtis su daugybe sutiktųjų apie rinkimus, politiką ir tiesiog gyvenimą,
  • muzikantas Andrius Vaicenavičius, "Kūjelių" grupės lyderis,
  • muzikantai (ir sutuoktiniai) Ignas Rubikas ir Akvilė Rubikienė.

Artūras su Neringa pasidalins savo nuotraukomis, pasakojimais ir mintimis socialinės atskirties tema, su siekiu palyginti Lietuvoje (bei visoje Europoje) matomus visuomeninius procesus su nuotaikomis JAV. O Andrius, Ignas ir Akvilė - muziką iš širdies šokiams ir gerai nuotaikai palaikyti.

Daugiau apie dalyvius


Artūras, kaip karo fotografas, iš arti matė Ukrainos konfliktą, yra daug keliavęs po Rusiją ir kitas buvusios Sovietų Sąjungos šalis, bei Lietuvą, fotografuodamas įvairiausių socialinių sluoksnių žmones.

Baigusi fotografijos studijas Londone, Neringa geriausiai žinoma dėl socialinių projektų "Superherojės", “Moterys kalba”, "Mūsų daug" bei kotroversiškojo "Jie laimėjo loteriją". Ji puikiai supranta ir subtiliai jaučia socialines problemas.

Ignas yra manoSeimas.lt įkūrėjas, gerai žinantis Lietuvos politines aktualijas, susirūpinęs provincijos ir miesto atskirtimi, dabar studijuojantis politikos magistrą Londone. Be to, moka groti ir kartu su Akvile kartkartėm koncertuoja "RIVA" vardu.

Akvilė - gerai folkloro ratuose žinoma ir puikiai lietuvių liaudies kultūrą išmananti muzikantė. Užaugusi mažame kaime su folk kultūra, o dabar šokį studijuojanti Londone Akvilė labai gerai pažįsta tiek Lietuvos provincijos, tiek miesto kultūrą.

Andrius, be to, jog yra grupės "Kūjeliai" lyderis, nepailstantis bardas, Oksforde studijuoja matematikos doktorantūrą ir yra šioks toks startuolių scenos žaidėjas. Nevedęs.

Ko prašome ir ką siūlome

Renginys visiškai atviras - visi laukiami! O tam, jog bilietai būtų pigūs ir įkandami taupantiems studentams, šioje kampanijoje renkame lėšas vakaronės maistui bei padengti svečių viešnagės išlaidoms. Iš viso tikimės surinkti 500 svarų, mat likutį turėtume padengti savo pačių lėšomis. Jei kampanija bus sėkminga ir viršys mūsų lūkesčius, likutis keliaus į iždą ateities renginiams.

Ko siekiame

Remdami Vasario 16-osios renginį, taip pat remiate ir Oksfordo universiteto lietuvių bendriją (http://ou-ls.org). Jau 6-is metus skleidžiame lietuvišką kultūrą Oksforde, būdami viena iš pačių pirmųjų studentų bendrijų Junginėje Karalystėje, savo pavyzdžiu įkvėpę burtis ir kolegas kituose JK universitetuose. Turėjome garbės priimti Rytį Zemkauską, Leonidą Donskį (a.a), Edward Lucas, Egidijų Aleksandravičių, Kristiną Sabaliauskaitę ir daug kitų įdomių svečių iš Lietuvos. Sieksime ir toliau organizuoti įdomius ir nuotaikingus renginius!

Kaip dar galite prisidėti

Jei norite prisidėti prie renginio įgyvendinimo, bet negalite paremti finansiškai, o verčiau pagelbėtumėte kitais būdais, kviečiame rašyti rasa.giniunaite@jesus.ox.ac.uk! Kiekvieno žmogaus indėlis nepaprastai svarbus.

story:
Aloha!

We are students from Brigham Young University-Hawaii, and we are in a Social Entrepreneurship class here on campus. We have a small student population at around 3,000 students, and 60% of the population are not native to the USA, coming from over 70 different countries. We were asked to look outward to our communities and to the world to begin our businesses while still here in school. For our project, we reached out to one of our team member’s home country—the Philippines. From personal experience, he was able to identify some needs that would be beneficial to his country. It also worked out that we had connections to an existing non-profit called, IHHELPP or Improving Health, Housing, Education, and Livelihood for the Poor in the Philippines. They are the distributors for the CEB (compacted earth blocks) machines, project planners, and aid for people in the Philippines. They reached out to us for help to fund a project that will change lives for generations. We need your help to purchase and transport a CEB machine that will be used at Christo Rey High School, in Capas, Tarlac Philippines to teach the students how to build the blocks, construct building plans, and then to make a home to last the storms—both within the family and also the natural storms.

The Philippines is made up of over 7,000 islands and has a population of more than 103 million people. The Philippine islands are located along the ‘Pacific ring of Fire,’ which is the area along two tectonic plates. This location causes the whole area to be a hot spot for earthquakes and volcanic activity. Because of the geological activity and the tropical waters, it is an ideal spot for hurricanes and tropical storms to develop.

The Disaster Emergency Committee reported that the Philippines receives an average of 20 storms yearly. The DW News(Deutsche Welle) estimated that a total of 80 tropical storms form yearly over the ocean, and an average of 19 make landfall in the Philippines, with Rappeler putting the average at about 14 tropical storms and six typhoons. The average yearly, though varying slightly, demonstrates the dangers that represent the people of the Philippines.

Tropical storms have been recorded to produce more than ten times the energy than the nuclear strike on Hiroshima, Japan. These storms can cause an average of $20 million to $600 million of damage throughout the path of the storm. In 2013, the Philippines was struck by Hurricane Haiyan. The D.E.C. reported 25 feet-high storm surge in certain towns. Winds were reported at 147 to 171 MPH. Over five million people saw their homes destroyed, with over five hundred thousand severely damaged homes. The Rappeler recorded over 6,000 dead, almost 30,000 injured, and over 1,000 missing. The World Times reported that these damages both in life and monetary worth is due to the fact that “a large number of the country’s 96 million people live in areas with poor infrastructure and flimsy housing.”

The CEB machines, one which we are seeking to send, will not only bring stronger bricks that would allow their homes to withstand higher winds than their currently “flimsy housing” but will also give them a cost-effective and quick way to create their own blocks to rebuild faster after the storms have passed.

http://world.time.com/2013/11/11/the-philippine...

https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/issues/disaster...

http://www.dw.com/en/philippines-a-country-pron...

https://www.dec.org.uk/articles/facts-and-figures

 

 

Rewards Timeline

November 24: End of campaign

November 25: Ordering of rewards

December 15: Send out all rewards

Our backers can get the rewards after we ship it to them within 5-7 business days. Will be longer if international.

 

Cost-Breakdown

65-70%—Goes to the project

20-25%—Operational cost

10%—Goes to IndieGoGo

 

Meet the Team:

 

Kim Russell Comenta

 

I’m from the Philippines, and I’m sophomore student at Brigham Young University-Hawaii majoring in Business Management and Entrepreneurship. I have always had a desire to help my country so that I can fulfill the vision of this school, which is to “enter to learn—go forth to serve.” This project will help hundreds of Filipinos to have sturdy houses, which will protect them from any calamities, so they can fulfill their own dreams, which is what I am pursuing right now.

 

Isaac Nicholes

My name is Isaac Nicholes. I am a Marine Biologist seeking my professional degrees and a devoted husband to an amazing photographer. I am from northern Virginia but have had the opportunity to live around the world. I have lived in Yokohama, Japan; Bangkok, Thailand; Warsaw, Poland; and several provinces of Northern Argentina throughout my life. In my travels, I have seen the differences between developing countries and first world countries. I have seen houses built out of sticks and plastic bags, out of nothing but cement and crumbling cement bricks that were made in bulk with little concern over their quality or substance. I have lived where families live together in a home that would be considered small in the United States, where the floor is made up of swept dirt which becomes muddy during storms. The quality of material and its sell price play a huge role in how struggling individuals build their homes for themselves and their families. As a scientist, I have researched the materials that go into making the Earth blocks, and I am confident that these blocks won’t only be more affordable but will allow those struggling in the Philippines to make their own blocks which will further save in man labor and expenses and lead to stronger and more structurally sound homes. Everybody deserves a home, but they also deserve a home that can protect them from the elements, from harm, a safe haven from the world outside. I support this project for the hope that it brings for those who struggle more than I ever have and the possibilities it brings them, for their own future, and that of their children.

 

Skye Mackintosh

 

My name is Skye Mackintosh. I am from Lehi, Utah but currently study here at BYU-Hawaii. I am majoring in Marketing with a double minor in psychology as well as Visual Arts/Communication. I lived for two years in New York City, and having lived in three different burroughs, I saw many different levels of income and quality of life. Seeing this has given me the desire to find those that are in great need of help with the simple necessities of life. I feel honored to be a part of this project to help these kids and families in the Philippines to have a way to build solid houses and other buildings with the material around them. I know that this will greatly improve their quality of life as I have friends from the Philippines who have had first-hand experience of living like this. I fully support this project and everything that it stands for. I am driven to see it through and have it truly help these people help themselves.

 

Ella Reynolds

 

Pacific Northwest raised and wouldn’t have it any other way! I came to school here in Hawaii in August of 2016. My major is Business Management with an emphasis in Human Relations and a minor in entrepreneurship. I have traveled through over ten countries and have goals to see as much as I can. I have seen poverty and have always wanted to make a difference that would matter. From experience, there is nothing that can fill our happiness greater than being in service of others. I live on a mini farm back home and have grown up with hard work at the forefront of my life. I’m excited to get things going to help those that are in the Philippines.

story:
About the Campaign

Sub-Saharan Africa is slated to double in population to 2.3 billion people by 2050, at which time 40% of the world’s children will be in this region.

Many talented, ambitious young people will be moving from rural areas into cities by way of informal settlements, such as Kibera, where Tunapanda Institute’s main training facility is located. This urbanization poses a problem if learning and working opportunities are not provided at a high enough quality and quantity.

The Tunapanda Team, all of whom are graduates of our free 3-month training programs in the past 4 years, will:

  1. Set up a first-of-it's-kind space training location in Kibera to re-imagine how people can live together in tight situations and encourage kids to think about space travel and Earth-focused problem solving.
  2. Iteratively develop up to 9 new open source micro-courses. Test each with 40-50 kids and young people in Kibera. Each video-driven micro-course will cost the Tunapanda team $4,000-$7,000 to develop and test, which includes some of the costs to keep our team fed and safe while they run our flagship free 3-month training programs.

Tunapanda's model is centered around financial sustainability - our team earns money by building websites, performing HCD-inspired research or usability testing, and training services for individuals and corporate clients. These open source courses can become revenue-generators for us and others around the world.

KASA's Potential Impact

We see an opportunity to unlock imaginations about space travel while also solving problems here on Earth. Some current space exploration programs plan to send millions of people to Mars within several decades, and the key constraint to space travel will not only be the rocket science: but rather, it will be how we can use scarce resources (including physical space) to keep people alive and happy. There are clear parallels to the crowded informal settlements of cities around Africa, and we can thus create impact here on Earth while preparing for exciting space adventures.

Tunapanda Institute has been developing and testing openly-licensed “micro-courses” that can be used for free or paid training by anyone through short bootcamps. For example, we recently ran a robotics bootcamp using a micro-course we created earlier this year (see video below).

Tunapanda Institute wishes to create an initial 9 micro-courses and test them with young people through our partners here in Kibera, before releasing them for free to the world so that others can also get involved in re-imagining the future of humanity, here on Earth as well as in outer space.

 

KASA’s Key Areas of Training Will Include:

 

Previous Micro-Course: Robotics

This video was made by Pulse Media in Kenya:

 

What we will teach

The curricula we will develop will combine the future with current needs to ensure that learners are at learning skills that can help them to generate income and become changemakers for their generation. Broken down into 9 broad categories, the learning will be based on important and emerging issues in today's world. By keeping in mind how technologies can be used in space exploration, as well as how they are relevant locally, our students can dream big while also having an impact. See the FAQ to learn how you can support a topic that you care about.

1. Robotics and human-computer interaction

As more and more tasks become automated and machines take a more active role in our daily lives, an essential component of building the future will be designing these machines and thinking about our interaction with them. Learning how to design and operate robots through computer programming is a growing field, and we have already run robotics courses for kids in Kibera to great enthusiasm. We want to continue developing these skills to ensure that the robots and machines that we use in the future align with our values and are used to make the world better for future generations.

2. Energy sources of the future

Creating efficient and sustainable energy systems will continue to be important to the future of the earth, as the population of humans will keep on rising. Better energy systems will allow every community, even in marginalized areas, to have access to clean energy. The systems that we shall develop will be useful on earth, space, and other planets. To enable this to happen, the learners will have to understand, design, create and repair this energy generation, distribution and storage systems.

3. Governance and decision making

The future of work and education are rapidly changing, making teamwork and communication more important than ever. We will all need to take part in different teams and work in different workplace cultures to become successful leaders and teammates. The best way to become adaptable is to learn the background of governance and decision-making and how new models, such as Holacracy, Teal, and cryptocurrency protocols work. Learners will partake in practical workshops to learn how to work with teams of various sizes and board games that will help us to learn strategies, tactics, and flexibility to changing situations. Pure centralization creates corrupt and slow companies and dictatorship governments. Pure decentralization creates slow decision-making and weak companies and countries. With modern technology and an emphasis on education, we can invent new ways to organize and make decisions.

4. The future of food

The way we currently feed our planet is not sustainable - if we can innovate where and how we grow food, as well as thinking critically about nutrition and what we eat, we can do better at feeding our species, both on this planet and the next. Learners will learn about new techniques and strategies for growing sustainable food sources in various locations (such as dense urban areas) and in varying climates. They will also learn the basics of nutrition so that they can feed themselves, their families, and their communities in a healthier way.

5. Communications and Satellites

In Africa communication has evolved from traditional methods such as drums and smoke to modern technology such as mobile phones and computers. IoT (Internet of Things) is one of the biggest frontiers that is improving our lives. Devices and systems that were previously unable to communicate are now connecting and making real-word decisions. Satellites enable faster and more data collection, and understanding the progress and future of communication technologies is very important. Learners will get skills to solve challenges such as access to clean water, medical monitoring, smart housing, and many others.  Tunapanda has already started building a community network, TunapandaNET, promoting digital inclusion through affordable access to connectivity and started local youth in Kibera on the path of becoming network and software engineers.

 

6. Buildings of the future

Physical spaces have a large influence on the way that people interact within them. In areas of dense and sparse populations, thinking critically about how we design our environments can have a huge impact.  As we design the future, we will need to design interior and exterior spaces to be functional, safe, and beautiful. We will engage with adults and kids to learn how to build spaces that allow them to tap into their full potential and inspire growth, creativity, and imagination.  Support this project to bring the future closer to hearts through our spaces and buildings.

7. Rockets and the history of space exploration

In the 20th century, scientists and visionaries sent humans and our technology off to explore the cosmos. We collaborated not only to explore but also to discover our world and what lies beyond. Understanding the science behind rockets through experimentation and prototyping for kids is not only beneficial for school but can also be used to understand how to tackle real-world problems.  We will focus on using creative imagination, peer-to-peer learning, and working in teams to shape our path to space. “It’s not rocket science, it’s just fun”

8. STEM

The challenges we are facing today are more complex and sophisticated, and current schooling systems often not prepare kids to solve all of them effectively. The future of education should be about practical skill acquisition, not just exams and rote memorization. Learners of all ages will be introduced to Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) courses. The learning will be heavily project-based and focused on problem-solving to that students learn the real world applications of the material they are memorizing at school. Kids learning STEM can start applying math and science concepts through prototyping new ideas, which will enable them to develop solutions on how to take and sustain mankind on other planets, while simultaneously improving this one.

9. Staring Into Space

For thousands of years, people have watched the sky to try and find their place in this world.

This has given us insights into where we come from and where we can go. Getting an understanding of the vastness of outer space helps to put things into perspective about how we can spend our time here on Earth. Giving kids in Kibera the opportunity to use telescopes and other tools to learn about space first hand will create an amazing opportunity for inspiration and creativity. In overnight excursions or camps, they can broaden their horizons, experience a connection with nature, and learn mindfulness and other skills that will assist them to achieve their dreams. We will give kids the opportunity to stare into space, which will allow them to dream big and find their place in this world, and the future we build together.

 

About Tunapanda Institute

Tunapanda Institute has been spreading knowledge across East Africa for six years. Its first project was an ‘education on a hard drive’ in 2012. Co-founders/brothers Jay and Mick Larson set up several computer laboratories in Kenya, Uganda & Tanzania and installed hundreds of gigabytes of free video courses and software in areas where internet costs are prohibitively high for online learning.

In 2014, they set up a school in Africa’s largest slum, Kibera. In 2016, graduates of Tunapanda's Kibera facility helped to set up another learning center in Kenya’s northern region of Turkana. So far, we have trained over 300 students in technology, design, and business skills. Graduates have gone on to use their skills as skilled employees, freelancers, and entrepreneurs.

In 2016, Tunapanda was named as one the 2016 NT100 – Nominet Trust ’s annual celebration of 100 inspiring tech-for-good ventures from around the world.

At Tunapanda, we strive to take our work seriously without taking ourselves too seriously. In 2014, we crowd-funded the launch of our Kibera training facility with a comedy video, "Tunapanda News" inspired by shows like The Daily Show. Now, in 2018, we created "Tunapanda News 2" to assure people that we still take our work seriously, and still don't take ourselves too seriously. We hope you enjoy it:

 

'Tunapanda' is a Swahili word that means 'We are growing', 'We are planting', or 'We are climbing.'

 

Kibera Aeronautics and Space Academy (KASA)

In 2019, Tunapanda is going to keep pushing its vision of accessible and relevant training programs by launching the Kibera Aeronautics and Space Academy. KASA will be located within walking distance from our main training facility and will be a hub for inspiring young people to dream and tackle the problems of the future. With a focus on how we can make humans an interplanetary species, the project-based learning will also allow young people to tackle problems here on Earth. In the coming years, we will have many challenges to face, and KASA wants to inspire young people here in Kibera to come up with solutions.

Tunapanda team members, almost all of whom are beneficiaries of our free 3-month training courses, will create and publish curricula that will allow young people to take the first steps in creating these solutions. These curricula will be open and available for anyone, anywhere to access and get the same learning.  We will build off of our introductory training program to focus on some of the key issues that could have a hand in shaping the future.

Tunapanda Institute is a 501(c)3 tax exempt organiztion (EIN: 46-3425836). All contributions will go to supporting the development of curricula and running training programs in Kibera, Nairobi (Earth)!
story_txt:
About the Campaign
Sub-Saharan Africa is slated to double in population to 2.3 billion people by 2050, at which time 40% of the world’s children will be in this region.
Many talented, ambitious young people will be moving from rural areas into cities by way of informal settlements, such as Kibera, where Tunapanda Institute’s main training facility is located. This urbanization poses a problem if learning and working opportunities are not provided at a high enough quality and quantity.
The Tunapanda Team, all of whom are graduates of our free 3-month training programs in the past 4 years, will:


Set up a first-of-it's-kind space training location in Kibera to re-imagine how people can live together in tight situations and encourage kids to think about space travel and Earth-focused problem solving.

Iteratively develop up to 9 new open source micro-courses. Test each with 40-50 kids and young people in Kibera. Each video-driven micro-course will cost the Tunapanda team $4,000-$7,000 to develop and test, which includes some of the costs to keep our team fed and safe while they run our flagship free 3-month training programs.

Tunapanda's model is centered around financial sustainability - our team earns money by building websites, performing HCD-inspired research or usability testing, and training services for individuals and corporate clients. These open source courses can become revenue-generators for us and others around the world.

KASA's Potential Impact
We see an opportunity to unlock imaginations about space travel while also solving problems here on Earth. story:
We have tested our products at a few colleges in New York City. It proved to be a device busy and inquisitive students love. Contributions to our campaign will allow Pengea to continue to foster a community of students learning about and understanding climate change. Informed people shape our world and informed students will become the stewards of our planet. Informed students will inevitably become the T cells in our global immune system as they come of age.

We named our first model "The Pengea Dream," because it is imperative to fuse the American dream, the Chinese dream, the East’s and West’s modernization dreams, and the universal human dream of advancement together to dream and work towards a future of sustainable development. A common global vision will move the world away from conflicts and toward cooperation. The dream is a far-fetched and deferred one, but it might just spark our generation to rise up and meet the demands of our age. Newfound knowledge and community will bring more peers online for the business of saving the world. Can a highlighter device accomplish any of this? If our eye-catching gadgets become common at university libraries, study lounges, and cafes, mass climate awareness will begin to take root.

With the Indiegogo community’s backing, we will be able to continue production and distribution. We will be able to work with traditional retailers to collect our depleted Pengea highlighters from our users. Our highlighters are designed for simple disassembly and ink replenishment. If we can collect sizable quantities, we can create regional labor work that wouldn’t have existed otherwise. We can prevent our detachable highlighters from ending up in landfills. With a user base and crowd funding, we will be able to continuously improve our engineering, lower costs, reduce waste, incorporate user content, and become the most responsible social enterprise we can be. We hope you become one of our early adopters. From the bottom of our hearts, thank you for your support.

Jason & Richard

Co-inventors & Co-founders of Pengea

story:
Overview

We are Yonder Dynamics, a multidisciplinary student robotics organization from the University of California, San Diego. Since the formation of our organization in 2016, we have been competing in the annual University Rover Challenge (URC), an international collegiate-level competition in which teams from around the world design and build an autonomous Mars rover. In the final round of competition, teams must complete the following four missions: Science Mission, Extreme Retrieval and Delivery Mission, Equipment Servicing Mission, and Autonomous Traversal Mission. These missions are held in Hanksville, a small town in Utah that features a Mars-like terrain for researchers and students to simulate their ideas for the Red Planet. You can read more about the competition by clicking on their website here. 

Our Yonder Dynamics 2017-2018 members:

What we've achieved so far:

  • Last year, we were one of the 36 teams out of 95 entries to make it to the final round of competition
  • We made UC San Diego history by making it into the final round two years in a row
  • We were the only school in the UC system to make both the 2017 and 2018 final rounds

With your support in funding, we can build a rover that will far surpass the results we've achieved so far. Our goal for this year's competition is to place among one of the top ten teams.
 

Our Project

We design and manufacture all aspects of the Mars rover. However, the necessary parts and software are not cheap, even with the help of our generous sponsors. By donating to Yonder Dynamics, you will be contributing to the funding that is necessary to purchase rover parts and fund the trip to URC, should we make it to the final round. Yonder members are eagerly taking on the competition's challenge to "design and build the next generation of Mars rovers that will one day work alongside human explorers in the field", and we cannot do this without your help. 

Procyon, our 2018 rover:

Based on what we've learned from trial and error through the past two competitions, team members have already created the designs that will eliminate previous inaccuracies. We are currently constructing and perfecting the new rover that will get us further above the competition. 

The 2019 Rover: What our subteams are working on

Motions: During the design process, the motions team made sure to integrate our systems by collaborating, and communicating closely. We use Solidworks for CAD and Google Drive File Stream to manage our data across our relatively large team of about 40 people. Compared to last year, all of our components will be machined to substantially higher specifications than ever before.

We’re depending on the drivetrain and chassis’s reliability, off road ability, and precise movement for every task in the competition. The suspension worked well last year, so we used that design as a foundation to improve upon. We completely redesigned the chassis out of carbon fiber and aluminum tubing and the back two wheel’s shock absorption system has an improved range of motion.

Moving on from our linear actuator design last year, we decided to challenge ourselves this year by using multiple belt pulley systems to actuate our arm. Each belt pulley system is responsible for rotating the whole arm, the lower arm, and the upper arm. We have incorporated turnbuckles into our belts for quick of our belts’ tensions. In addition, our arm has taken advantage of carbon fiber tubing for lowering weight while maintaining structural integrity.

Electrical: Electrical is designing a power budget based on the all electrical components to ensure power is maintained at all times during competition. Our focus will include motors and motor drivers selection, and designing an interactive printed circuit board for the software components. We are currently testing frequencies (900 MHz, 2.4 GHz, 5 GHz) to transmit our telemetry, controls, and video feed, as well as choosing types of antennas and radios to use. Further testing will include max power draw by each rover component with a focus on the drive train and arm to determine ideal operating point for competition.

Software: The University Rover Challenge is the most interesting programming challenge given to college students because of the autonomous traversal challenge. Our rover needs to find tennis balls hidden in the Utah desert autonomously, which is a surprisingly difficult problem composed of three main sections. The challenges are state estimation (figuring out where you are), obstacle avoidance (mapping the environment and generating safe paths), and efficient exploration. The first two are solvable problems and the software team will be learning to apply an extended Kalman filter to our sensor setup and modifying A* for our situation. However, for efficient exploration, the literature is very light and the software team has designed a novel solution to the problem and plans to maybe even publish a paper based on our results.

Science: The science team is responsible for tackling the soil analysis portion of the competition. Our task is to design and build a system to collect soil from the ground, deposit it into a sampling container, and carryout the necessary experiments to determine the presence of life using a number of techniques. Currently, we are utilizing a microbiological assaywhich monitors the turbidity of a sample over time to detect the presence of extant life. Also, we are using Raman spectroscopy to detect cellular carotenoids produced by some known extremophiles to search for extinct life.
 

The Impact

We have a diverse organization with members that come from all different types of backgrounds with various majors, from Computer Science and Mechanical Engineering to International Business and Communications. With so many members that specialize in individualized subjects, Yonder Dynamics is divided into five main subteams: Software, Motions, Science, Electrical, and Business. 

Although Yonder Dynamics is only a three-year old organization, we have created so much impact among the undergraduate students that are a part of the rover-building process. Members are hands-on with every single step, from the raw design and creating CADs to drilling and constructing the rover together. We are one of the few groups on campus where students have the opportunity to enjoy scientific research and inquiry on their own merit, giving them valuable professional skills they can use for lab positions, internships, and even future careers. 

A member working on this year's rover:

More importantly, members create strong bonds that transform into life-long friendships. We love working with each other and regularly enjoy events that build our teamwork, such as a bonfire night filled with s'mores or a relaxing weekend retreat in the snow. Our philosophy is "People First", meaning we strongly believe in developing each of our members as individuals before anything else. We're all united by one thing - our passion for robotics and space. 

Yonder members from URC 2018:

Yonder Dynamics in the News: 

In 2017, our team was featured on local TV channel ABC10news. Here is a link to the article.
 

We were also featured on UC San Diego's school-wide email newsletter, ThisWeek@UC San Diego. Here is a link to the article.

 

Thank you to our sponsors!

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Risks & Challenges

The University Rover Challenge has several rounds that teams must pass in order to continue on to the final round in Hanksville. Competition is tough, and more than half of the teams that applied for URC will be cut though the Systems Acceptance Review (SAR). 

For the last two years of competition, we have narrowly made it into the final round of competition among the ranks of the 30+ teams that are accepted. Although we are still learning from previous mistakes, we have made it our goal to confidently pass the SAR by creating a completed rover system that will demonstrate the fruits of our hard labor.

Should we not make it past the Systems Acceptance Review round and are unable to move forward to the final round of competition, we will still complete the construction and testing of our rover. Indiegogo rewards will also still be fulfilled as promised.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate to our campaign, please share our Indiegogo campaign to others and spread the word! Raising awareness is also a very important way to contribute. We appreciate any type of support we can get. 

If you are interested in donating to us in the future, here is a link to the donation page on our website. 

Also, don't forget to follow us on our social media pages to join us on our journey to URC 2019. We will be posting regular updates on the competition and any other related news when we can. 

Our website (currently under construction): https://www.yonderdynamics.org/
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/yonderdynamics/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/yonderdynamics
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/yonderdynamics/
