We are Yonder Dynamics, a multidisciplinary student robotics organization from the University of California, San Diego. Since the formation of our organization in 2016, we have been competing in the annual University Rover Challenge (URC), an international collegiate-level competition in which teams from around the world design and build an autonomous Mars rover. In the final round of competition, teams must complete the following four missions: Science Mission, Extreme Retrieval and Delivery Mission, Equipment Servicing Mission, and Autonomous Traversal Mission. These missions are held in Hanksville, a small town in Utah that features a Mars-like terrain for researchers and students to simulate their ideas for the Red Planet. You can read more about the competition by clicking on their website here. 
Our Yonder Dynamics 2017-2018 members:

What we've achieved so far:

Last year, we were one of the 36 teams out of 95 entries to make it to the final round of competition
We made UC San Diego history by making it into the final round two years in a row
We were the only school in the UC system to make both the 2017 and 2018 final rounds

With your support in funding, we can build a rover that will far surpass the results we've achieved so far. Our goal for this year's competition is to place among one of the top ten teams. 

Our Project
We design and manufacture all aspects of the Mars rover. However, the necessary parts and software are not cheap, even with the help of our generous sponsors. By donating to Yonder Dynamics, you will be contributing to the funding that is necessary to purchase rover parts and fund the trip to URC, should we make it to the final round. Yonder members are eagerly taking on the competition's challenge to "design and build the next generation of Mars rovers that will one day work alongside human explorers in the field", and we cannot do this without your help. 
Procyon, our 2018 rover:

Based on what we've learned from trial and error through the past two competitions, team members have already created the designs that will eliminate previous inaccuracies. We are currently constructing and perfecting the new rover that will get us further above the competition. 
The 2019 Rover: What our subteams are working on
Motions: During the design process, the motions team made sure to integrate our systems by collaborating, and communicating closely. We use Solidworks for CAD and Google Drive File Stream to manage our data across our relatively large team of about 40 people. Compared to last year, all of our components will be machined to substantially higher specifications than ever before.We’re depending on the drivetrain and chassis’s reliability, off road ability, and precise movement for every task in the competition. The suspension worked well last year, so we used that design as a foundation to improve upon. We completely redesigned the chassis out of carbon fiber and aluminum tubing and the back two wheel’s shock absorption system has an improved range of motion.Moving on from our linear actuator design last year, we decided to challenge ourselves this year by using multiple belt pulley systems to actuate our arm. Each belt pulley system is responsible for rotating the whole arm, the lower arm, and the upper arm. We have incorporated turnbuckles into our belts for quick of our belts’ tensions. In addition, our arm has taken advantage of carbon fiber tubing for lowering weight while maintaining structural integrity.
Electrical: Electrical is designing a power budget based on the all electrical components to ensure power is maintained at all times during competition. Our focus will include motors and motor drivers selection, and designing an interactive printed circuit board for the software components. We are currently testing frequencies (900 MHz, 2.4 GHz, 5 GHz) to transmit our telemetry, controls, and video feed, as well as choosing types of antennas and radios to use. Further testing will include max power draw by each rover component with a focus on the drive train and arm to determine ideal operating point for competition.
Software: The University Rover Challenge is the most interesting programming challenge given to college students because of the autonomous traversal challenge. Our rover needs to find tennis balls hidden in the Utah desert autonomously, which is a surprisingly difficult problem composed of three main sections. The challenges are state estimation (figuring out where you are), obstacle avoidance (mapping the environment and generating safe paths), and efficient exploration. The first two are solvable problems and the software team will be learning to apply an extended Kalman filter to our sensor setup and modifying A* for our situation. However, for efficient exploration, the literature is very light and the software team has designed a novel solution to the problem and plans to maybe even publish a paper based on our results.
Science: The science team is responsible for tackling the soil analysis portion of the competition. Our task is to design and build a system to collect soil from the ground, deposit it into a sampling container, and carryout the necessary experiments to determine the presence of life using a number of techniques. Currently, we are utilizing a microbiological assaywhich monitors the turbidity of a sample over time to detect the presence of extant life. Also, we are using Raman spectroscopy to detect cellular carotenoids produced by some known extremophiles to search for extinct life. 

The Impact
We have a diverse organization with members that come from all different types of backgrounds with various majors, from Computer Science and Mechanical Engineering to International Business and Communications. With so many members that specialize in individualized subjects, Yonder Dynamics is divided into five main subteams: Software, Motions, Science, Electrical, and Business. 
Although Yonder Dynamics is only a three-year old organization, we have created so much impact among the undergraduate students that are a part of the rover-building process. Members are hands-on with every single step, from the raw design and creating CADs to drilling and constructing the rover together. We are one of the few groups on campus where students have the opportunity to enjoy scientific research and inquiry on their own merit, giving them valuable professional skills they can use for lab positions, internships, and even future careers. 
A member working on this year's rover:

More importantly, members create strong bonds that transform into life-long friendships. We love working with each other and regularly enjoy events that build our teamwork, such as a bonfire night filled with s'mores or a relaxing weekend retreat in the snow. Our philosophy is "People First", meaning we strongly believe in developing each of our members as individuals before anything else. We're all united by one thing - our passion for robotics and space. 
Yonder members from URC 2018:

Yonder Dynamics in the News: 

In 2017, our team was featured on local TV channel ABC10news. Here is a link to the article.
 


We were also featured on UC San Diego's school-wide email newsletter, ThisWeek@UC San Diego. Here is a link to the article.
 


Thank you to our sponsors!

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Risks & Challenges
The University Rover Challenge has several rounds that teams must pass in order to continue on to the final round in Hanksville. Competition is tough, and more than half of the teams that applied for URC will be cut though the Systems Acceptance Review (SAR). 
For the last two years of competition, we have narrowly made it into the final round of competition among the ranks of the 30+ teams that are accepted. Although we are still learning from previous mistakes, we have made it our goal to confidently pass the SAR by creating a completed rover system that will demonstrate the fruits of our hard labor.
Should we not make it past the Systems Acceptance Review round and are unable to move forward to the final round of competition, we will still complete the construction and testing of our rover. Indiegogo rewards will also still be fulfilled as promised.
 

Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't donate to our campaign, please share our Indiegogo campaign to others and spread the word! Raising awareness is also a very important way to contribute. We appreciate any type of support we can get. 
If you are interested in donating to us in the future, here is a link to the donation page on our website. 
Also, don't forget to follow us on our social media pages to join us on our journey to URC 2019. We will be posting regular updates on the competition and any other related news when we can. 
Our website (currently under construction): https://www.yonderdynamics.org/Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/yonderdynamics/Twitter: https://twitter.com/yonderdynamicsInstagram: https://www.instagram.com/yonderdynamics/

story:
Overview

படங்காட்டு (Padang-kattu) a new card game from our "Play and Learn" series. This is a simple quick draw card game, where the players act or draw to guess Tamil words. A perfect card game for the Tamil schools, fun parties, vacation, travel, reunions, and after-dinner conversations. 

 

This படங்காட்டு (Padang-kattu) card game is for all ages. The game has 1200 Tamil words spread across six categories such as compound words, science words, animals and birds, personalities and cities, and, etc. Players draw a card from a word-cards deck and act or draw or draw it blind so that their team guesses the word from the card. If the team wins, the team collects the card. The team collecting 24 cards wins the game.

படங்காட்டு (Padang-kattu) is for 2+ player, ages 7+. It takes  2 - 3 minutes to learn and 45 minutes to complete the game. 

 

1200 Tamil words on 100 Word-cards

24 action-cards (note the color and icon).These help in choosing the word from the word-card. 

Guide cards (help on word category and action-card icons)

What do you need to play?

1) Your friends or family members, 2) paper, 3) pencil and 4) timer. 

 

Goal: The team collecting 24 word-cards wins the game. Players pick an action-card, based on the card's icon and color, players read the word on the word-card (which they hide from others) and perform the action (either act or draw or blind draw) on the card to their team members. If the team finds the word, the team keeps the card.

Step 1: Pick your team. Let us say 2+ per team. 

                                              

 Step 2:  Choose the word-card color to play either a red or yellow side. Each side has six words in six categories. 

 Step 3: Okay, let us pick the yellow side. Keep the yellow side facedown.  

Step 4: Get the guide card to help the teams on the word category and action-card. 

Step 5: Shuffle the action-cards and keep the action-cards facedown. 

Step 6: The game setting is done, we can begin to play. Team A goes first and a player from the team picks the action card below and show it to all. The following card tells the player is going to act the word on the green color and the icon indicates it is a living being (an animal or a bird).   

Step 7: The player now picks a word-card (let say the following word-card) from the word-card stack and reads the word (without letting others know about the word) on the green color (புலி - tiger) and act out the word for the team A. 

Step 8: If team A finds the word within 1 minute, team A keeps the card. 

Step 9: The game continues until a team wins 24 cards. 

We want to get படங்காட்டு (Padang-kattu) into many Tamil homes and schools. Your donation or pre-purchase is very important to bring this product. 

We are trying to hit the funding goal of at least $7000 to meet our minimum production quantity. We plan to deliver by Feb 15, 2021. We are building a quality game in Tamil, which the industry lacks. For every, $1000 through this campaign, we will donate 10 game boxes to the Tamil schools. 

In addition, your donations also helps in funding our "Young Tamil author program" and new product development. In our "Young Tamil author" program, we publish books written by children learning Tamil.

Help us bring this game to more kids!

Each contributor gets our perks.  If you wish to just donate, we will give the perks (the game boxes) to Tamil schools. For example, if you donate $100, we would donate 5 game boxes to Tamil schools.   

  • The main Perk is the game. We will ship the product to you home. 
  • Even if we do not meet our goal, anyone who contributes will get their Perks.

International shipment - Yes, we will ship internationally to your location. No additional cost is required for international shipping. We have distributors and friends in international locations to help with international distributions. 

Risks & Challenges

Risk, if we didn't meet our goals, the production time might extend by a month and the perk shipment might be delayed. 

  • Ofcourse, your help is very critital for our success. If we don't we are trying to find other loans . which might cost us to bring the products. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We want to share படங்காட்டு with as many kids as we can. Please help us get the word out about this campaign by using the Indiegogo share tools!

  • You get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Share our campaign detail on your social media page or WhatsApp friend groups. 

Your love and generous support make this product reach our children and learn the Tamil language in a fun and interactive way.

Other Ways You Can Help
We want to share படங்காட்டு with as many kids as we can. Please help us get the word out about this campaign by using the Indiegogo share tools!

You get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
Share our campaign detail on your social media page or WhatsApp friend groups. 

Your love and generous support make this product reach our children and learn the Tamil language in a fun and interactive way.

story:
Meet Chatterbox, the educational smart speaker that puts privacy first

Chatterbox is the world's first educational build-it-yourself, program-it-yourself smart speaker kit for kids that puts privacy first.

Think of it like an Amazon Alexa or Siri, but one focused on privacy that kids can build and program to bring their creativity to life. 

 

Featured in

A HUGE thank you to Hackster.io for interviewing us and taking the time to learn about Chatterbox, our beginnings and our future.

Also featured in:

Why learn about AI?

Computers of the future will be voice-driven artificial intelligence. How do we prepare kids for a future where a human-like AI is ubiquitous? We do that by giving them the tools and motivations to create and use their very own AI.

By building the hardware and teaching the voice assistant, kids learn how and why this technology works, rather than being tricked by "black-box" technology into thinking voice AI is human.

 

What is Chatterbox?

​1. Smart Speaker Kit

The only smart speaker kit easy enough for kids to build. The Chatterbox case is made of recyclable chipboard (really strong cardboard) and powered by the Raspberry Pi computer, the world's most popular educational computer. Its ears and voice are powered by our very own ChatterVoice HAT and microphone. Fold it, build it, customize it!

2. Smart Assistant

Chatterbox is the only educational assistant that kids can teach and program how to listen, talk and respond to commands. It's designed for learning and engineered for fun!

3. Chatterbox App

The Chatterbox app is a kid-friendly app that empowers kids to build their own voice-activated skills by connecting LEGO-like blocks. 

 

 

How Chatterbox Works

1. Build your own smart speaker

Our step-by-step instructions make it easy for any child seven or older to build the chipboard case and assemble the electronics, making problem solving fun and hands-on. It's as easy as making a paper airplane!  

 

2. Teachable smart assistant

Think of Chatterbox as a smart assistant that doesn't know it's smart yet. Teaching your assistant new tricks is simple using the easy-to-use Chatterbox Skill Builder. Kids as young as 7 years old can learn to build unique skills to get the weather, ask questions, control lights, listen to music and make their own voice-based games. Anything is possible!  

3. Montessori inspired, educator approved

Chatterbox is designed to give kids a practical learning environment where they can explore their unique creativity while developing communication, problem solving and critical thinking skills.   

 

What Kids Learn

 Chatterbox is a maker kit for children to build real, screen-free technology that they can use in their daily lives. Designing voice skills places greater emphasis on communication and creative thinking.   

1. Critical Thinking -- Learn to deconstruct problems to understand how things work.

2. Communication -- Build information processing skills by having to anticipate how other people communicate and ask questions. 

3. Problem Solving -- Solve problems using realtime information from the internet.

 

Kids are teaching their Chatterbox amazing skills!

Kids can set up magic words to control lights, play music, message grandparents and craft their own interactive story adventures. Anything is possible!

Featured Integrations

 

What's in the Box?

Chatterbox is a maker kit that contains everything kids need to build and program their very own smart speaker.

 The kit includes:

-Laser-cut chipboard enclosure

-Raspberry Pi 3B+ and specs

-ChatterVoice HAT + Mic board

-Large arcade button

-Speaker

-SD card with pre-loaded ChatterOS

 

No Ads and Always Privacy First

Your child's privacy and safety is extremely important to us. Unlike Amazon Alexa or Google Assistant, Chatterbox only listens when you push the big yellow button. Chatterbox doesn't harvest or share any personal data and doesn't contain any ads. We *strongly* advocate for a commercial-free childhood.  

Have specific questions and concerns? We want to hear them! Email us at support@hellochatterbox.com.
 

What People Are Saying About Chatterbox

 

Meet the Team

 We're educators, designers and developers committed to make learning fun. Our team's collective experience has built educational software and hardware products used by over 60 million people and 80 thousand schools worldwide. 

 

Project Timeline

 

 

Teaching Chatterbox to speak, get weather forecasts and how to text messages to Dad.

What People Are Saying About Chatterbox

 
Meet the Team
 We're educators, designers and developers committed to make learning fun. Our team's collective experience has built educational software and hardware products used by over 60 million people and 80 thousand schools worldwide.

Teaching Chatterbox to speak, get weather forecasts and how to text messages to Dad.

story:
SLA 3D printing gets more and more popular. However, the printers on the market are either too expensive or cheap but not user-friendly. So we made Paladin, the perfect combination of great quality and affordable price tag.

Paladin SLA 3D printer is designed with the industrial level 1080p LCD and light source so that it can print with high resolution consistently. With the all-metal body, auto leveling and dual Z-axis slides features, Paladin is easy to use and has better durability.

 

  • AUTO-LEVELING

Automatic leveling system makes the print preparing easier. Even if your print bed is somewhat unleveled, the auto-leveling 3D printer will make minor adjustments to make sure your print platform at an optimum place. 

 

  • AUTO RESIN PUMPING

Paladin has a built-in pump to pump refill in or drill out the resins from the tank, and it makes the resin management super easy and cost-effective. Pressing the button to start the auto-refilling or resin recycling. There is a sensor which can judge the remaining condition of the resin to add it automatically. The pump can be cleaned by pouring anhydrous alcohol into the resin tank after the resin is recycled. In the case of the same kind of resin, the color can be mixed randomly.

 

  • AIR PURIFYING

Resins can smell bad and that`s the reason stopping many people to start SLA 3D printing. We bear that in mind when design Paladin! With the built-in air purifier, it can eliminate most of the awful smell and safe to use inside the house.

 

We used an all-metal design for Paladin`s body not only to make it durable and stable during the printing but also to make it a piece of art placing on your desktop.

 

3D printing is time-consuming and we don`t want to miss the critical status. That`s why Paladin is one-button to get started and you can check the printing progress through the intuitive touchscreen.   

 

The key for a good printing result is the light source. We use a patented design and it can offer a more concentrated and improved light source for Paladin SLA 3D printer. 

 

 The LCD screen is another core component.  Its normal thickness is 0.7mm but we used a special version of 1.3mm, and it has better heat resistance feature. By doing so, the screen will last 20 times longer (up to 3000 times print) than the normal ones.

 

Paladin's software supports different layer thickness to help you get a balance between printing quality and printing time.

We also designed 3 great resins for you to get started with. They are good for multiple purpose usages, affordable too!

 

  •  Standard Resin | High-detail resin with smooth, injection mold-like surface 

 

  •  Flexible Resin | Simulating soft-touch materials and adding soft overmolds to multi-material assemblies

 

  •  Castable Resin | Good burnout performance with no ash, perfect for craft and jewelry design

 

  •  Touch Resin | Super good elastomeric properties, designed to stimulate rubber
story_txt:
SLA 3D printing gets more and more popular. However, the printers on the market are either too expensive or cheap but not user-friendly. So we made Paladin, the perfect combination of great quality and affordable price tag.
Paladin SLA 3D printer is designed with the industrial level 1080p LCD and light source so that it can print with high resolution consistently. With the all-metal body, auto leveling and dual Z-axis slides features, Paladin is easy to use and has better durability.
 
XY Resolution: 50μm | Z Resolution: 10μm | Printing Size: 150*130*73mm
 
 

 
AUTO-LEVELING
Automatic leveling system makes the print preparing easier. Even if your print bed is somewhat unleveled, the auto-leveling 3D printer will make minor adjustments to make sure your print platform at an optimum place. 
 

 
Auto-leveling
 
AUTO RESIN PUMPING

The pump can be cleaned by pouring anhydrous alcohol into the resin tank after the resin is recycled. In the case of the same kind of resin, the color can be mixed randomly.
 
Auto Resin Pumping

Build-in Air Purifying 2W Power Input

All-metal Body

Intuitive Touchscreen

Light gathering technology - Others vs Paladin
 
 The LCD screen is another core component.  Its normal thickness is 0.7mm but we used a special version of 1.3mm, and it has better heat resistance feature. By doing so, the screen will last 20 times longer (up to 3000 times print) than the normal ones.
 
Thicker LCD Screen for More Accurate Prints
 
Improved LCD Life With Better Heat-Resistant Materials
 


 

 
Step1: One Button to Connect The Resin & Auto-leveling
 
Step2: Drag The Printing File to The USB Drive
 
Step3: Insert The USB Drive to Paladin and Press The Start Button
 
Paladin Software
Paladin's software supports different layer thickness to help you get a balance between printing quality and printing time.

 

 
We also designed 3 great resins for you to get started with. They are good for multiple purpose usages, affordable too!
 
 Standard Resin | High-detail resin with smooth, injection mold-like surface 
 

 
 Flexible Resin | Simulating soft-touch materials and adding soft overmolds to multi-material assemblies
 

 
 Castable Resin | Good burnout performance with no ash, perfect for craft and jewelry design
 

 
 Touch Resin | Super good elastomeric properties, designed to stimulate rubber

story:
Short Summary

Hi everyone, 

Thanks for taking the time to read on…

My name is David Shepherd and I have previously been employed very satisfyingly across a broad range of Corporate Support Services Management within State Government as well as Sales Management and Recruitment in the Private sector. 

I am married, live in Tasmania and have a 27 and 21 year old daughter living in New South Wales and Queensland respectively.

Having firsthand experience of the shortcomings of medical and health services available in rural and regional sectors as well as looking for future directions I am now determined to complete a Bachelor Degree in Medical Radiation Science that will enable me to work within Medical Imaging (Radiography).

This will enable me to practice professionally, derive permanent employment on graduation and also provide options for part-time, on call and locum services to rural and regional locations in my later years.

I have been accepted into Charles Sturt University, Wagga Wagga NSW campus (Student ID 68103148) and commence orientation on 23 February 2015 with studies commencing 2 March 2015.

Course fees are initially covered by the Australian Government and are repayable from future earnings through the tax system. Relying solely on Australian Government AUSTUDY living support of around $214 weekly while studying will not cover the financial resources required to study interstate at CSU Wagga Wagga including transport between my family home in Tasmania and CSU Wagga Wagga (NSW) campus, accommodation, utilities, meals, health, clothing, textbooks, computer and peripherals, telephone, internet, travel and the list goes on!

There are extremely limited opportunities for casual or partime employment within the Wagga Wagga area and I have insufficient financial reserves to maintain myself so that is why I need your help and support now.

Your generosity, support and encouragement will open a new chapter in my life, guarantee my future economic independence and allow me to give back to communities.

What We Need & What You Get

I estimate that additional actual costs for first year studies are somewhere around $9000 in real terms over and above existing commitments especially given that two households need to be sustained for at least part of the first year.  Once the households are amalgamated into the Wagga Wagga area that will substantially reduce costs and allow excess funding to be rolled forward into future years. Don't be afraid to "overgive"!

I am applying for AusStudy allowance of $214 weekly which will cover living essentials but not the initial move to Campus, accommodation, textbooks, housing setup,computer etc.

Expense Amount

Initial Transport from Tasmania to Campus $500 

Session 1 Accommodation $5000

Accommodation setup (household furniture/appliances/home wares) $1500

Textbooks and Stationery $800

Computer, peripherals and consumables $1200

TOTAL $9000

You can become a part of my life story.

All I can promise is to update you on my progress so that you have the continued satisfaction of seeing what you have been a part of.

Any contribution grows the pool of funds and given the variables available I am confident that that I can adjust my University experience to accommodate the reality of dollar availability.

I know I am in for some hard yards, I have to be on Campus on 23 February 2015 need to start and do this even while waiting for funds or I will miss this amazing opportunity!

Hopefully, funding will be sufficient that I can rollover unused funds into subsequent years that will not be as expensive as Year 1 as there will only be one household to run and no travel expenditure.

The Impact

 I have lived in small rural and regional communities for some time and have firsthand experience of the pain and trauma suffered when the closest hospital maybe an hour’s drive away, can’t complete simple X-rays for a broken arm/shoulder because they can’t maintain 24 hours services and may limited On Call or Locum capability. You then may have to stay in hospital overnight and then be driven another hour or more to have X-rays done! So maybe 24 hours later you get your arm set!

I love living in a rural setting although it comes with the price of limited levels of medical support availability - too few practitioners over an extended geographic area and what seems to be continuing budget reductions.

I have recently spoken with radiographers and sonographers and explained that I want to study, gain real life experience and then focus on providing on call services to rural hospitals that can’t sustain full time Radiography staff as well as rural and regional Locum support. Without exception they all said that would be amazing, many recounting incidences of cancelled leave as there was no Locum or on call staff replacements available. 

I have a strong record of achievement in all I undertake. One short example:

Having to leave High School before sitting my Higher School Certificate I decided a number of years later I needed to do this to provide options for further study. I engaged the help and support of former teachers and friends who were now teachers and sat the examinations on 9 weeks’ notice – only missing out on my HSC by 3 marks in English! The following year I returned to college full time and undertook a combined Year 11/12 in one year and Matriculated with results above 85% of my former school colleagues.

I can do this.

With your support.

Now.

Risks & Challenges

I have been inspired to set this course of action by a number of people I have met along life’s journey: including GP who began Medical studies around my age.

During my years of Management experience I have often needed to assess what is the worst that can happen if I take a certain action and if things go wrong. 

So what are the risks? What do I do? I can’t see that there is any great risk in this undertaking. I was recently asked whether I found the prospect of studying at University daunting and when I responded yes he said then I just needed to work harder at it. I will.I am no stranger to hard work.

As Winston Churchill famously said: “Never, never, never give up.” 

Other Ways You Can Help

 Some people just can’t contribute but that doesn't mean you can’t help!

What can you do?

Share this request for funding. Post it on Facebook, Twitter etc

Become a mentor during my studies.

Encourage me.

FINALLY: While it would be great for one person to fund this funding request I am reminded of the owner of NCR who in the late 1800’s/early 1900’s stated he would rather have 100 agents sell 1 cash register each rather than 1 agent who could sell 100!!

WILL YOU, CAN YOU, BE ONE OF THE 100 OR EVEN 1000?

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Our Work.

In 2014, a report by the UCLA Civil Rights Project found New York State's public schools to be the most segregated schools in the country.  Despite the 1954 victory of Brown v. Board of Education, NYC schools currently serve 1.1 million students in separate and unequal schools. 

IntegrateNYC4me believes that we can transform this reality.  

The mission of IntegrateNYC4me is to engage school communities around NYC in transforming New York City from a system of segregated, unequal schools to a system of integrated, sound, equitable schools.  We are committed to bringing the rich diversity and resources of our city into our schools.   We  engage segregated school communities with political leaders, academics, advocates, and artists to take part in examining segregation, bringing awareness to its impact, and building relationships to set the foundation for integration across segregated school communities.  

Our Project.

This year four public schools engaged in our work will be painting community murals to raise awareness about the impact of segregation and the possibilities of integration in NYC.  One mural will be painted in collaboration by the students of the Bronx Academy of Letters and Eleanor Roosevelt High School after they complete a week long exchange examining the impact of segregation on their school communities, building powerful relationships with students whom they may never have met otherwise, and creating a collective vision for more integrated, equitable schools.  A second will be painted by Parkslope Collegiate High School and Middle school to represent their interpretation of the history of segregation and their vision for the future of integration.  Your contribution will create the possibility of connection, creation, and sharing for the young people engaged in this historic work.

We need to raise $5,000 by May 1st to purchase supplies for the creation of the murals and the publicity materials to share the work with our surrounding communities.

Join us in the powerful act of sharing the possibility of integration with the 1.1 million students of NYC schools.

story:
Short Summary

Hi my name is Amber Hernandez, I am a junior at South Miami Senior High School. I am seeking sponsorship from within my community in order to attend the National Student Leadership Conference. A chance in a life time where I will be able to spend 10 days in a career program where I will enjoy hands-on experiments, cutting- edge technology, and innovated leadership workshops in the health profession at Harvard Medical School.


What I Need 

  • $4000 tuition payment towards Medicine & Health Care program
  • Upon reaching my goal, I will be able to have clinical experiences in a surgical room, visit medical facilities, diagnose and treat patients, and do scientific research on HIV/AIDS and cancer.

The Impact

By attending the NSLC on Medicine & Health Care I will gain an interactive approach to learning that gives me the opportunity to immerse myself in the challenging complexities of the medical profession. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, you can help by spreading my message with your friends and family on social media and via email by sharing this link!

story:
MSAE Robotics

Maharishi School is located in the small town of Fairfield, IA. Our students are participating in the FIRST Robotics Competition for the first time in their academic career. The competition involves lifting, transporting and maneuvering recycling totes throughout the field of play and gain the most number of points they can in 2.5 minutes. They will compete in teams of three schools, all collaborating to achieve the task of clearing the field of play of litter.

Each of our eight students wants to pursue a career in STEM, and this competition allows them to nurture the many skills needed in those fields. Their talents range from computer programming, mechanical engineering, electronics, metalwork and structural design. Throughout the daily meetings--which last four to five hours on the weekdays, and up to 12 hours a day on the weekends--the students have learned valuable technical skills as well as interpersonal skills of teamwork and conflict resolution.

Your contribution will help us fund the materials needed to finish the construction of our robot. The registration of $6000 was raised by the students and an additional $1500 has been spent on supplies by the students. These out-of-pocket  expenses limit the boundaries of our design. The greater amount of funding we receive, the greater amount of creative freedom is available to our students. 


What We Need & What You Get

We will need funding for the following:

- Materials (aluminum angles, circuitry, motors, gears, pulleys, chains)

- Travel expenses to the competition

- Lodging expenses in Peoria, IL

- Additional funding will go towards further establishing a robotics curriculum at our school, including an inventory of robotics equipment, mechanical tools, and supplies for STEM education.

For your support, we will provide you:

- Updates on the progress of our robotics competition entry

- Personalized letters showing the effect of this competition experience on our student's academic and future professional careers

- Sponsorship recognition on the competition robot to be displayed at the event


The Impact

As a small school, we are limited in the number of programs we can provide to our students. Our students have very sharp engineering minds but do not have the resources to apply them to real-life applications. This competition allows them to experience firsthand the excitement and challenges that the process of engineering  offers.

Risks & Challenges

Our main challenge is to create a robot that can participate in the 2015 FIRST Robotics Competition and compete with other schools to gain a spot for the National Robotics Championship. The interdisciplinary knowledge of electronics, mechanical engineering, and structural design must be applied seamlessly to achieve the requirements of lifting, transporting and maneuvering through the competition field of play. The risk of funding this campaign is that our students are competing for the first time in such a competition. However, with a majority of our students being seniors and already possessing a strong basis in technical knowledge, we have the confidence of overcoming any challenges that we may face.

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to financial support, you can provide our students with mentorship in a STEM field of your expertise, exposure through sharing our campaign to your peers, and guidance in building a strong robotics program at our school if you share that experience.

story:
A BOOK, A GIFT, A LIFE  - Campaign to Restock School Libraries in the Philippines.

WHY A $10,000 GOAL?

Because there is a GREAT NEED or an even GREATER NEED to restock and rebuild the school libraries in the Philippines especially schools that were devastated by storms. We require monetary funding and gift-in-kind support to realize our mission. Along with other organizations that take part in rebuilding people's lives  ReadPhilippinesToronto also reaches out by giving a gift of books in hopes to improve literacy among its people. We are eager to feed hungry minds and to make these books available again in the hands of children, youth and adults. The generous amount you donate will be used to buy new books, school supplies and to defray minimal administrative expenses. We will also use the fund to defray shipping costs to various areas in the Philippines. 

Recently, we responded to RAPPLER'S MOVE.Ph Donate A Book To Mindanao campaign led by Lou Gepuela and also teamed up with the Library Renewal Partnership in Manila. We shipped around 300 novel, travel, reference and self-help books that will be trans-shipped to various schools in the Philippines. We are currently in collaboration with Pinoy Reading Buddies, a reading and literacy advocacy group which carries out workshops for children and young adults held in various provinces of the country.

ReadPhilippines Toronto continues to receive book requests from schools, teachers and community groups. It is our responsibility to respond to these requests. Your kindness and generosity are vital to our cause.

This is the library of Abaca Elementary School, Abaca, San Enrique, Iloilo after Yolanda. All contents of the library, including books were destroyed. Photo provided by John Aghon through Reyma Pareno-Eastman to ReadPhilippines on March 16, 2014.

WHO ARE WE?

READPHILIPPINES Toronto is a group of Filipino-Canadians who have passion for community service and the love for reading. The group convened on November 11, 2005 to address the needs of one of the schools in Infanta, Quezon which was destroyed by a storm on November 29, 2004. PICAB Elementary School library has to be restocked with books and the children need to get back to their reading again. Hence, the birth of ReadPhilippines. Our goal is to promote reading and literacy and to help fill up the bookshelves of the libraries of underprivileged schools in the Philippines especially schools in the rural areas of the country. We realize these goals by sending new and good-quality used books ranging from reference books, paperback and hardback novels to recreational reading materials and informative magazines. We strongly encourage individuals and organizations to donate used books and monetary donations to defray shipping costs. We aim to fill up the empty shelves of these schools and we aim for these books to be available in the school libraries where they are mostly needed as soon as possible.


October 3, 2015: Sorting, labeling and packing children's books to be shipped to R.P.Cruz Sr. Elementary School Purok 2 New Lower Bicutan Taguig City

WHY DO WE DO IT?

Books educate and are a portal to the many aspects of life. Books are the basic tools for literacy and education but most of the children and adults in the Philippines grow up without access to books. So for many of them books are truly a gift of life and hope. We also want to save unused books from ending up in landfills. Collecting and putting them back in library shelves and in the hands of people who need them not only impact their lives and the society but the environment as well.

HOW DO WE DO IT?

We announce our need for books through word of mouth, public announcements, website, social media and flyers. We use places like a church or a community centre as our book drop-off location. Once we gathered the books we label them, pack in a balikbayan box (24x18x24) and then ship them. Our funding  is scarce so members chip-in for the shipping cost. Shipment to Manila normally takes 6 to 8 weeks and more if sent to provinces. We ship the books we collected to a school recipient as soon as we gather them.

OUR GRATITUDE

ReadPhilippines Toronto, its members and the many people who will be benefiting from this cause would like to thank your for your time to read our story and for your generous support. Thank you very much for giving them the opportunity to see their way into a bright and productive future.

We are eager to feed hungry minds and to make these books available again in the hands of children, youth and adults. The generous amount you donate will be used to buy new books, school supplies and to defray minimal administrative expenses. We will also use the fund to defray shipping costs to various areas in the Philippines. Recently, we responded to RAPPLER'S MOVE.Ph Donate A Book To Mindanao campaign led by Lou Gepuela and also teamed up with the Library Renewal Partnership in Manila. We shipped around 300 novel, travel, reference and self-help books that will be trans-shipped to various schools in the Philippines. We are currently in collaboration with Pinoy Reading Buddies, a reading and literacy advocacy group which carries out workshops for children and young adults held in various provinces of the country.ReadPhilippines Toronto continues to receive book requests from schools, teachers and community groups. It is our responsibility to respond to these requests. Your kindness and generosity are vital to our cause.
This is the library of Abaca Elementary School, Abaca, San Enrique, Iloilo after Yolanda. All contents of the library, including books were destroyed. Photo provided by John Aghon through Reyma Pareno-Eastman to ReadPhilippines on March 16, 2014.WHO ARE WE?READPHILIPPINES Toronto is a group of Filipino-Canadians who have passion for community service and the love for reading. The group convened on November 11, 2005 to address the needs of one of the schools in Infanta, Quezon which was destroyed by a storm on November 29, 2004. PICAB Elementary School library has to be restocked with books and the children need to get back to their reading again. Hence, the birth of ReadPhilippines. Our goal is to promote reading and literacy and to help fill up the bookshelves of the libraries of underprivileged schools in the Philippines especially schools in the rural areas of the country. We realize these goals by sending new and good-quality used books ranging from reference books, paperback and hardback novels to recreational reading materials and informative magazines. We strongly encourage individuals and organizations to donate used books and monetary donations to defray shipping costs. We aim to fill up the empty shelves of these schools and we aim for these books to be available in the school libraries where they are mostly needed as soon as possible. 
October 3, 2015: Sorting, labeling and packing children's books to be shipped to R.P.Cruz Sr. Elementary School Purok 2 New Lower Bicutan Taguig CityWHY DO WE DO IT?Books educate and are a portal to the many aspects of life. Books are the basic tools for literacy and education but most of the children and adults in the Philippines grow up without access to books. So for many of them books are truly a gift of life and hope. We also want to save unused books from ending up in landfills. Collecting and putting them back in library shelves and in the hands of people who need them not only impact their lives and the society but the environment as well.HOW DO WE DO IT?We announce our need for books through word of mouth, public announcements, website, social media and flyers. We use places like a church or a community centre as our book drop-off location. Once we gathered the books we label them, pack in a balikbayan box (24x18x24) and then ship them. Our funding  is scarce so members chip-in for the shipping cost. Shipment to Manila normally takes 6 to 8 weeks and more if sent to provinces. We ship the books we collected to a school recipient as soon as we gather them.OUR GRATITUDEReadPhilippines Toronto, its members and the many people who will be benefiting from this cause would like to thank your for your time to read our story and for your generous support. Thank you very much for giving them the opportunity to see their way into a bright and productive future.

story:
Hello!


I am a young entrepreneur and i love challenges, you do two years we decided to start this project called Squash Club Tuluá.

The squash passionate about but there´s no where to play, then decided to build a sport complex for the practice of this sport. We have played man and doors and we got great support, so much so that we need very little to start.



We need your support!

For the complex can function we need the wood floor to play, safety glass, fixtures and stands. Therefore, if in materials or money help us gratefully received.

The complex have designed four squash courts but enabling at least two can operated in the medium term and bring the other.




Specifically need 27 - luminaires with specular base 15 mts - tempered glass squash, with their respective fittings 170 mts of wood Guaymaro 240 mts wooden mezzanine Anti- impact rubber 384 + Transport , installation, assembly .




Why help?

Our project we have started to pulse, and painstakingly slowly going forward. 
Tulua , Valle del Cauca , Colombia , is a very nice town , but also quite struck by the war that exists in our country , and despite the progress and the will of the people has come out ahead , many young people are on the street, generators being more violence. 

Squash club Tuluá, is a space for young people to be linked and have a choice to keep their free time spent in healthy, recreational activities and competitive . We also want to promote and encourage the practice of Squash in Tulua and region . 


Risk and Challenge


One of the most latent risks is one in which we are now , which is the lack of liquidity to reach the desired point. We know that we have no squash nearby ( in the city of Cali to 92km away, are located closest ) which is a direct competition , but know and understand that the incursion of this new discipline can take longer to consolidate the expected. 
However , the goal is to position and promote the sport and its practice as an activity easily accessible and excellent benefits for the body, and of course wins.


If you've got here 

We thank you very much for your time and for your interest . 
If you have any idea who we can provide the materials we need as we would greatly appreciate if you recommend us . 
In any and every circumstance , thanks and whether they will walk and reach Tulua , do not forget to visit .. spend on the house !.

story:
Helping Hands at Hemp Nation

Hemp Nation’s purpose as a Research and Cultivation School is to develop and promote personal independence by using raw hemp materials, processing tools, and business techniques to grow, harvest, create, make available, and allow for the sale of excess hemp retail products.

We provide education by offering lectures, classes, labs, and other hands-on experiences focused around the propagation, harvesting, and processing of industrial hemp as well as its useful, manufacturable end-products; i.e. cloth, paper, bio-diesel, various construction materials, and food stock. Hemp Nation also strives to provide all the tools and materials needed to grow, process, and package hemp products including land, seeds, fertilizer and planting tools.

The participants work the fields, grow houses, or labs, manning all the equipment while learning hands on in a live environment. A portion of whole goods is kept by Hemp Nation for other projects while the rest is evenly distributed among the participants for the last and most creative lab in a coursework track - “The Finishing Lab.” All who enter The Finishing Lab are considered artists - no longer participants - and are taught and encouraged to take care in their creative process as they turn their hemp whole goods into ready-to-use or ready-to-sell conditioned merchandise, also known as retail goods.

Hemp Nation acknowledges that everything made in these Finishing Labs, belongs to the artist, to keep or to sell. Artists are encouraged to only keep what they need and prepare the rest to sell in the retail market, hence, the artists have become their own bosses. Also, these artists can now effectively reproduce every aspect of their product, having obtained knowledge and skills they can employ at will for their own independence.

This is where Hemp Nation brings in the storefront and restaurant, “Wake & Bake” in Alamosa, CO. Just like Hemp Nation, Wake & Bake is also run by volunteers and will serve a full breakfast menu 24 hours a day while providing a retail venue for hemp goods. Artist’s from Hemp Nation may also choose to sell their handcrafted hemp goods at Wake & Bake. Proceeds from sales are then split equally between Hemp Nation which puts 100% of its funds back into the next generation of programs, and the artist.

Opportunities at Hemp Nation take three forms:

a.) Full-Time Volunteers:  Those who have chosen to devote at 32 - 60 hours a week toward the development, success, and daily operation of Hemp Nation. Full-time volunteers receive free meals, limited assistance with housing (based on current availability) and other essential needs as set forth and approved by the board of directors. These dedicated volunteers run the day-to-day operations of Hemp Nation, receiving no direct compensation, but are granted full access to all services and benefits of the Hemp Nation facilities during their personal time for the length of time they are active Volunteers for Hemp Nation. 

b.) Part-Time Volunteers: Those who donate less than 32 hours per week. Part-time volunteers eat with full-time volunteers and are only granted access to all of the services and benefits of the Hemp Nation facilities as agreed upon. 

c.) Members: Those who pay a fee to access the services and benefits of the Hemp Nation facilities. Members work under the direction of a designated instructor, following all rules and regulations of the lecture or lab. Members also receive 10% off in store retail and dining purchases, 50% off local produce and free domestic shipping of our retail products. Members also receive invitations to attend special events

d.) Students: Those who pay a fee for a specific lecture or lab and only have access to the related services and materials for the duration of the event. 

Hemp Nation has been running with less than ten full time volunteers and we are ready to mature to the next level. This core group dedicates their time, talents, and energies in exchange for job security, steady meals, and the chance to make an independent future for themselves that cannot be taken away. These are exciting times as we push forward with our plans to expand and open our doors to more full time volunteers. In order to make sure that our volunteers — and thus Hemp Nation — is successful, we need an extra push of cash to get us on our way. 

Our Capital Plans

We are looking to build two water wells to supply all the water we need for next season's hemp crop, the potable water needs of our resident volunteers, and the water for our edible food garden. $12K - $20K

Currently, Hemp Nation is run completely off the grid by the use of solar and propane. The solar power rig was donated and could easily support several more batteries before reaching its limit. We would like to have enough solar power to be able to get through an entire harsh winter night. $3K

Additional funds will go to increasing the space we have for volunteers. We are currently offering three (3) meals a day. With the additional volunteers, that means even more supplies. $300/week-of-meals/10 volunteers. Our goal is to extend this program to sustain 30 volunteers. We are always on the lookout for old RVs or trailers and the cost to purchase and remodel varies. Summer will bring the ability to make earthen homes with perhaps some plumbing.

The rest of the funds will go to getting a few other items to help make Wake and Bake a success:

1.) Supplies to build a walk-in cooler and freezer

2.) Large dough mixer

3.) Tableware and general supplies

If we are able to meet our funding goals, our dreams of expansion will be realized. Hemp Nation functions with the ability to scale according to its resources. All the volunteers live simply, we practice transparent and controlled spending, and we are committed and motivated to succeed.

Will you please help us by making a small donation so we may go forward and make this a true Hemp Nation?

story:
Hacking Education and More with Simple Ideas

The Hack Learning Series is what our schools and our teachers have needed for decades. Schools don't need more policy. They don't need more standards or more tests. Teachers need quick fixes to the problems that plague them daily. Hack Learning books provide amazing, quick fixes that schools can implement immediately, with no-nonsense strategies from expert Hackers. The first two books are currently in production, but we need your help to put them in teachers' hands. 

Something new

Don't miss our update in the "About HLS" section below: We've got an amazing new HLS product!

The Hack Learning story from author Mark Barnes

For more than a decade, I failed my students. I tried to teach 12-year-olds from a dusty old box filled with worksheets, lectures and coffee-stained bubble tests. The kids hated my class and, worse, many hated learning. Just when I thought about giving up on teaching, an amazing thing happened. I read one powerful book about what motivates people, and I knew that my philosophy of teaching and learning was archaic and wrong. This epiphany helped me realize that learning should be engaging and fun; that even big problems can be solved with surprisingly simple ideas. To see these ideas, our learning needs to be hacked.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Become an Executive Partner--Our Top Perk

Remember, our soon-to-be-launched Hack Learning App will have tens of thousands of users. We'll feature our Executive Partners there, too!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------What helped me solve my problem was someone else's experience and objectivity, coupled with a hacker's mentality. During the last decade, I've worked with professionals who understand the hacker's mentality: They see solutions most people do not see. I've spent years honing their approach, and I've recruited some of the best hackers in the world to help me build the Hack Learning Series--books that solve big problems with simple ideas right now--no 5-year plan needed. 


About the Hack Learning Series

The Hack Learning Series is an ongoing, independent project. Initial production includes four professionally published books with both ebook and beautifully produced paperback versions. 

Updated March 23

We are also developing a Hack Learning Series app, which will put all of our content in the palm of your hands on iPhone, iPad, Android, Windows Phone, Kindle Fire and Nook,  All books in the first wave will be published in the next 16 months, and our app will be available in April. Campaign contributors will receive a variety of perks, including supporter recognition, eBooks, hard copy books and, get this, books for life at the Partner level. More important, you'll be part of what promises to be education's game-changing series. 

Your donation helps fund our startup costs: expenses absorbed prior to publication of the first book

  • initial series setup fees
    • publication
    • distribution
    • copyright registration
    • ISBN purchase for hard copy and eBook version (5 books)
  • graphic design
    • HLS logo
    • Hacking Education front and back cover (both pictured below)
    • eBook cover
    • Front and back cover design for the second HLS book, which will begin production prior to the publication of Hacking Education
  • production
    •  editors
    •  proofreaders
    • interior book designer
  • App development 
  • marketing 
    • web hosting
    • advertising
    • press release
    • HLS gear

The Hack Learning Series flagship book

The Impact

Most education books are packed with research, statistics, abbreviations, philosophy, 5-year plans, and some contain empty promises from people who either have never taught or haven't been in a classroom in decades. Hack Learning books provide real answers from amazing Hackers--the best in the business.

Support our Hackers

Hack Learning Series authors are internationally recognized experts, who provide practical advice from experience. Mark Barnes' first book, Role Reversal, was named a Best Professional Book by Teacher Librarian Magazine. Mark's Assessment 3.0 sold out on Amazon, during the pre-sale period. Mark's Brilliant or Insane blog attracts hundreds of thousands of readers monthly  Hacking Education co-author and our lead consultant Jennifer Gonzalez publishes Cult of Pedagogy, one of education's most popular resources. Jennifer's article "Nothing Says Over 40 Like Two Spaces after a Period" has been read by more than 400,000 people. Mark Barnes, Jennifer Gonzalez and other HLS authors bring the Hacker mentality (experience and vision) to books that are easy-to-read blueprints for change. Our mantra is: Read today, implement change tomorrow. 

What schools need and Hack Learning books give

  • A guiding theme: Education, Assessment, Common Core, Digital Literacy, Leadership, Poverty, Special Education, and many more
  • 10 Hacks: simple solutions to the problem from leading experts in the field
  • Blueprint for change: step-by-step guidelines for easy, immediate implementation of every hack
  • The Hack in Action: Yes, others have done it
  • How to overcome pushback: Every book explains how to handle pushback from the naysayers
  • Advice for getting started immediately
  • A plan for capacity building: How to extend the hack over time

Praise from other education experts

Our challenge

Rather than selling the Hack Learning Series to a publisher, we decided to remain independent and maintain complete control over all parts of the project. Our mission is to produce the best problem-solving books that education stakeholders have ever seen, in a short time, with a small team of the very best Hackers in the world. However, we believe our independence is our strength. The Hack Learning Series is our baby--and yours. It will have our undivided attention and unconditional love, and our readers will benefit from books that arrive quickly and come with a reasonable price. 

Help us meet this demanding schedule

  • Hacking Education: 10 Quick Fixes for Every School (our flagship book): July, 2015
  • Hacking the Common Core: 10 Strategies for Amazing Learning in a Standardized World: December, 2015
  • Hacking Digital Literacy: 10 Ways to Mobilize Learning at Home and in School: March, 2016
  • Hacking Poverty: 10 Keys to Helping Our Neediest Children: July, 2016
  • And many more planned
Hackers have simple ideas that solve huge problems

You can make teaching and learning better 

Other Ways You Can Help

Unlike major publishers who have mailing lists with millions of people, we rely on you to spread the word. So please do any of the following that you can:

  • Tell everyone interested in teaching and learning that real answers are on the way
  • Please use the IndieGoGo share tools to like, tweet, embed on your blog and email this campaign to friends, family and colleagues; remember, when you share this campaign, you are helping reform education and improve teaching and learning for our kids
  • Subscribe to the Hack Learning newsletter for amazing weekly learning hacks
  • Visit HackLearningSeries.com often for updates new learning hacks and please like the Hack Learning Series Facebook page
  • Become a Hacker: Share your own 30-second hacks on Twitter at hashtag #HackLearningSeries. We'll share them with the world, and you'll become a recognized expert
  • Please contribute any way possible. While we may not be ending world hunger, we are changing the way people solve problems, and that's a pretty big thing

story:
See the Updates section for the latest news on this campaign!

Hello! We are the Green Dot Homer Team. We’re a group of instructors who have been working since 2012 to deliver bystander education classes to people in Homer Alaska, and the surrounding communities. Bystander education is a unique way of tackling violence by empowering people to stop it in the moment and to see that we each have a role to play.

A green dot is simply a moment in time when someone uses their words or actions to make it less likely that someone will get hurt. Green Dot is a way of looking at the problem of violence with hope that it can be solved, and that we all have a role to play in solving it. The numbers are on our side: most people don’t want the next act of violence to take place. As individuals, we have the power to influence our friends, family, coworkers.

In the past year, almost 200 people have been trained in Green Dot techniques. We’ve presented at health fairs, in workplaces, to clubs, and are now working toward teaching high school students these powerful skills that apply to bullying and teen dating violence as well.

Our goal is to raise 10,000 in order to train 1,000 people in Homer. That’s almost a fifth of Homer’s population. Which means that in your average Homer restaurant, one person at each table would be trained.

We’ll do this in two different ways: 1) By working with workplaces to train their employees, making their workplace a green dot spot; and 2) by training the rest of the folks who are interested in gaining the skills Green Dot offers.

Training people incurs certain costs, which can’t be covered by grant funding. We like to provide snacks and incentives for the people who come to the trainings and the workplaces who decide to become a Green Dot spot. It’s part of what keeps the movement alive. Instructors donate hundreds of volunteer hours to meet and study materials, while workplaces often support their staffs’ wages and donate the space. With $10,000, we can focus on actively recruiting workplaces and people for trainings without worrying about how we can pay for it. We can make Homer an exponentially safer pace.

Each cent you donate, except a 6.75% transaction fee from this website, goes to Green Dot Homer unrestricted funds which will help us purchase incentives for people who get trained and purchase supplies that will drastically increase our ability to support businesses and groups that want a safer, violence-free environment. Even if we don’t reach our entire goal, the money you donate will still go to help support Green Dot’s efforts in Homer, Alaska.

Thank you for taking taking the time to read about  our chance, please consider donating and sharing the link to this page on social media!

story:
We are a Greek research group of electrical engineers envisioning a green planet. With raw materials and passion we change the way you move. With our hand-made, eco-friendly, prototype, electric vehicle constructed from scratch, your 1.000 km trip will now cost less than 20 cents of a euro. It's time for you to become part of this effort. 


What is “Prometheus”?

“Prometheus” is a non-profit research team of the National Technical University of Athens - Electrical and Computer Engineering Department. Prometheus members design and construct high efficiency electric vehicles. All students are undergraduates and PhD candidates of the specific department.




Why “Prometheus”?

Prometheus was the Greek mythical titan who gave mankind fire after stealing it from the gods. Fire changed mankind dramatically. Our vehicle is named "Pyrforos" which means “he who brings fire". Our team is named after the titan “Prometheus” being the symbol of our University. 


Now it’s our time to bring a new type of “fire” as he did thousands of years ago. Αn ultra-efficient green way to move.


What do we do?

Our team continuously upgrades all of the vehicle’s components by re-designing and re-constructing them.  Prometheus is one of the few teams in this competition which possesses a significant know-how in the entire range of electric vehicle development.



What have we constructed so far?

"Pyrforos II" is our team's newest accomplishment and the successor of "Pyrforos". Seven years of challenging improvement enhanced our experience and know-how in the electric vehicles design and construction. As a result, driving "Pyrforos II" is actually cheaper than using your laptop computer!
"Pyrforos II" technical features: 

Kerb Weight:                                 39kg 
Nominal Race Consumption:  60W
Race speed:                                   27 km/h 
Top speed:                                     50 km/h
Range:                                             60 km 
Battery Recharging Time:        30 minutes
Cruise Control:                             ECO Adaptive   



What have we accomplished so far?

Our team is steadily improving its ranking in the "Shell eco-marathon Europe"  races every year. Last year's performance achieved 10th position among 50 participants in the most competitive category of the race.  It's noteworthy that teams from industrial European countries with large budgets were ranked lower than our team’s vehicle.

Another important success was attained by "Prometheus" in 2013. Our team received the "Best team spirit award" among 200 competitors. The award pertained to the team's promotion of Greek culture, the vigorous team work, spirit and enthusiasm. In addition, after hard training on safety methods and applying a rollover protection system at "Pyrforos II", we were received 2nd place for the "Off-track Safety award 2015".


Due to the fact that we have minimal financial resources, we had to achieve our goals through other routes: Those of innovative, inexpensive, yet effective means. 

What is the main goal?

Our short-term goal is the implementation of our newly developed propulsion system technologies in "Pyrforos II" and their demonstration at the "Shell Eco-marathon" race in London next summer. Elevation and sharp turns make the new track a new challenge for all teams. We should now possess not only efficient vehicles but strategic driving plans. Due to those reasons, we are planning to construct a new electric motor and a power inverter specifically optimized for the track conditions and different driving strategies. 



As far as the electric motor is concerned, we want to proceed with the assembly and testing of a tiny, high-speed, high-efficiency electric motor coupled with a reduction gear, to power the rear-wheel of the vehicle. The new motor is expected to have equivalent efficiency with the old one, but in a remarkably higher speed range of the vehicle. Thus achieving improved efficiency in sloping roads and therefore enhanced economy.



Besides the new motor, we are already designing a highly efficient controller that converts the direct current from the battery to smooth three phase ac current that excites the machine stator . The control strategy being used is a robust field oriented control via space vector modulation. Cutting-edge discrete mosfets will replace the old all-in-one module and increase further the efficiency. The inverter circuit will also enable us to view what 's happening inside the motor in real time by sending signals wirelessly to our laptops. An autopilot program that will follow an energy optimal policy is also under development. 



What are our mid-term plans?

The next big step for "Prometheus team", a dream yet to come true is constructing "Pyrforos U". An Urban, electric vehicle with amazingly low running costs. Taking advantage of the team’s know-how in designing efficient vehicles, we can now step up and construct a vehicle to compete in the “Urban-Concept” category of “Shell Eco Marathon” and get a big step closer into being able to mass produce a cheap, environmentally friendly vehicle that anybody could drive in a city environment. A true vehicle that would be greek from top to bottom. The design and the specifications of "Pyrforos U" are depicted below. The appropriate funding is now required. 


Kerb weight:                                        80 kg
Motor Power:                                      6 kW
Torque:                                                 100 Nm
Motor efficiency:                               >94%
Acceleration:                                       5.5 sec 0-50km/h
Top speed:                                            100 km/h
Range:                                                    60 km
Battery Recharging Time:               30 minutes
Dimensions:                                         230 cm x 105 cm x 122 cm (L x H x W) 

Why was our team created? 

For the first time in 2009, a small group of students began representing the National Technical University of Athens and Greece in the world's most competitive ultra energy efficient vehicles' race, "Shell eco-marathon Europe". The substantial aim of this effort was to inspire young Greek engineers in developing energy efficient technologies for a greener world. It is noteworthy that most of the initial team members as well as their successors are now working in the R&D departments of the greatest automotive industries, developing the electric vehicles of the future. 

Why do we need your support?

"Prometheus" is neither funded by the University nor by the Greek State. All previous funds and sponsorships have been granted by Greek businesses and the private sector. Although funding has always been uncertain and unpredictable, we have always managed to collect the necessary financial support. In the past two years, however, support has been scarce due to the economic crisis and deep recession in our country. Therefore, most Greek business sponsorships go to charity organizations, placing technological and scientific research initiatives in a lower priority. 


Taking into consideration the growing interest of people who believe in the necessity of a greener world, we came up with the idea of crowdfunding. Our initial, main goal is to achieve fundraising covering the pink section of the chart. Should we manage to reach this goal, we will continue our efforts to accumulate the financial support necessary for the construction of "Pyrforos U".



Who receives the money?

Contributions are deposited into the Institute of Communications and Computer Systems (ICCS) account which manages the finance of all the research programs of our University with tranparency. This means that every expense incurred for equipment, expendables etc. is verified by the Institute for its necessity, usefulness and validity.

.
