story:
Education Crisis in Africa: In School, But Without Books

Promoting Global Learning (PGL) is a UK charity (Registration Number: 1158202) established in 2014, by Sue Gerrish and Henry Yentumi, with a vision to raise the standard of education in Africa. Following several visits to Africa, Sue and Henry realised the challenges African children face to learn and they became passionate about transforming their life chances. In England, children are very fortunate to have an abundance of books and to be surrounded by stimulating, colourful and well-resourced schools and classrooms. In Africa the situation is quite the opposite:

  • Of Africa's nearly 128 million school-aged children, only half have the opportunity to attend school and learn basic skills.
  • An estimated 37 million African children learn so little while in school that they are hardly better off than peers who never went to school.
  • More than 90% of African children who attend school have never owned a book of their own.
  • Teachers use a ‘chalk-and-talk’ method of teaching a class of up to 60 pupils. This is a valid teaching method but only 78% of schools have blackboards and less than 50% of schools have chalk.

Within a few months of setting up, PGL had filled a garage with old textbooks, story books, stationery and laptops kindly donated by schools in the UK. Now they have collected more than 500,000 essential books from over 500 schools and individuals across UK, which are ready to be shipped to Africa. PGL's next goal is to ship a container of 100,000 books to pupils in nursery and primary schools in Ghana and to set up 3 mobile libraries in communities which have limited access to books or lack the funds to build a permanent library.



Help us to set up three Mobile Libraries for children of the Upper West Akim District in Ghana

We are getting ready to ship more than 100,000 books to Ghana and to distribute our educational materials through 3 mobile library vehicles. These libraries will provide services to disadvantaged schools in the Upper West Akim District of Ghana and aim to ignite a passion for learning, reading and exploring among local children.

  • Upper West Akim District is located in Eastern region of Ghana and has a total population of 97,950. 
  • 65% of the working population is engaged in agriculture and their income levels are extremely low.
  • There are 167 public schools available at the basic level. The total number of students at school is 19,811 with approximately 15,000 students in nursery and primary schools.
  • 13 primary schools are operating under trees; and a further 10 primary schools and 8 junior high schools have no permanent classroom blocks.
  • The pass rate for Maths is 27% and for English is 22%, 11 schools have a zero percent (0%) pass rate. 


To make this happen, we need to raise £60,000

Your contribution will make an enormous difference in the lives of thousands of children in Ghana. The fund will be used for:

  • Shipping: £3,000 - Shipping a container of 100,000 books from UK to Ghana.
  • Mobile Library Vehicles: £34,000 - Purchasing 3 second-hand Transit type vans in good condition: each costs around £11,300.
  • Interior Design: £4,800 - Designing, shelving and colouring  expenses to decorate the vans and turn them into to 3 efficient and friendly mobile libraries.
  • Annual Staff Salary: £3,200 - Hiring 3 drivers and 3 librarians.
  • Staff Training: £1,500 - Organising training for our staff and volunteers. We plan to engage 2 volunteers per community.
  • Annual Fuel Cost: £5,400 -  Average monthly fuel expense per vehicle is around £150.
  • Repair & Maintenance: £2,100 - Average annual repair & maintenance cost of £700 per vehicle.
  • Annual Insurance: £1,000 - Insuring 3 mobile library vans.
  • Annual Storage & Garage: £5,000 - Renting a storage unit for books and a garage for the mobile library vans.

If you help us to meet our goal, your kindness will not go unnoticed or unrewarded. Please check out the right rail for the packages of authentic African perks you could receive as a way of saying thank you for your vital contribution.


Minimising operational risk through local partnerships

Creating change like this is not an easy thing to do. We have formed local partnerships with “Street Library Ghana” and “Wechiau Community Library” in Ghana. Our partners’ commitment, insights and experience will maximise our efficiency and access, enabling us to deliver books to the most vulnerable children in rural communities. 



The Impact

We are inspired by the words of Kofi Annan,“knowledge is power. Information is liberating. Education is the premise of progress, in every society, in every family." 

Imagine a world where children must learn to read without books. Imagine a classroom where over 60 children are studying from a few copies of old, uninspiring textbooks. Sadly, this is the reality in many schools in Africa. 

Through your help, we are able to provide a well-resourced and inspiring learning environment by organising reading clubs and introducing a library concept to thousands of vulnerable children in deprived rural communities. Together, let’s transform the life of many children in 2016.


Your contribution will give hope and opportunity to many children in Africa. We promise to keep you posted regularly on how your generosity has transformed the lives of the children.Thank you.


For Further information, please check our website:
http://www.promotinggloballearning.org/
story_txt:
Education Crisis in Africa: In School, But Without Books 
Promoting Global Learning (PGL) is a UK charity (Registration Number: 1158202) established
in 2014, by Sue Gerrish and Henry Yentumi, with a vision to raise the standard
of education in Africa. Following several visits to Africa, Sue and Henry realised
the challenges African children face to learn and they became passionate about transforming their life chances. In England, children are very fortunate to have an abundance
of books and to be surrounded by stimulating, colourful and well-resourced schools
and classrooms. In Africa the situation is quite the opposite:



Of Africa's nearly 128 million school-aged children, only half have the
opportunity to attend school and learn basic skills.
An estimated 37 million African children learn so little while in school
that they are hardly better off than peers who never went to school.
More than 90% of African children who attend school have never owned a
book of their own.
Teachers use a
‘chalk-and-talk’ method of teaching a class of up to 60 pupils. This is a valid
teaching method but only 78% of schools have blackboards and less than 50% of schools
have chalk.

Within a few months of setting up, PGL had filled a garage with old
textbooks, story books, stationery and laptops kindly donated by schools in the UK.
Now they have collected more than 500,000 essential books from over 500 schools
and individuals across UK, which are ready to be shipped to Africa. PGL's next
goal is to ship a container of 100,000 books to pupils in nursery and
primary schools in Ghana and to set up 3 mobile libraries in communities which
have limited access to books or lack the funds to build a permanent library.



Help us to set up three Mobile Libraries for children of the Upper West Akim District in Ghana


We are getting ready to ship more than 100,000 books to Ghana
and to distribute our educational materials through 3 mobile library vehicles.
These libraries will provide services to disadvantaged schools in the Upper
West Akim District of Ghana and aim to ignite a passion for learning, reading and
exploring among local children.





Upper West Akim District
is located in Eastern region of Ghana and has a total population of 97,950. 


65% of the working population is engaged in agriculture and their income
levels are extremely low.


There are 167 public
schools available at the basic level. The total number of students at school is 19,811 with approximately 15,000 students in nursery and primary schools.


13
primary schools are operating under trees; and a further 10 primary schools and 8 junior high
schools have no permanent classroom blocks.


The
pass rate for Maths is 27% and for English is 22%, 11 schools have a zero percent (0%) pass rate. 









To make this happen, we need to raise £60,000




Your contribution will make an enormous difference in the
lives of thousands of children in Ghana. The fund will be used for:




Shipping: £3,000 - Shipping a
container of 100,000 books from UK to Ghana.


Mobile Library Vehicles: £34,000 - Purchasing 3 second-hand
Transit type vans in good condition: each costs around £11,300.


Interior Design: £4,800 - Designing, shelving and colouring  expenses to decorate the vans and turn them into to 3 efficient and friendly
mobile libraries.


Annual Staff Salary: £3,200 - Hiring 3 drivers and 3 librarians.


Staff Training: £1,500 - Organising training for our staff and
volunteers. We plan to engage 2 volunteers per community.


Annual Fuel Cost: £5,400 -  Average monthly
fuel expense per vehicle is around £150.


Repair & Maintenance: £2,100 - Average annual repair & maintenance cost of
£700 per vehicle.


Annual Insurance: £1,000 - Insuring 3 mobile library vans.


Annual Storage & Garage: £5,000 - Renting a
storage unit for books and a garage for the mobile library vans.


If you help us to meet our goal, your kindness will not
go unnoticed or unrewarded. Please check out the right rail for the packages of authentic African perks you could receive as a way of saying thank you for your vital contribution.

Minimising operational risk through local partnerships

Creating change like this is not an easy thing to do. We have formed
local partnerships with “Street Library Ghana” and “Wechiau Community Library”
in Ghana. Our partners’ commitment, insights and experience will maximise our efficiency and access, enabling us to deliver books to the most
vulnerable children in rural communities. 





The Impact




We are inspired by the words of Kofi Annan,“knowledge is power. Information is liberating. Education is the premise of
progress, in every society, in every family." 
Imagine a
world where children must learn to read without books.
Imagine a classroom where over 60 children are studying from a few copies of
old, uninspiring textbooks. Sadly, this is the reality in many schools in Africa. 
Through your
help, we are able to provide a well-resourced and inspiring learning
environment by organising reading clubs and introducing a library concept to thousands of vulnerable children
in deprived rural communities. Together, let’s transform the life of many children in
2016.


    
Your contribution will give hope and opportunity to many
children in Africa. We promise to keep you posted regularly on how your generosity has transformed the lives of the children.Thank you.


For Further information, please check our website:http://www.promotinggloballearning.org/

story:
Kensington Winter Solstice 2015

A non-profit, hand-made, commerical free festival!

Produced by Red Pepper Spectacle Arts
www.redpepperspectacle.weebly.com

With your generous donation you will be helping Red Pepper Spectacle Arts produce this beloved commercial-free grass-roots celebration that transforms the streets of Toronto’s historic Kensington Market. 

This event beckons the return to light on the eve of the winter solstice, every December 21st. On this longest night thousands of decorated revelers take part, with hand-made emblematic lanterns, encountering on route, tented-theatrical scenarios of shadow play, rooftop masking antics, roving giant puppets and stilted dancers with eclectic musical accompaniment. All are illuminated by the glow of fire breathers and spinners, a Fire Finale in Alexandra Park, and a community feast for the numerous volunteers harkening the return to light. 

Even a small or medium donation will help us pay for things like - artist fees, production and design costs, administration, rentals, permits, materials and much more. 

Many thanks for your continued support of the Kensington Winter Solstice and Red Pepper Spectacle Arts.

ABOUT
Red Pepper Spectacle Arts co-creates and facilitates multi-disciplinary collaborative arts engagement cross-culturally. We work in collaboration with social service agencies, various communities and other arts organizations towards greater social justice, accessibility and equality in cultural production. We pursue the highest standard in artistic practice and create an environment where all skill levels have access and opportunity to achieve significant results and creative success with a wide variety of media.
www.redpepperspectacle.weebly.com


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate but still want to help in some way contact kinoshameg@gmail.com

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Volunteer
  • Bring a friend to the event!
  • Attend a lantern making workshop
  • Email us if you have another idea to help

    Thank you so much for taking the time to visit our campaign and we will see you at the festival!

    Many thanks

         Red Pepper Spectacle Arts Staff, Board of Directors, and artists.

story:
American Historical Theatre: 

We Educate! We Entertain! We Inspire!

American Historical Theatre has been providing educational, engaging, and entertaining First-Person programming for over three decades. AHT's focus is to tell the stories of the heroes and heroines of our political and cultural past. In many cases, these are the stories of ordinary people who decided to do something extraordinary; Such is the case of Rosa Parks.

  • Rosa Parks has yet to be developed by AHT and we feel that the time is just right. This year marks the 60th Anniversary of the day she made history in 1955!
  • The United States Congress has called her the "First Lady of Civil Rights"  and "The Mother of the Freedom Movement." 
  • What did one young woman on a Montgomery Alabama Bus do to deserve such accolades and why? What was she thinking? What drove her to her actions and what did she hope to achieve? How did this change her life, and the lives of others in the United States?
  • Providing the answers to these questions in an educational, entertaining, first-person program is the work of American Historical Theatre.
  • With your help, AHT will bring Rosa Parks' story to new audiences. The story will be told by Rosa herself, as portrayed by first-person interpreter Alexandra Ford.

Why is this campaign called: Adopt a Character?

Because we need to research, write the script, costume, and present Rosa Parks, and we need your help!

  • Your contributions will pay for her books, her schooling, her clothing, and all the preparations needed to raise the character of Rosa Parks up in the world.
  • Miss Ford has her work cut out for her. For Rosa Parks, Miss Ford will need to gain a complete understanding of Rosa Parks, the United States in the 50's, a segregated South under the Jim Crow Laws, and the growing Civil Liberties movement. That takes many, many hours of time and devotion, but she still has to live in the 21st Century and that takes money.
  • December 1st, 2015 marks the 60th anniversary of Rosa Parks' arrest. It is also the date that Miss Ford will be ready to debut Rosa Parks at the Powel House in Philadelphia. Donors at the $100+ level will receive an invitation to her first-person presentation and the reception to follow.
  • Donors at the $50 and $25 level will receive items crafted to remember the important anniversary. They are of course, also encouraged to attend her debut on December 1, 2015.
  • If the financial goal we set is not reached, it will be harder on AHT. We are a very small not-for-profit, but we are still are committed to bringing up Rosa Parks.

The Impact your donation may make:

Rosa Parks said: "I'd see the bus pass by me every day...but to me, that was a way of life; we had no choice but to accept what was the custom. The bus was among the first ways I realized there was a black world and a white one."

  • Rosa Parks' story will serve to remind all who hear it that we cannot always stand by and observe the status quo. Sometimes, we have to take a seat to be heard and knowingly place our personal comfort aside in order to bring about the changes that will help "We the People..." form that "...more Perfect Union" that is our Nation's promise.
  • Perhaps the next Rosa Parks, the next Frederick Douglass, or the next Malala Yousafzai may be sitting in our audience. They will be inspired by the true stories of personal bravery, and someday they may take their opportunity change the world for the better. Your donation will have helped to make such an inspiration possible.
  • This is Phase 1 of our Adopt Rosa Parks campaign. $3500 will get her to the Powel House on December 1, for her 60th Anniversary.
  • Phase 2 will be a call to action to go the rest of the distance and develop a curriculum relevant program for school age students. We then need to actually bring the performance to the students or bring the students to the performance. Again, this takes money and we need your help!

This is AHT's first effort at Crowd-funding.

It is hard to ask for money, but AHT's devoted Actor-historians depend upon non-profit funding to keep their important work going. We strive to keep history alive and relevant so that the rising generations aren't doomed to make the mistakes of those who came before them. Perhaps they may even choose to model their actions on the stories of those people who accomplished great things.

If we only achieve part of phase one this time around, that will still be a great start. If you can't donate now, there are other ways you can help.

  • Even if you are unable to contribute financially, you still can help! Share this campaign with your friends and followers. Every share helps, and AHT thanks you for it.
  • Indiegogo has customizable share tools! Rosa Parks did what she could to insure that we continue to live in a free country, so Feel Free! to explore the possibilities of how you can help us get her message out to the rising generations, And, potential donors.
  • If we are successful, there will be future campaigns because there are many more great stories to tell. AHT plans to "adopt" Jacqueline Kennedy Onasis, John Hancock, and Frederick Douglass to name a few. You can continue to get the word out, create a buzz, and help us continue to achieve our goals: to Educate, Entertain, and Inspire!

story:
Indiegogo just extended our campaign deadline for more ten days, Will you join us in supporting kids learning and building the next generation innovations, authors, activists and entrepreneurs?


Our Palm Tree Academy  set up a new model of peer-to-peer learning  that focuses on training kids and young adults in technology, design, drama, and business skills that helps them become authors, perform freelance digital work, engage in creative self-expression, and (eventually) become entrepreneurs.

We all know that donating to kids learning is one of the best things we can do – we are giving them skills their schools can not offer  and supporting  skills-centered education  which is suitable for poorer communities of the world. Your donation will help kids get a solar powered training set like the one below.


Help us reignite kids innovations; with you, we are creating a new generation of innovators creating lots of stuff like, locally engineered sanitary towels, writing kids play books, drama skits and producing short videos about their innovations.  We are  helping our students attain the vital technological skills their current education system cannot afford to provide them with.

 Some of the cloth and Dashiki ladies wallets made by kids;


Our model also caters for and gives special attention to children with disability to support their learning and innovations. We all know they have extraordinary skills, don't we?

WHY YOU NEED TO SUPPORT INNOVATION TODAY 


Every dollar that you pledge will go towards supporting the Palm Tree Academy  to ensure it is as successful and impactful as possible. Here’s how your money will be used.The money will be used in four primary areas:

  • Securing kids education – we want to ensure  that every kid's education is secured. We are giving them skills their schools can not offer!  We are  pioneering  skills-centered education  which the sustainable in poorer communities of the world.
  • Supporting girls sanitation - We are not only focusing on kids learning  but also putting lots of energy and resources to promote their innovations. We are  training hundreds of school kids to produce locally engineered sanitary towels for girls.
  • Let Kids, dance, play and write their own drama – the success of the program greatly depends on how we counsel and keep kids engaged in drama and music. Your contribution will support kids learn, play and dance. Be sure we will send you a copy of their DVD.
  • Creating learning space –  Your contribution will help open up community skills incubation centers where kids  learn and  show their innovations to the world. With you, we are creating leaders that challenge their communities most pressing problems

One of our volunteers demonstrating how Microsoft Word works on a tablet to South Sudanese school children.

Your contribution will support kids learn, play, dance and innovate solutions to change their worlds. We'll send their DVD of their innovations.

For every $5, our team of 63 volunteers donate 720 hours per week to kids learning. We are pioneering kids innovations in one of the poorest countries in the world; South Sudan.

MEET SOME OF OUR TEAM MEMBERS



Imagine a world where every child has the opportunity to grow and prosper, where education, technology, and knowledge are open to them, to help them be the best they can be. Would you help us bring a new educational program to South Sudan that could change the future of children in this beautiful, but resource-challenged country?


Palm Tree Academy seeks your help in providing  kids a fully-packaged learning program that promotes learning and  innovation. We are not helping kids learn together but turning schools and communities in centers of innovation.  Our kids are divided into three main innovation clubs;  1. Girls Health;  2. Technology,  3. Drama and Arts

WHAT WE HAVE ACCOMPLISHED

So far, we have been able to put together really dynamic programming with young adults and kids combining instruction on computer use,  community organizing, arts, and social.  We develop and identify organizers, educators, and artists committed to social and economic justice. We now have a strong network of 63 volunteers. Most important is the Pam Tree Academy was founded by ICOD Action Network; a highly impactful nonprofit in East Africa

Michael trains South Sudanese team in November how to collect data using tablets


WHY ARE ILLITERACY RATES SO HIGH?

After 21 years of devastating civil war, South Sudan got its independence on June 9 , 2011 and was beginning to thrive. But then  Civil War  and genocide started again in December 2013 and progress came to a standstill. Thousands died and  schools in the country were destroyed and closed!
Forced cannibalism, gang rapes and death by burning are among the atrocities marking the brutal civil war taking place in South Sudan despite the peace agreement.

This is the reason we opened up the Palm Tree Academy to promote kids innovation from anywhere within their communities.  We all know kids have amazing skills, are full of imagination, can change  and shape their own world. This is why our volunteers are dedicating invaluable energies see kids grow and learn.

An empty classroom (left) and a tree shade class on the right. Will you join us to improve kids education?

What we’re creating in  South Sudan for $3,500 would cost much more than 100 times that amount in the United States or Europe.

SOME OF OUR PERKS

We are nonprofit: But we request you to select from one of our several excellent African perks like South Sudan themed Dashiki (sample below)  as a way to thank you for your contribution!




Postcards and calendars, jewelry, clothing, or handmade South Sudan art. Postcards,  jewelry, and calendars can be shipped to you before Christmas, clothing will sent to you in January.

____________________________________________________________________________

Donations over $100 will be recognized with their names engraved in  Donor Render  blocks in all  community incubation centers.  The Donor Wall will become a stunning representation of the support from the local, regional, and global communities.

____________________________________________________________________________

If we are lucky to raise more, our  stretch goals are as below


Importantly, your money will NOT be used in the following areas:

  • The prize money.
  •  Staff salaries and offices.
  • Funding teams to do their work.
  • Fundraising activities and events.

TWO WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

These are two ways in which you can play an essential role in the success of the Palm Tree Academy:

  1. Contribute! - a great place to start is to choose one of our awesome perks. Check top right corner of this page to find out more!
  2. Refer Friends - Use the the social media and email  tools to share our campaign with friends and encourage them to contribute  too.

LIKE & SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN ON FACEBOOK! A LARGE PORTION OF THE DONATIONS  CAN  COME FROM LEARNING ABOUT IT THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA. SO, GO! LIKE! SHARE! TWEET!

story:
Qui suis-je?

Je m'appelle Rabelais Marius Nkounawa.

Je suis étudiant camerounais, titulaire d'un Master en sciences de la population et du développement, et je suis actuellement en thèse de doctorat à l'Université Catholique de Louvain en Belgique sous la direction du Professeur Philippe De Leener, appuyé par Philippe Bocquier, Bernard Fusulier et Felix Metchuyie. 

La rareté des bourses dans le domaine des sciences sociales fait que je suis obligé de faire des jobs d'étudiants pour subvenir à mes besoins. Mais dans cette étape de la recherche, la nécessité d'un budget conséquent fait que je me tourne vers vous pour solliciter un mode participatif de financement de mes recherches de terrain au Cameroun. 


Mais de quoi je veux vous parler concrètement ? 

Je fais un doctorat en Etudes du Développement sur la relance de l'agriculture familiale en Afrique en général et au Cameroun en particulier. Tout part d'un constat, qui est qu'aujourd'hui la situation socio démographique et économique de l’Afrique démontre que l'agriculture familiale est la plus pratiquée, et qu'elle seule au contraire de l'agro business peut apporter les solutions aux problèmes de l'emploi du chômage et de la protection de l'environnement, tant en milieu rural qu'en milieu urbain. 

Je part de ce constat logique que si les sociétés africaines aujourd'hui sont en proie à des changements, lesquels changements commencent par la plus petite entité sociale qui est la famille. Dans cette logique, les modes de productions de ces familles pour la plupart agropastorales changent aussi, en ce que l'unité de reproduction biologique est en même temps l'unité de production économique. 

Seulement, presque aucune des politiques publiques mises sur pieds tant au niveau local, national, régional ou même dicté par les institutions internationales ne prend en compte cette donne. On peut comprendre pourquoi autant de politiques sont autant d'échecs! 

   Quels sont les impacts sociétaux de ce projet? 

Je me dis donc que pour comprendre la construction et la persistance des freins à l'agriculture familiale en Afrique, il faut interroger au préalable ces mécanismes fondamentaux relatifs aux changements à la fois structurels et fonctionnalistes de la famille. 

Alors sans doute que des politiques mieux adaptées, mieux ciblées seront proposées aux agriculteurs. Alors sans doute que la relance de l'agriculture en Afrique et au Cameroun seront enfin des réalités, et permettront l'amélioration des conditions de vie des agriculteurs et une source d'espoir pour cette jeunesse africaine de plus en plus nombreuse, de plus en plus déboussolée, et dont on a l'impression que le rêve ultime dans fort bien de cas se résume dans cette impression, dans ce sentiment illusoire que l'avenir se trouve ailleurs !

Où se déroulera la recherche de terrain proprement dite? 

La recherche de terrain se déroulera au Cameroun, dans la région de l'Ouest, en pays Bamiléké, sur une période de trois mois, de janvier 2016 à mars 2016. Longtemps considérée comme "le grenier du Cameroun" et dans une large mesure de l'Afrique centrale, cette région est aujourd'hui en proie à un taux d'exode supérieur à toutes les autres du pays. Et la question dont de savoir qu'est ce qui se passe fondamentalement dans ces sociétés pour que le mouvement des populations soit contraire à celui de tous les discours politiques qui considèrent l'agriculture comme le moteur du développement du pays? A notre sens, les arguments de pénibilité, de rentabilité, sont relativement éculés, tant les métiers alternatifs à l'agriculture ne dérogent aucunement aux causes généralement évoquées pour l'abandon de l’agriculture. 


Alors que j'essaye de comprendre les freins à l'expansion agricole en Afrique, j'en ai moi même, des freins! Vous connaissez le nerf de la guerre... 

Pour la réalisation de cette recherche sur le terrain au Cameroun, j'ai besoin d'un montant de 5000$ réparti comme suit

- Voyage aller/retour: 1000$

- Frais de séjour: logement, nutrition, santé: 583$/3 pendant trois mois.

- Dépenses liées à la recherche proprement dite : transport, matériel de collecte et d'analyse des données, rémunérations des accompagnateurs, frais de communication avec les encadreurs en Belgique et au Cameroun: 583$/mois pendant trois mois. 

- Dépenses diverses et frais d'hébergement du présent appel par Indiegogo: 500$. 


Comment contribuer et qu'est ce que vous obtenez en retour de votre participation? 

Les suggestions de contributions sont les suivantes et correspondent chacune à un plat traditionnel Camerounais, pour rester un peu dans le thème de la recherche :) Les récompenses pour les contributions sont décrites dans la rubrique Contreparties.  
       

    


D'autres façons d'aider

Si vous pouvez pas contribuer cela ne veut pas dire que vous ne pouvez pas aider :

  • Demandez aux gens de passer le mot et de faire de la publicité autour du projet S'il vous plaît. 
  • Rappelez-leur d'utiliser les outils de partage Indiegogo !

Merci de tout coeur !


Who am I?

My name is Rabelais Marius Nkounawa.

I am a Cameroonian student with a Master’s degree in Population and Development Studies, and I am currently working on a doctoral thesis at the Université catholique de Louvain in Belgium.


Due to the scarcity of funding for research in the social sciences, I have to work student jobs to support myself financially. However, at this stage in my research, I need more substantial financial support, which is why I am asking for your participation in financing my field research in Cameroon.

                              


But what am I talking about exactly?

I am doing a PhD in Development Studies on the topic of reviving family farming in Africa in general and Cameroon in particular. My research is inspired by the observation that, in Africa’s current demographic and socio-economic situation, family farming alone – not agribusiness – has the potential to address unemployment and environmental protection issues in both rural and urban settings.

My logic is that changes in African societies today begin in the smallest social unit: the family. The modes of production for these families, most of which are farming families, are changing, in that the biological reproduicing unit is at the same time the unit of economic production. 

But almost none of the public policies set up at the local, national, or regional level or even dictated by international institutions take these changes into account. It’s easy to see why so many policies fail!

Where will the research take place?


My field research will take place in Cameroon in the western region of Bamiléké over a period of three months, from January 2016 to March 2016. Long considered "the breadbasket of Cameroon" and to a large extent Central Africa, this region is now experiencing a higher rate of exodus than any other region in the country. The aim of my research is to explore why such movement in population is occurring, despite all of the political discourse promoting agriculture as the country’s engine of development. This exodus cannot simply be attributed to perceptions among Cameroonians that farming is unprofitable and laborious; in reality, the alternative to farming is no more profitable and no less strenuous than farming itself. 


Just as I am trying to understand the barriers to agricultural expansion in Africa, I myself am confronted by barriers! 

For the realization of this field research in Cameroon, I need a total of $ 5,000, allocated as follows:
- Roundtrip travel: $ 1000
- Living expenses: housing, food, health: $ 583/3 for three months.
- Expenses related to the research itself: transportation, equipment for data collection and analysis,  various remunerations, cost of communication with my supervisors in Belgium and Cameroon: $ 583 / month for three months.
- Miscellaneous expenses and hosting fees from Indiegogo: $ 500.


How to contribute and what you will get in return for your participation


Suggestions for contributions are as follows and each corresponds to a Cameroonian traditional dish, to stay a little in the research theme :) Awards for Contributions are described in the compensation section.

    

   


Other ways to help


If you cannot contribute financially that does not mean you cannot help:
• Please ask people to spread the word and advertise this project.
• Remind them to use Indiegogo sharing tools!

Thank you very much!

story:
The Association of Collaborative Politics (ACP)

was founded on the mission of bringing Americans with different ideas together for a common purpose. It is most important to know that we are a non-partisan organization with no allegiances to any political party. We want to foster a collaboration between all parties and ideals. Now, more than ever, we experience a political environment that is partisan and divisive. In the midst of the divisiveness, Americans are put off by political bantering and gridlock on issues that are the most pressing of our time. This is what ACP seeks to end. We know different ideas exist and we know there are many possible solutions to the toughest issues of the day.

What We Need & What You Get

We want to raise funds to grow ACP! It has a solid foundation with dedicated staff that includes:

Anthony Schullo, Director
Kevin Useni, Director
Shelby Fischer, Development Coordinator
Emily Labedz, Educational Outreach Coordinator
Anna Labedz, Digital Media Coordinator

Help us grow our not-for-profit organization by joining our vision of issue-based communication, issue-based action, and political engagement by Americans of all ages. We can be that organization, with your help.

Donate $10 or more and we will send you a thank you that will include this "Stop! Collaborate & Engage." bumper sticker to signify your commitment to political engagement, idea-sharing, and issue-based action.

Your support is important to us! We aren't going to use funds for political campaigning, or donating them to unnecessarily powerful political action committees. We want you to help us break down the political barriers and get back to the issues that effect your life.

Become an active member in your democracy, in your government, and advocate for the issues that are important to you! Here is how we do it at ACP:

Our Mission:
The Association of Collaborative Politics seeks to provide an environment for constructive, collaborative, issue-based involvement as a means of improving our communities and our country through political engagement, political idea-sharing, and civic education.

Our Goals:
– To respect and understand the views and opinions of individuals from all political parties.

– To encourage the collaboration of different ideas as a means of finding solutions to the issues.

– To provide civic education and political resources to individuals attempting to learn more about the political process.

– To become, as an organization, an active part of the political process with the help of dedicated members.

– To facilitate dialogue that focuses on solutions to the issues, what we call “issue-based communication.”

What We Don’t Stand For:
– Discriminatory conversations/remarks geared toward an individual or population of people based on race, sex, class, sexual orientation, religion, or political party affiliation.

– Dialogue that seeks do put down others opinions, rather dialogue that seeks to understand and consider them.

– Criticism of government institutions or politicians without a desire to research and learn more.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not only can you give to ACP, but you can get involved as well! We would love to have you on board and engaged.

  • Visit our website at acpolitics.org.
  • Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.
  • Reach out to us at info@acpolitics.org to find out other ways to engage yourself in the political process!
Thank you for your support in getting what is sure to be an impact organization off the ground.
- Your ACP Leadership Team

story:
Short Summary

My name is Chris. On 19th December I will be moving to Istanbul, Turkey. I am asking for your help because I will not be able to take anything with me and I can only just pay for rent. Donating to this campaign would mean so much more to me than just getting furniture, it means that someone actually cares and that I will not be left with an empty house when I move.

What I will get out of the money

It will be used for furniture, future rent payments and for food, electricity and water.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not willing to donate today then you can always subscribe to my youtube channel which I will link below. It is free after all.

LINK:

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCil-0AZ46gzzaFPPTcjEMYg

story:
Please help save the Rozhen Observatory, Bulgaria.

Dear friends of Astronomy,

The Rozhen National Astronomical Observatory (NAO) is the greatest astronomical complex in South-East Europe. There are 3 telescopes made by Carl-Zeiss, Jena: a 2-m reflector, one of the largest in Europe, a 60-cm Cassegrain, a 50/70-cm Schmidt telescope, and a 15-cm Solar Lyot coronagraph.


Rozhen NAO places Bulgaria among the nations with their own facilities for space exploration. Rozhen telescopes are used for observations of a wide variety of astronomical objects: Solar system bodies (comets, planets, asteroids), stars, nebulae, and galaxies. Astronomers, students, PhD students, and their lecturers use the entire infrastructure of the Observatory for research and training.

The results of this research are published in prestigious international specialized journals. Regarding scientific indicators, Bulgaria ranks 43rd in the Physics and Astronomy area and 40th in the Astronomy and Astrophysics category among about 200 countries in the period 1996-2013 (according to Scimago Journal & Country Rank Scimago ). This is due to the high professionalism of the Bulgarian astronomers and to the availability of good astronomical infrastructure, such as Rozhen NAO!

To function normally, the telescopes of Rozhen NAO need permanent technical care, since the maintenance of the telescopes and their equipment is an integral part of the scientific process and, therefore, requires adequate and regular funding.


That is why, pressed again by the adverse financial conditions, we, the astronomers of the Institute of Astronomy and National Astronomical Observatory – Rozhen, as well as of the other astronomical centres in Bulgaria, are forced to address all who are concerned that NAO proceeds to fulfil its mission as a research and education centre. Yes, it concerns the equipment of the NATIONAL Astronomical Observatory and NOT the scientists themselves.


Other Ways You Can Help

All donations (regardless of their size) that would be credited to Rozhen NAO will be used SOLELY for the Observatory. These are resources necessary for the operation of the telescopes and for the purchase of imminent supplies for the scientific equipment. Each year an individual report on the funds received and their detailed expenditure will be worked out. The report will remain public and everyone will be able to access it on the website of NAO – www.nao-rozhen.org

Donations to the Rozhen National Astronomical Observatory are welcome to the following

Bank account:

Societe Generale Expressbank

56 Bulgaria Blvd., 4700 Smolyan, Bulgaria

IBAN: BG94TTBB94003120017759;  BIC: TTBBBG22

Institute of Astronomy, NAO-Rozhen

Sincerely Yours:

Prof. Dr. Tanyu Bonev,

Director of IA and NAO
